name: Presidente. –
text: I would remind honourable Members that there is no catch-the-eye procedure for this debate, nor will 'blue card' applications be accepted. Before giving the floor to the Bulgarian Prime Minister, Boyko Borisov, I would like to thank the Bulgarian Presidency for its fruitful cooperation with the European Parliament.  I would like to thank the representatives of the Bulgarian Government who have taken turns in this House. We have signed many rules together. It has been a fruitful presidency, and I would also remind you of the initiative on the Western Balkans, to which the European Parliament attaches great importance.  I would also remind you of the attempts made by the Bulgarian Presidency to try to resolve the problem of the reform of the right of asylum, which remains a priority for us, and I call on Bojko Borisov, in his capacity as Head of Government, to continue, at future Council meetings, to support the initiatives of the European Parliament. (The sitting was suspended for technical reasons linked to the interpreters' strike.)

name: Presidente. –
text: We can resume the sitting; I apologise to Prime Minister Borisov for this interruption, which is too long as far as I am concerned, caused by the attitude of some Members who prevented the technicians from restoring the audio service, because they wanted to sym health with the interpreters and therefore prevented the technicians from entering the room, playing a role as trade unionists.  But the negotiations are between the interpreters and the administration, so it was not up to them to intervene. That is why we are late, for which I apologise to the Bulgarian Presidency and to all the other Members.

name: Бойко Борисов
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President Tajani, Honourable President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen of MePs, Members of the European Parliament, as you know on July 1st, our Presidency ended and six months ago I stated from this stand that Bulgaria will work with everyone in a constructive, dialogueal and pragmatic way, that we will rely very much on an open and continuous dialogue with the European Parliament in order to achieve as much as possible , therefore, to all political parties, to all the MPs, to all of you, Mr President and Mr President, thank you for the exceptional support we have had as your presidency in all the working committees, sessions, big thank you! We reached 41 agreements with the European Parliament out of 105 we inherited, 45. We have closed so much more in the Council so that our Austrian colleagues can start negotiations with you as early as July, and I hope that Sebastian Kurz and his colleagues in Austria will not have such a start in the Presidency.   We have set 4 main priorities and made successes and progress on all of them. Undoubtedly, our greatest success was to achieve the theme of the European perspective of the countries of the Western Balkans. We have put this on the line because we understand their accession to the European Union as a condition for better development and for the security of the whole of Europe. There can be no peace and prosperity on the continent until all of Europe is united. I think our efforts have worked. The Summit in Sofia on 17 May helped Athens and Skopje resolve the name dispute. This is a historic moment and an achievement that we should all be proud of. You've supported us very much, too. The next big step was last week, when the Council decided when and how accession negotiations would begin for the Republic of Macedonia as well as Albania.  And of course, I leave it last, but it gave the launch, the agreement on good neighborliness between Bulgaria and Macedonia, with which we opened the topic and gave a personal example.  We are pragmatic, we have worked hard for the connectivity of the region because political declarations are important, but citizens need to see the real results in their daily lives. Corridors 4, 8, 10, digital infrastructure, railways, ports – this will allow for much greater prosperity, connectivity and, of course, the lifting of gross domestic product in the entire Balkans, not just the Western Balkans.  At the Meeting in Sofia, we agreed to provide additional means of connectivity, 11 transport projects for a digital programme in the Balkans, for energy connectivity, for young people through Erasmus+. We have seen the same enthusiasm and pragmatism in our other priorities. We defended the interests of the citizens of Europe and tried to be balancers and honest intermediaries. We proposed and organized a meeting European Union – Turkey in Varna on March 26 to sit together at a table and discuss the accumulated problems. We have restored dialogue with Turkey. Our agreement with Turkey is working, we have zero migratory pressure. This gives us reason to propose to address the problems of migration to seek such political solutions with other countries.  We have made great progress by improving the Schengen Information System, the Visa Code and the Schengen Border Code, as well as interoperability. So on the subject of migration, Europe has done a lot, the Commission has done a lot and we have also tried to make our contribution.  On the reform of Dublin, the asylum system: we invested a lot of effort. We left no stone unplaced and achieved quite a lot with your support, 4 of the 6 open files are on the final line. Thank you that the European Parliament has shown flexibility and has been a key partner. But the general decision has yet to be taken and that is why we were looking for a compromise by early dawn of the European Council. I'm proud we made it. Once again, Europe has shown that it is ready to work together and find European solutions. We are deeply convinced that with our work we have laid the foundations for a good and sustainable solution.    There are many more themes on which we have achieved results in the name of a better future for Europe. It is difficult for me to list everyone, but I would also like to mention the social pillar, the Energy Union, the Banking Union, the Digital Single Market, where we have been extremely successful, as well as the preparations for the European elections in 2019.  We have also adopted the European Union's first industrial programme for military capabilities. Many are, but what they all have in common is that we have found unity – both in the Council and with you, the representatives of the citizens. Our successes are also yours, because if we didn't work together, they would never have happened. That's what we promised at the beginning of our presidency, and that's what we did. We sought consensus between states and institutions, even when there was great controversy.  I would like to thank you once again and wish to continue in the same cooperation with our colleagues in Austria, because the foreign policy environment for Europe is dynamic and complex. This, of course, also influenced the Bulgarian Presidency.  I will highlight some of the factors that cannot be left on the European agenda. The U.S. and President Trump's decisions. At the informal dinner in Sofia, we talked about trade relations with the US and withdrawal from the Iran agreement. We had to protect our European interests, and that is mandatory.  Brexit is not only an internal but also a geopolitical problem. It is very important that the outcome of the negotiations does not jeopardise the security of Europe and its citizens. The situation in Africa remains very difficult. There is the source of migratory pressures towards Europe, which is why at the Council last week we discussed the financial opportunities for Africa and continued investment in the partnership with these countries.  Terrorism remains a serious threat, we have worked hard to improve security across the European Union, but this remains a serious problem.  Bulgaria will continue to support the European Union in combating these challenges. I believe that during our presidency we were able to capture the pulse of events and give a very good foundation to our colleagues from Austria, as we received from Estonia. Once again, I would like to congratulate Yuri and the Estonian Government on their presidency, and I really hope that we have come close to the high criterion they imposed. Bulgaria will continue to look ahead and work towards its full membership in all the policies of the European Union, Schengen and the euro area. We achieved high economic growth of 4%, unemployment fell below 6%, low external debt below 30%, 24% to date, Jean-Claude. We have a significant financial reserve and in practice it is zero budget deficit – sustainable, for years. We have shown that we are a loyal partner and we are patient. I believe in diplomacy, not the practice of vetoing it. We all know how it ends.  The motto of the Bulgarian Presidency was "Unification makes power" and today, after 6 months, we can say that the power of unification is the future of Europe. So thank you again. I thank the teams of both President Tajani and Jean-Claude Juncker, these tens, hundreds of technical persons at all levels, experts, the translators thank you for their cooperation, for the fact that our first presidency, at least in the general opinion, was successful and Bulgaria as a country feels a proud member of the European Union. I also thank all bulgarian MPs from all political groups for working hard and helping a lot.

name: Presidente. –
text: Before Giving the floor to Jean-Claude Juncker, I must inform you that all today's work will be delayed by half an hour due to the blocking of the repair of electrical services caused by some of our colleagues who prevented the services from repairing the devices. We will therefore have to postpone everything by half an hour, so the votes will also take place at 12.30 p.m.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to say something about what has happened today, but I will not do it. But I should, because this is not normal. Full stop. (Applause)

name: Le Président. –
text: I agree with you because it is unacceptable to block the work of Parliament on the side of Members.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Commission President. Mr President, every time I speak in an insufficiently nuanced way about parliamentary procedures, you interrupt me right away. Therefore, I refrain from saying what should be said. In fact, we would not have done that if Mrs Merkel or Mr Macron had been present. We would never have done that.  Independently of that, I would like to start by thanking Prime Minister Borisov and his entire team for a very successful presidency. On a more personal level, he personally, because he has the merit of a successful presidency; Lilyana, who was the real engineer of this presidency; and for the high quality of the public service in Bulgaria and in Brussels, the ambassador and all those working with the Prime Minister in Bulgaria, in Sofia and elsewhere. Well done, a great job. Thank you for that. (Applause) The motto of your presidency was 'United we stand strong', and this sums up the way you have approached your presidency. You did it every hour, every second, every minute, and it was a pleasure to work with the Bulgarian Presidency. I hope that this good tradition initiated by Estonia and continued by Bulgaria will prevail during the Austrian Presidency. You have built bridges, you have brought people together, and in the more specific areas you have delivered. This is true of everything that has been done in relation to economic and monetary union. This is true of modernizing telecommunications rules. This is true for everything concerning digital Europe and the work of the Bulgarian Commissioner for these affairs, in whom I have full confidence and for whom I have great friendship. The Bulgarians, on both sides, were excellent. The digital economy, led by the Bulgarian Presidency and Mariya Gabriel, has made great progress. The same applies to the governance of the Energy Union. That is why I am particularly pleased that you have been able, in difficult circumstances, it must be said, to carry out the work on seconded work. You have contributed, more than others, and in difficult circumstances for you, to make the principle of 'equal work, equal pay in the same place' the guiding principle of all the social policies of Europe.  Sie waren sehr stark in Sachen Westbalkan-Politik. Wir haben oft dar-ber gesprochen, wir waren in Sofia, wir waren in Warna, wir waren 'berall, weil das Thema Westbalkan ' ' so wie Sie es versprochen hatten 'berall im Mittelpunkt Ihres Tuns stand. Sie haben dafar gesorgt, dass die europeische Politik, die europeische Perspektive des Westbalkans in der Region besser verstanden wird. Es gab ja beim Amtsantritt dieser Kommission Entt-uschung, als wir sagten; es kàme in dieser Legislaturperiode von 2014-2019 zu keinen neuen Beitritten. Wir sind uns jetzt dar-ber einig geworden, dass groe Anstrengungen erforderlich sind, Sie haben aber wesentlich dazu beigetragen, dass das Unerkl-rliche im Westbalkan erkl-rbar wurde. Ich habe mich dafar zu bedanken, genau wie ich mich dafar zu bedanken habe, dass Sie immer bereit waren, in Sachen Au-engrenzschutz Ihren Mann zu stehen. Boyko, excellent!

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Prime Minister, Dear Boyko Borissov, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Rapporteur on the work he has all said. When we met in January and discussed what was to come, we crossed our fingers and wished the young Bulgarian Presidency all the best. Today Prime Minister Boyko Borisov and his entire team are back here and can take stock. It is a fantastic record, it is a strong record that has been achieved in the last six months. Thanks to the Bulgarian leadership, Europe has made a great deal of progress. On behalf of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to express my sincere thanks for this. It has strengthened Europe. I would like to thank your team, the Minister and all my cabinet colleagues. I would like to thank Marija Gabriel, the Bulgarian Commissioner, who built bridges and helped to initiate and accompany many dossiers. That was a good community effort. When we look at the content, the first thing that comes into view is the economy, the internal market. I like the results of geo-blocking, we in the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats like the results that we provide 30% of European content for digital content, that is, to strengthen European culture. Energy governance has already been mentioned and the Defence Union has also been strengthened under your Presidency. Europe has been strengthened in the economy. The second major issue I would like to emphasise is the issue of migration. You have demonstrated that the protection of Europe – securing borders, securing borders with determination – and humanity fit together. We have completed the resettlement under your Presidency – a package that makes it clear that Europe is still open to people who are really in need, and on the other hand, on the external border, you are showing how we can really protect Europe in a humanitarian way and properly protect it by not having illegal migrants in bulgaria. Both points good points! I think that is also a good argument to say now that Bulgaria should now also become a Schengen member. Bulgaria has demonstrated that it can secure its external borders. Bulgaria has shown that it can do its homework in internal security. The criteria have been completed. That is why the interior ministers should now finally deal fairly with this issue of Bulgarian membership in the Schengen area. (Applause) The Western Balkans have already been mentioned. The question is whether we export security to the Western Balkans or whether insecurity is imported into Europe from the Western Balkans. That is the question that is in the room, and that is why we must now turn to it. Your presidency has focused on this. I think it is important that this has been backed up by concrete projects. Ladies and gentlemen, we have had an experience over the last six months, namely that when the Heads of State or Government meet there, there is a dispute, there is a dispute, that national selfishness is practised, and on the other hand, we have seen that, when there is a strong Presidency of the Council, an enormous amount can be achieved together with the European Parliament. That is why I say that the Europe of the institutions, of the Commission, of Parliament, of the Councils of Ministers in Europe is making progress and is achieving good results for the people and that the Europe of states, of national selfishness, is unfortunately not in a position to solve the tasks of our time. I believe that this is also a recognition of this Presidency. Therefore: Thank you again, dear Boyko Borissov! Clear course for Europe – with you in the leadership of the Council, we have had a strong European advocate who does not veto, but practises partnership. I would also like to make it clear that Bulgaria has joined the ranks of the large states that are advancing Europe. A great record! Thank you very much for that.

name: Eric Andrieu
text: On behalf of the Group of The President, Mr Prime Minister, Mr President of the Commission, on behalf of the Group of Social Democrats, I thank you and congratulate you on this six-month presidency, which has seen a great deal of progress in our institutions. I believe that the work that has been done on the Western Balkans is a considerable amount of work and you have said it and President Juncker has pointed out that on the question of Albania and Macedonia, the agreements are there. Bravo for this work of dialogue, congratulations for the method, congratulations for the energy and the way you have dynamically all these territories. It has also been said, we are not going to repeat ourselves, on digital, you have proposed it as a strategic priority and I think it is safe to say here, thanks also to your Commissioner, that things have made great progress at the Union level. Our shared history will remember that your work has contributed to the progress of this major subject in favour of the balance of the development of the territories. There are points that I would like to highlight, mainly and in particular the political agreement that was concluded in a trilogue on 20 June last under your presidency on the draft EU-wide governance regulation on energy and climate policies which should enable the eu's energy and climate targets to be achieved in Europe by 2030 with a 40% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 40 per cent. a minimum share of 32% of renewable energy in the EU's energy mix and a target of 32.5% energy savings. These issues and objectives are important, but not sufficient if we are to collectively meet the objectives of COP 21 and perhaps the power outage we suffered here at the beginning of the session is here to remind us. We must always go further in terms of energy if we are to achieve our collective objectives. It is a lot of work, and I wanted to thank you publicly for that. I would also like to congratulate myself, on environmental issues, that during your presidency, and I know that this particularly affects your Commissioner, you were able to obtain a majority in the Council to ban the three bee-killing neonicotinoids. This is a major biodiversity issue. We had failed on glyphosate, where you won on neonicotinoids, and I think the Europeans today are grateful. Again, we need to go further in biodiversity. I am concerned about two issues. First of all, with regard to the MFF , and this was not in your mandate - it is worrying not to be able to convince the Member States of the need to devote an ambitious budget to the European project in the making. We must now strongly point out the need to give the Union a strategy and a major role at the international level. Finally, I will highlight the limits of the Council on immigration on 28 and 29 June. The decision that was made there, although difficult, was a minimum decision. It is therefore a small regret towards this Presidency.

name: Ангел Джамбазки
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of ministers, honourable Prime Minister, it is quite obvious that the technical preparation of the Presidency of the Government has been excellent and this is visible and heard by all who are in the Chamber. Technical files, all things related to digitisation, social pillars, the fight to protect our interests with regard to posted workers, etc.  Much more important are the few political issues that have been posed and protected. There is no Bulgarian who does not understand the importance of not have borders between Ohrid and the Black Sea. This is what is thought of in the European Union. For this, the setting of this topic is an undeniable success, as for the European Union, because it signals development, signals a halt to centrifugal processes, especially after Brexit. I can't help but congratulate you on that. I congratulate you, of course, on the policy that the government is leading in terms of maintaining balance and good relations in the countries within the European Union. Don't punish Hungary, Poland, prepare for excellent relations with the UK after Brexit. They must remain our not only partners, but our closest, most heartfelt friends, partners with whom to work together in the field of defense and security. I congratulate you for defending a policy that has been personally mine and my political organisation since 2013 with regard to illegal migration. For example, strong security at the external borders, combating sewage and lubrication of sewers, preventing the application of unfair clauses in the Dublin Regulation that harm border states, because, let's remind us, our countries, specifically Bulgaria, were not colonial states, did not profit on the basis of foreign resources, foreign labour, and there is no reason for us to pay foreign bills.  For this reason, whoever wants to accept displacement is his personal will, but we cannot and should not do so, and here I encourage you to continue in this direction to protect our interest and the interest of the countries we represent.  In conclusion, after the congratulations, I would like to invite colleague Keller again to visit Pirin, now in the summer it is even nicer, to see how nice the mountain develops. I hope she was able to count the lifts in Germany. Only last year there were built about 300, in Bulgaria not one was built. Here you go, we'il have a cup of tea, i hope it'il be interesting. Thank you, good luck to the next Austrian Presidency.

name: Илхан Кючюк
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of commissioners, honourable members, honourable Mr Borisov, I congratulate you on the end of the Bulgarian Presidency. I do it without unnecessary pateism, because neither Europe, letly less Bulgaria, needs it, as we do not need directed applause, because they interfere with objective analysis. That's what I usually say. Undoubtedly, our Presidency has revived the policies of the European Union forgotten in recent years. We cannot help but note the positive development of enlargement policy, and in particular the emphasis that has been placed on the Western Balkans. Today, for 4 of the countries, the map seems drawn, but we must not forget the other two – Kosovo and Bosnia and Herzegovina. I very much hope that the upcoming Presidencies will continue to actively work towards the integration of the Western Balkans. And despite progress on a number of legislative initiatives, we remain vital to our common future. The European Union remains in a difficult position, there is no significant progress on Brexit. Until last week, there was no clear solution to the refugee crisis, and it is not yet clear how we will deal with migration management and a number of other common challenges.  Bulgaria receives congratulations on the well-organized events of the presidency calendar, but receives no confirmation that it is a serious economy with an invitation to the Eurozone. Therefore, there is no official intention expressed by the Bulgarian Government. We have not received confirmation that we are a country that can be trusted with an invitation to Schengen, despite public promises to do so. Together with Romania, we continue to be part of the security and verification mechanism.  Our country can be proud of its contribution to European civilization, with the work of the holy brothers Cyril and Methodius, the rescue of its Jews, its unique modern ethnic model. There may be many examples here, but we cannot be proud of the fact that you first empowered extreme nationalism in Europe and thus introduced duality in terms of the values of the European Union. Of course GERB did it with the blessing of the European People's Party. This is what happens in other countries. There is no way to fight double standards at European level when you show duality in terms of principles in your own country.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I would like to say to the Prime Minister that it’s fair to say we still have a lot of problems in Europe which have not been resolved in the last six months. We have the eurozone issue, we have Brexit and so many other things. However, Prime Minister, I really wouldn’t blame it on you. We have inside as well as outside problems. We have a big German governmental crisis that is blocking everything and we have governments playing hardball on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). We even have the Austrians playing foul, and they have only just started their Presidency! In other areas, however, it has indeed been possible to succeed. One of them was on the Western Balkans, on which I congratulate you because I think it’s really important that countries receive a reward if, like in Albania, they make huge reforms or, like Macedonia, they agree on solving such a big problem. I hope everyone in this House will support the agreement. (Applause)  Finally, putting the Paris Agreement into EU law was a big achievement under your Presidency so I congratulate you on that. I hope that, as you leave the Presidency, you can take with you the spirit of biodiversity – many colleagues have said how important that is – because Bulgaria is also so rich in biodiversity and natural beauty. I have had the opportunity of visiting Pirin National Park: it is really fantastic and we should do everything possible to preserve it. Lastly, I also hope your Government will be a bit more forthcoming on corruption because this is a big obstacle in many Member States. I hope you were also able to experience media pluralism and pluralism of opinion here, and how enriching it actually is. I hope that soon we can all travel to Bulgaria without having to show our passports and without any other problems. (Applause)

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, thank you for the floor. The Bulgarian Presidency has inherited two difficult tasks: one is the issue of Brexit and the other is the issue of migration. After a number of rounds of negotiations on Brexit, there are unresolved fundamental issues. Such is the territorial scope of the agreement, something about the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland. This preseses the looming threat that there may not be an agreement. This must be avoided. We must represent the interests of the EU27, but the only way to reach an agreement is to consider the fair interests of the British people.  There are positive developments on migration at the end of the Presidency, partly thanks to the Italian elections. The emphasis has shifted from addressing integration and migration to preventing it, protecting borders and rejecting mandatory quotas, which can be seen as a positive development. Thank you very much.

name: Мария Габриел
text: member of the Commission. – Mr President, Honourable Prime Minister Borisov, dear Members of the European Parliament, on behalf of Jean-Claude Juncker, the President of the European Commission, I would like to thank first of all for this constructive debate, which very clearly recognises the successful Presidency of Bulgaria.  Congratulations once again to all those involved in this process, to the successful Presidency, which will remain as a Presidency filled with a European spirit of unification, a lot of hard work and concrete steps forward in a number of areas – digitisation, the Western Balkans, social policy, economic union. You have not escaped your attention, extremely important topics on which we will all continue to work. This is the next multiannual financial framework, this is Brexit, these are the themes of migration and security. They were raised by colleagues from the European Parliament and many other important issues. All this has made the Bulgarian Presidency successful, but this leaves a solid foundation for future successes of the Austrian Presidency. From us once again – thank you, and wish the Austrians success.

name: Бойко Борисов
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, once again thank you all.  I listened very carefully to every single parliamentary group. I agree with many things, and for others, of course, we will draw conclusions. I've never claimed to be perfect, I've never said we're sinless, and I don't think there's one in Europe that says it.  So, we are trying very hard to protect the environment, we have made a new anti-corruption body, with a new law, with huge powers, with huge opportunities, and I really hope that this topic will fall off our agenda.  As for the ethnic model, I have always argued that Bulgaria has a unique ethnic model and I have always argued that the role of DPS in this regard has been huge. Democracy in Europe invented political parties, or as Churchill said, and he didn't like them, but nothing better democracy invented. And it was the will of the Bulgarian people to arrange us in the way we currently manage. This is the role of the people, but a voice of the people, a voice of God.  So, let's try and make sure that everyone stands as an earring on our ear, that the ethnic model is the best that Bulgaria has achieved in this field, and it must continue. Yes, political rebukes, struggles, this is normal in politics, but the straight line is that among Bulgarian citizens of different religions we should not give any chance to sprout opposition. So, in this respect, I guarantee you that I am always on the lookout. But the other is the will of the people, the other is the will of the voters, and they have arranged us in this way. And we, in doing so, work, I hope, successfully.  Thank you to the Socialists, thank you to the Greens, thank you to the Conservatives. Brexit, my colleague, is something for which we have actually made a tremendous effort – with Michel Barnier and separately, at least now I am not prepared to tell you – 3, 4, 5 meetings, perhaps with Theresa May, with her ministers, in both London and Sofia. We have tried to resolve as much as possible a normal divorce, a normal Brexit, because indeed Britain is not any country in Europe, and I hope that common sense will actually achieve such a Brexit that protects both the rights of Britain and, at the same time, the rights of the Member States of the European Union. I hope because it is a powerful economy, and we are, here you see, we are one Europe. On the Balkans, thank you once again for helping us, this is our common success. Serbia two more chapters opened, Montenegro, Macedonia and Albania, Kosovo and Bosnia and Herzegovina, a colleague, you can also ask their prime ministers and presidents how many meetings we did, how much effort we put in. They themselves know that they are not yet ready to be offered the status that Skopje and Tirana have been granted. And I'il say why. Already the electoral code in Bosnia and Herzegovina is not clear, they themselves need to line up. The same is largely for Kosovo, there is much to be done, but the way, the talks, their participation in all the meetings... You remember how many years we were observers in the processes, they are at all meetings, they participate, I hear their problems, they know each other, they invite them to Brussels, they have their perspective, and if they do their homework, which we continue to do in Bulgaria, in Romania, of course that the necessary will be done. So, not to be long, and Sabathian Kurtz I'm sure he's excited, advice I would never give without being asked. I truly wish the Austrian colleagues, Chancellor Kurz, all of you, to help them, to be successful, because the success of a presidency is a success for all of us, and vice versa, when mistakes are made or problems are made, it still affects all of us. So, to Sebastian Kurz and to all Austrians, I wish a lot of success. If you need it, we're here for you. Just as I have consulted Yuri in Estonia, we are always at your disposal. Thank you again, it was an honor to be here with you.

name: President. –
text: Prime Minister Borissov, thank you, and I think the applause reflects our appreciation of the work of the Bulgarian Presidency. The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. – Let me, as rapporteur for the Social Democrats, on the so-called 'social democratic system'. To thank your Presidency for the efforts made by Bulgaria to discuss this important legislative proposal. Unfortunately, although the positions of the Member States and the European Parliament still differ substantially on a number of issues, even after the last six months of intensive negotiations, the issue of accessibility has remained high on the political agenda, thanks to your efforts. I also appreciate that Bulgaria is not one of a number of states that have recently been told that they are not prepared to change their position in any way on the required substantial limitation of the scope of the Directive and who, for content or procedural reasons, did not want to continue negotiating the resulting form of this key legislation. Six months ago, at this point, I expressed my wish that the common interest of the two institutions should be to adopt a text that will substantially improve the quality of life not only for people with disabilities, but also for older citizens, and contribute to their full participation in society. I believe that, on the basis of your contribution, the Austrian Presidency will return to the negotiating table as soon as possible so that the European Accessibility Act does not remain merely an unfulfilled promise after many years of waiting. The European Parliament is ready to help.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the presentation of the Austrian Presidency's programme of activities (2018/2593(SDR)). I welcome the Chancellor, Sebastian Kurz.

name: Sebastian Kurz
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Buongiorno Antonio, bonjour Jean-Claude, honourable Members! It is a great pleasure and honour for me to have the opportunity today to be with you in the European Parliament, with you as the elected representatives of the European people at European level.  We met high up in Schladming on Saturday at a summit in Austria to take over the European relay from Boyko Borissov. It was a solemn act, because in Austria, as a pro-European country, we consider it a great honour that we are allowed to take over the Presidency of the European Union.  It is not only a great honour for us, but above all it is also a great responsibility. And I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Bulgarian Presidency on its work over the last six months, a work which, in our view, has been very professional, and we will endeavour to continue the work for the European Union in the same vein. It is a great responsibility that we can assume here in order to make a contribution to the future of the European Union. I admit that, as a young person at the age of 31, the European Union is something of a matter of course for me. In recent years, however, I have become increasingly aware that we, as politicians, must not take the European Union for granted, but must work hard every day to develop the European Union's project of peace and success and constantly change it for the better. As the Republic of Austria, we can take over the Presidency at a very challenging time – at a time of upheaval. We are witnessing an ever-changing political landscape in the United States, which has become more unpredictable for us in Europe. We are seeing an enormous economic rise in China, but at the same time a social model that is far from ours in Europe. And with our largest neighbour on our continent, Russia, we still have ongoing tensions directly in Europe. Within the European Union, tensions have increased in recent years, and there is almost the impression that there are divisions here that need to be overcome. With Brexit, we are witnessing for the first time that after years when only states wanted to join the European Union, one country voluntarily leaves the European Union. Please do not misunderstand me, I was allowed to be Foreign Minister of the Republic of Austria for four years, and every time I travel to outside Europe, I have become increasingly aware of how grateful we can be to live in Europe. I have become increasingly aware that much of what we take for granted in Europe is not self-evident. I have become increasingly aware that the rule of law, democracy, the fundamental freedoms that seem normal to us, are anything but God-given elsewhere in the world. So it is a gift to be able to live in Europe, it is a gift to be european , even at a time full of challenges.  However, in recent years, when I was allowed to travel a lot as Foreign Minister, I have not only become aware that these freedoms, the rule of law and democracy are far from self-evident elsewhere, but I have also become increasingly aware that it is our task to fight to ensure that this remains the case in Europe. The rule of law, democracy, fundamental freedoms – this is not only the foundation for us in Europe, it is the heart of our coexistence. And we, as the Presidency, will play our part in ensuring that these fundamental freedoms in Europe remain a matter of course. In addition, however, it is important to fight to ensure that Europe maintains its competitiveness. Because prosperity in Europe, justice, the European way of life – the model of life of the European Union – depends on our fundamental rights, but it also depends on our competitiveness and our economic performance. We must therefore also work, at a time of digitisation and automation, to ensure that we remain competitive as the European Union, that we are not overtaken by other regions of the world because we are more bureaucratic or slower, but that we must do everything we can to ensure that we continue to be at the top of the world even in this changing time.  That is precisely why we, as the Presidency, want to focus on the big issues. In the spirit of subsidiarity, we firmly believe that it is necessary to focus on big issues, and that is what we want to do with you, together with the European Parliament – but of course also with the Commission. I would like to thank you very much, Mr President, for the good visit to the Conference of Presidents of the European Parliament in Vienna on 19 June: it was a first good exchange in preparation for our Presidency. However, I very much hope that we will be able to continue the good cooperation that we have been able to initiate here, even during the six months, in an equally friendly and professional manner.  We certainly do not agree everywhere, but I noticed at the time that all the political groups in the European Parliament do not always agree. Perhaps, however, this is precisely what makes us in Europe a little bit: that we can afford to disagree, but at the same time we must also know that we should focus on where we agree that we also focus on the objectives, where we can reach compromises.  That is precisely the aim of our Presidency: to be a bridge builder and to focus on issues where it is possible to move our European Union forward together. We put the Presidency under the motto: Europe that protects. We want to focus on challenges that are currently being asked in our time, we want to do everything we can to ensure prosperity in Europe, and we want to do so not only within but also outside our European borders. More specifically, we want to focus on three priorities. Firstly, security and the fight against illegal migration, because the protection of the European population must be a top priority and because we need a paradigm shift in migration policy. There needs to be a greater focus on external border protection as the basis for a Europe without internal borders. In this context, I am very pleased that last week at the European Council – in my view – we managed to reverse the trend and to place an important focus on external border protection, on cooperation with third countries. This is essential, in addition to the debate on the Dublin reform and also the distribution in Europe. In particular, the discussion at German level on national measures on Austria shows us once again that there is a need for a focus on external border protection and that a Europe without internal borders can only exist in the long term if there are also functioning external borders. Secondly, we also want to focus on safeguarding our prosperity. Digitisation and also automation are changing our world, and only if we succeed in leading the way here and taking advantage of the opportunities that arise here will we, as the European Union, continue to be at the forefront of the world. We must do everything we can to ensure that, in future, the large Internet companies are not only created in the United States and China, but are also possible in Europe. As the European Union, we have the best basic conditions: the rule of law, good infrastructure, well-educated people in our European Union and, above all, an internal market of 500 million people. But we must now also create the right framework conditions to ensure high-tech-made in Europe in the future and, above all, to achieve a level playing field. In this context, I support the European Union's idea of a compensation tax for Internet giants, because such a move would contribute to greater equality of opportunity and fairer competition for European companies as well.  (Applause) Thirdly, ladies and gentlemen, in addition to the issue of security and the fight against illegal migration, in addition to the issue of safeguarding our prosperity, it is of course also necessary for us as the European Union to be active in our neighbourhood. A Europe that protects does not end at the European external border. Only if we succeed in ensuring peace, security and stability in our neighbourhood will we be able to guarantee peace, security and stability in Europe in the long term. We want to help improve the relationship in our eastern neighbourhood. In addition to the response to Russian aggression, as well as sanctions for conduct contrary to international law, it is necessary to strengthen the channels of dialogue here again. Because peace on our continent will only be able to exist with and not against Russia in the long term. We also want to step up cooperation with Africa, and I am very grateful to the President of the European Parliament for being a driver here. Only if we manage to improve living conditions in Africa can we ensure that the suffering of the people there is reduced. Only if we are involved in fair trade with Africa Together, while supporting European investment there, we can ensure that there is also sustainable development and prospects for young people. Thirdly, the neighbourhood that is particularly close to our hearts as the Republic of Austria is, of course, the region of south-eastern Europe and, in particular, the Western Balkans. In our opinion, the European Union's project is only completed when the Western Balkans are also part of our united Europe. These states, ladies and gentlemen, have not only earned a European perspective, they have earned their membership of the European Union, and we must give them the best possible support on their way to the European Union. In this context, I am very pleased that it was possible to reach an agreement on the name dispute, and we are glad that Macedonia and Albania will now also be able to open accession negotiations – even if we would have liked to see this more quickly. What is needed, however, is an honest perspective for these states, and continuous progress towards the European Union. Only by ensuring that this will we be able to ensure that other countries in the world do not increase their influence in the region more and more, and only if we ensure that this can we ensure that the European Union project is eventually completed and that these states are also part of our European Union and can also benefit from our fundamental values and the development of the European Union. In addition to the national priorities that can be set during a Presidency, there are, of course, issues on the agenda that we have not chosen. I am allude to Brexit. We are all unhappy that Britain is leaving the European Union, but it is all the more important that we deal with this in an orderly manner. There can be no cherry-picking for Britain, but it is just as important that we ensure an orderly political as well as economic relationship with The United Kingdom. In this context, I am very grateful to the Chief Negotiator of the European Union for his work and we will do everything we can to support him in the best possible way and to ensure the unity of the 27 on this issue. We want to support the European Commission in the best possible way in the negotiations for the next European budget, for the multiannual financial framework, even though we are aware that the negotiations are still very difficult. I believe that we need a good mix of quality and, of course, timing, because both are crucial for the stability of the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, we are aware that we can take over the Presidency of the Council of the European Union at a challenging time. We are aware that it will also be the last full Presidency before the election to the European Parliament, and we are aware that it will be a great effort and effort for us. Nevertheless, we are looking forward to this activity. We ask you to cooperate as best as possible and support the Austrian Presidency, we are glad that we can be bridge builders on some difficult issues in the interests of Europeans, in the interests of our European Union.  (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Chancellor. The protection of the external borders is also very important for the European Parliament and it is important that, during your Presidency, agreement can be reached on the reform of the asylum package, which is a priority for Parliament, given that a text has already been approved which is the result of the reworking of the European Commission's proposal. We would therefore be grateful if the Austrian Presidency could help to achieve this reform.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Mr President of the Commission. Mr President, Chancellor, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I look forward to this Austrian Presidency, because the two previous Austrian presidencies were crowned with success, because all the relevant austrian political forces have also swam in the same direction and have moved coherently in the past. I have actually known Sebastian Kurz for many years, and I know that he is supported by European convictions. The same applies to the Austrian Federal Government. If you were to take a look at the government programme of the Austrian Federal Government – which many do not do, but what many are talking about – you might find that this government programme of the Austrian Federal Government has a clearly pro-European tonality. I welcomed this at the time, and I welcome it now. As in the past, we will have to work together a great deal. The Commission's offer is that we want to do this in friendship and mutual understanding. I am also convinced that we will succeed in this. The Commission will go to Vienna at the end of this week, Thursday and Friday – a beautiful city. We look forward to this visit. I would have preferred this meeting to have taken place in Tyrol, because this is the Austrian federal state that I know best, but Vienna is also okay and carries messages that need to be continued. We will have to talk about the protection of external borders, which is also a concern of the Chancellor. But this is not an invention of this time. The European Commission, which is sometimes a little more far-sighted than the Member States can be, proposed the protection of external borders as early as 2008. It is clear who was against the fact that there should be a European external border protection, there were several German speakers in the association who refused to do so. If we had done so, and if we had implemented the successor proposal of the Barroso Commission from 2013 and the proposals of the Commission I chaired in the Presidency of February, March 2015 in the Council, we would have spared ourselves many problems. (Applause) The Austrian Chancellor recently argued in an interview or in a direct interview – I cannot remember it correctly, probably also in direct conversation – that we should not increase the number of European border guards to 10 000 by 2027, but that we should do so at an acceleration rate for 2020. We will do that. The Commission will put these acceleration proposals on the table of the two legislators in September. I would like us to have 10 000 men on duty in 2020 to support the 100 000 national border guards in their difficult task. Incidentally, I believe that we should literally put in place a genuine, proper, efficient border police force. I am also in favour of swiftly addressing the technical issues, the material issues that arise in this context. I also made this statement at the European Council last Sunday. We need more aircraft, we need more ships, we need more vehicles – wheeled vehicles mean correct German. That is what we should be doing in the coming days and weeks. I would like us to adopt by July the five legislative proposals on asylum, which were also pushed forward with admirable energy by the European Parliament. I proposed this in the European Council. This was not unanimously agreed, but where we agree between the institutions of Parliament, the Council and the Commission on asylum issues, we should do so instead of giving the impression that we are just talking and not acting. We could act! (Applause) I would be glad if the two asylum issues that are still open – you know what I am allabouting – were to be pushed so far by the end of the year under the Austrian Presidency that we could come to a conclusion in the near future. So we need the Austrian negotiating skills. We also need this in terms of multiannual financial frameworks. The Commission has presented its proposals. This does not apply to the unexpected unanimous approval, but we in the Council, under the Austrian Presidency, must start working on these proposals consistently. In the past, we always had a kind of negotiations in toolboxes. There will be no other way. We must, step by step, agree on partial elements step by step that a deal will be possible before the European elections in May next year. I know that this is difficult, both here in this House and between governments, but if the Austrian Presidency does not do what we expect of it, in fact, to work quickly on these issues, we would find ourselves in a similar situation to last time, in the last multiannual financial framework. If we finish too late and are not ready to start on 1 January 2019, we will lose thousands of research places in Europe. However, we have agreed that research and innovation is an absolute priority in the European Union and for the European Union. We have agreed that we will massively expand the Erasmus programme. If we do not achieve this by 1 January 2019, we will not be able to provide positive support to tens of thousands of students and teachers with the Erasmus programme. So, dear Sebastian, there is a lot of work to be done. I know that you work a lot, that you can also empathize with the sensitivities of others. I try to do something similar, I don't always succeed – you don't always, but mostly. Positive negotiations and charm-driven solutions are on the House table. It's not just Wiener Schnitzel that belongs on the plate. But you know that I am a big fan of the Wiener Schnitzel. I was in Mongolia, in Ivory Coast, in Africa, in Asia – Wiener Schnitzel everywhere, but not only Wiener Schnitzel belongs on the plate of the house. (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the A warm welcome to the Austrian Presidency of the Council, to you, Chancellor, dear Sebastian Kurz, i might say a god of greeting. Austria is a strong European country, a great European country. When you are in Vienna, you feel that, if you look into the history of the country, you know that. If I may single out one point, the Austrian Constitution of 1867 has already established a multilingual parliament, as we are today. It has been stipulated that every Austrian citizen has the fundamental right to his own language, culture, traditions. At that time, as in many other regions of Europe, the foundations were laid for what we are now allowed to practice and live in Europe. For example, the fact that a student exchange was established in Austria as early as the 19th century is a beautiful facet that gives us orientation even today. And then in recent history: one of the great pioneers of European unity, Alois Mock, cut through the Iron Curtain on the border with Hungary in 1989, 20 days later Austria applied for membership of the European Union, and four months later the Berlin Wall fell – also a beautiful symbol of Austria's contribution to the unification of this continent. That is why we are looking forward to the Austrian Presidency with the message "building bridges", for which you stand, dear Sebastian, and for which Austria stands. From our point of view, from the point of view of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, there are three areas: firstly, the tasks that you – and therefore you too – are being given by the Bulgarian Presidency. The tasks of the discussion on our currency are part of this, the euro results for the further development of the euro area, which we now had in the Council. My group supports the establishment of a European Monetary Fund, as it is always called. We need more independence from international structures. We support the establishment of an investment budget for the European Union. We have done a lot in reforms: social reforms, labour market reforms. We have done a great deal in the stability of budgets. And now Europe must invest. That is the right time. That is why our group is doing this. We would also like us to talk a little more about successes, because the 2.5% economic growth and the almost ten million jobs that have been created are a strong record that we have already made in recent years. Of course, the Bulgarian Presidency of the Council also includes Europe's second top issue: the continuation of work on migration. You have our full support when it comes to the protection of external borders. A few minutes ago, Boyko Borissov, who is on the Bulgarian-Turkish border, sat in your seat, showing that the protection of external borders is possible, that we can end illegal migration on this continent. Only then will we be able to get the citizens of Europe to be open to resettlement and to the truly wounded in the world, that we also welcome those in Europe. That is why we are fully supported in the protection of external borders. I am also pleased that you have announced that you will convene an Africa Summit, that you will also turn to this continent and that you will stick to the European solution. The third thing the Bulgarian Presidency gives you is the Western Balkans. Thank you for your clear announcements today that this region needs a clear European perspective. The second box we are seeing, of course, is the work on all the issues of this parliamentary term, and it will be an intense working month that is ahead of you. These include fair taxes – treating internet companies in the same way that our craftsmen see taxes collected – and that includes the issue that Jean-Claude Juncker raised, namely the budget. My group wants a modern budget that means less bureaucracy for the citizens. My group is also prepared to talk about saving in Europe. We need to be self-critical about the efficiency of spending – yes. But we also want a budget that means security for the citizens, for those who benefit from the European budget. And we want a budget that makes the future possible for this continent. That is why we want the discussions to be concluded before the European elections. This is a difficult task, but we should try to get it done in 2018. Together we ask you to tackle this task. And last but not least, the third box: themes of departure for this continent. Not only work, not only business as usual, but also Departure. I'm glad you're putting that in the spotlight. You are a young head of government on this continent, you stand for the future of the continent. That is why I am pleased that you are making this so clear: in trade policy – the key question about the economic successes of our continent, the buzzword of unity – on the question of the digital world, whether we can also implement our values, such as copyright, which we will be discussing this week, the ideas that Europe stands for, in the digital world. I would like to point out that in a few days' time Donald Trump and Vladimir Putin will meet in Helsinki. It is also a question of whether we are only fence guests in global development, whether we are just watching what the great blocs of this world decide for us, or whether this continent stands on its own two feet and is capable of taking decisions. And, dear Sebastian, I must also mention this: if we want us to be self-confident in global areas, then we will not be able to avoid the question of whether we should set aside the principle of unanimity on foreign policy issues and come to majority decision-making in the Council. Only then can this continent really bring the power that this continent would have. In this respect, there is a lot to do for you. We wish you good luck, and you can rely on your PPE Group. (Applause)

name: Udo Bullmann
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, Mr President of the Commission, Chancellor, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for his work and for his work My Socialist Group thinks a great deal about the departure of the European project. However, we do not believe in the demolition of the European project. That is why, Chancellor, let me come straight to the question of this morning: in Germany, there have been critical discussions for weeks between two sister parties – the CSU and the CDU – about – I believe – not the relevant issues of migration policy, but on side issues, small questions compared to the big questions. The dispute was about the extent to which people registered elsewhere as asylum seekers can be rejected directly at the german-Austrian border as those who have applied for asylum. The sister parties, if you may call them that, yesterday agreed on a proposal to set up centres where, by administrative agreement, they would be sent back directly: Italy. In Austrian newspapers, and this is becoming a European problem, I can read this morning that your government is saying that if this happens, we will secure the southern border, that is, close to Italy. I want to know: is this the case? I would like to know – because this is no longer just a posse in the Bavarian state government, but a European problem: does Mrs Merkel, did Mr Seehofer consult you before this idea was born? Have you agreed to make this proposal? How do you feel about this and will you agree? Or are we now finally facing a European crisis, where the domino effect is imminent, which will destroy Schengen, which the President of the Commission has always warned about and where he invested last Sunday to prevent it? They would help us with an assessment. I have doubts as to whether all this can still be explained by rational means, after your Minister for the Interior has also said that there are about 20 people a week involved. However, let me embed my discussion in a larger question. Our two countries have been through dark stages in the last century. Europe was given to us, to the Germans earlier, to the Austrians at their own discretion later. We both benefit immensely – economically, politically, culturally. This path has been paved by great personalities, by people like Bruno Kreisky and Willy Brandt, who have taught us to open the door to the east, to unite the family who have looked to southern Europe, who have inspired the North-South dialogue, without which we would not be where we are today. Gyula Horn and Alois Mock – and this has been mentioned – have literally cut the Iron Curtain. This has enabled thousands of my compatriots to make their way to freedom – for which we are grateful. These were great Europeans whose names no one will forget. Now we see 700 gunmen, heavy equipment, helicopters approaching the Austrian-Slovenian border. That is roughly the region that, in 1867, Mr Weber, agreed to have a multilingual parliament. Were we further than we are today? My group says no to this development in Austria too!  (Applause) Armament at the borders within the European Union – yes, where do we actually live? This is not the Europe we want. This is not the Europe we support.  You also disappoint the internal Austrian debate – that seems to me to be urgently needed. I sometimes wonder, when voices are heard, whether the CSU, whether the development of the Austrian People's Party, is evidence that we are entering into the Orbanisation of Europe and also of the Christian Democratic parties. I don't know for sure. Sometimes I think we are entering into despair, into the politics of fear, into politics, to make people afraid of people. My Socialist Group will oppose this, because we stand for the policy of hope! We stand for the policy of the future of the European project!  That is why you are choosing the centre of Europe. If you come back to where we need you, we will also be counting on your vigour in this Austrian Presidency.  (Applause)

name: Ulrike Trebesius
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, Chancellor Kurz, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has Your country took over the Presidency of the Council of the EU on 1 July this year. Many citizens of my country have high hopes for Austria, but also for you personally. Since you formed a government, you have followed up your announcements with deeds. They set important priorities in migration policy, in a performance-based tax policy, in a sensible social policy and in a performance-oriented education policy. Its greatest merit is certainly the closure of the Balkan route, which has given a decisive impetus to a reorientation in European refugee policy. On behalf of many of my compatriots, I would also like to thank you warmly for this.  The external border protection, which has been discussed for many years, is more than overdue. Active action is not accustomed in Germany. The federal government of my country has been sitting out most of the problems for years, delaying them or exacerbating them – whether through incompetence or a lack of will, let us be put aside. In Germany, it is not governed, but at best managed. They want to be bridge builders. This is very important these days, because my country's policy has driven not only a deep wedge into my country, but into the whole of the European Union. But it is not just illegal migration that poses difficulties for the EU. The euro crisis has also been simmering for years. In the nearly ten years since the onset of the financial crisis, little has improved. The south of Europe has made too little progress in reform, debt has risen, and financial markets accept this whole construct only because they are sure that the North will take on the debt. That is also why Mrs Merkel has received so much support in the EU in recent days to keep her in office. In the coming months, the EU wants to make major changes to the European Treaties.  For years, THE EU centralists like Mr Juncker, like Mr Weber, like Mr Verhofstadt, have been working on various proposals that have one thing in common: they want to turn the European Union into the United States of Europe, (interruption: no!) with an economic government, (interruption: no!) with European taxes, with more centralisation. Now we should have learned from our history that centralized systems have crucial difficulties. They are not flexible and they are not innovative. Just two weeks ago, Mrs Merkel, together with French President Macron, made major concessions towards the European transfer union and central government with the Meseberg Declaration. The establishment of a eurozone budget with its own taxes or the banking union with a transfer of deposit guarantee funds from northern to southern Europe are only examples. With such concessions, can it be surprising that Mrs Merkel must be kept in office? Mr Kurz, three weeks ago your colleague Mark Rutte was here in Strasbourg. He was right to say that there was less EU, but better. He was right to point out that the euro did not keep the promise of prosperity, but that it was only a redistribution of wealth within the EU. We want a European Union that is limited to its core competences. It is also undisputed that Angela Merkel's opening of the border led directly to Brexit. I have been working closely with my British Conservative colleagues for four years, and I can tell you how great the loss will be for our continent, how great the loss of these factual and competent voices will be. And even more countries will turn away from this EU if they continue to feel patronised, ganged, and exploited by Brussels. You have the opportunity to set important priorities here before the election to the next European Parliament. I wish you every success in this.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –Mr President, I say to Ms Trebesius: I am guilty. I am in favour of the United States of Europe. I think can only be to make from the European Union a good federal state, a perfect union; that should be a goal for everybody. Chancellor, you have talked a lot about migration, and you have said your first priority is to be tougher on illegal migration. But I have to tell you one thing, being President of the European Council is a little bit different than being Chancellor of Austria. You have not only to please who you think are your voters in Austria. What you do as a Council President is something completely different. You have to build bridges, you have to make compromises, and you have to find difficult compromises. And from time to time, I have to tell you, it will not be pleasant. There will be unpopular compromises that you have to make on a lot of things. There is Brexit, the multiannual financial framework; there is a lot you did not talk about. That is a little bit strange as reform of the eurozone is a priority in the coming months and there is naturally also migration, so I will not talk to you now about all these fights. On Brexit we are waiting for the white paper of the British Government after the Chequers meeting. I hope that the match between England and Colombia will be less violent than the meeting in Chequers, but we will see this in the coming days. On Friday, there is the eurozone reform. The Council did nothing about that. They pushed all the problems until the end of the year. My question to you is: what are going to do? What initiative are you going to take on this? And then there is the so-called migration crisis, and I say ‘so-called’ because I don’t think it is a real migration crisis which we are living through in Europe at the moment; it is a political crisis on the back of migrants. That is the reality. Look at the figures before spreading fear into the populations and public opinion. There were more than one million crossings in the Mediterranean in 2015. That fell to 360 000 – still too many – in 2016. In 2017, 170 000 and now in the first six months of the year, 45 000 crossings in the Mediterranean, which is 0.07% of entire migration flows worldwide: 68 million in all. So what are we talking about? In my opinion we are not talking about a sudden influx of people crossing the Mediterranean. We are talking about a political decision, an opportunistic decision of one minister of the interior in Italy, Mr Salvini, who created this problem that we now have on our plate. That is happening, and Mr Salvini has a very simple opinion: he says, ‘not in Italy, put them in Germany, put them in Austria put them in Hungary maybe’. And Mr Orbán, who is a friend of Mr Salvini’s, says: ‘no, not in Hungary, we will put them in Italy or in Germany or why not in Austria’ and then your friend, Mr Seehofer, has another opinion and says ‘no, not in Germany, send them back to Italy or eventually to Hungary and maybe to your country, Austria’ and you are saying – and have already – you don’t want them in Austria. You want them to stay in Italy or in Germany or to send them to Hungary. You see what the problem is, Ms Chancellor. The problem in Europe is that the only consensus that the Council and the prime ministers and you and your friends can agree today is: ‘not in my back yard’. That is the only consensus that you are capable of for the moment, and that is the scandal of Europe. Don’t talk about migrants. We are talking about a political crisis on the back of migrants, and what I am asking you is not only to be tough on migration or illegal migration. You have to be tough on illegal migration but when an asylum seeker is coming from Syria when he enters the European Union, he is illegal before he asks for asylum. What I am asking you is to play the European card, as Austria has always done. And the European card is a real European border and coast guard. Back the proposals of the Commission before the end of the year with the Council. Secondly, make an agreement on Dublin. The parliaments have a position. The Council has no position for the moment. Thirdly, create European reception centres where people can ask for asylum inside or outside Europe, I don’t care, what is important is that they are not falling into the hands of the smugglers and the criminal gangs. Finally, a legal system of economic migration, which we absolutely need. In conclusion, Chancellor, you can count on the support of all this Parliament. Not for big speeches against migration but for European solutions on migration.

name: Presidente. –
text: I would ask honourable Members to keep to their speaking time. I am flexible but you cannot overdo it. I am not just referring to you, Mr Verhofstadt. I would also like to see the commission's report on the Trebesius spoke more than expected. I therefore call on you to keep to the timetable so that other Members do not protest and use the excessive duration of your speech to start a political polemic.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, the Chancellor has said that the Austrian Presidency wants a Europe that protects. We couldn’t agree more, Mr Chancellor. In an uncertain world, the first thing that most of our citizens want is protection. Let’s take a look at what they say when we ask them and I have here the report commissioned by Parliament seeking the opinion of all people in Europe.  So, what do they say? The first thing they want to be protected from is terrorist attacks. Secondly, they want their jobs to be protected. Thirdly, they want to be protected from poverty and social exclusion. Even though the survey was conducted in the immediate aftermath of the biggest wave of arrivals in Europe, being protected from uncontrolled migration only comes fourth, right before being protected from climate change. When it comes to prioritising European action, all citizens say first work on tackling poverty and social exclusion and then work on fighting terrorism.  I am saying that because your Presidency has decided to conflate security with migration and make this its top priority, as if every migrant or asylum seeker were a potential criminal or terrorist, which would then justify keeping him or her away from the EU’s territory. And you do that, when in actual terms, as Guy Verhofstadt just said, the arrivals on our shores have dramatically dropped.  Make no mistake about it though, taking into account the dire situation of so many people in the areas surrounding Europe, the asylum and migration challenge will not fade away anytime soon. It is one that does not lend itself to simplistic solutions, but one that Europe can meet while fully respecting its core values.  So why is it, Mr Chancellor, that in chorus with too many other European heads of state and government, you choose to focus public attention on an issue that does not rank highest in our citizens’ minds and whose size makes it manageable, if only Member States would show solidarity with one another?  The simpler explanation, Mr Chancellor, is that you are seeking a diversion by riding on fears that you and your friends are fanning. You probably want to draw the attention of the people away from what you want to do at home – extending the working day to 12 hours, reducing social benefits to people based on nationality, or contradicting the banter of your coalition partner by ratifying the Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA), which is a very multinational-friendly free trade deal.  So the picture becomes clear. You want a Europe that protects, yes, but that protects those who wield economic power, not the citizens. This is evidenced by the report that we have launched which highlights how your country still allows wealthy Austrian citizens to park their money away in Liechtenstein, a country that sells passports to dubious individuals or shows little enthusiasm in fighting money laundering.  After the financial crisis, Mr Chancellor, anger and anxiety grew in our society. We could, and we should, respond by changing our economic and social policies in order for them to serve the people. Instead, you and your friends choose to double down on neo—liberal policies and diverted the anger and anxiety towards very convenient scapegoats – the migrants.  So I’m asking you, Mr Kurz, and also you, Mr Weber, is this the new normal at the European People’s Party? Over the last few months we have seen your member parties increasingly adopting the ideas and rhetoric of the far-right, such as in Austria, in Bavaria or in France. Going together to the polls, like in Italy, governing with it, such as in Austria and, to crown it all, your member in Hungary is hailed by the entire far—right international as a hero.  You claim to be doing all this to prevent the expansion of far—right parties. The reality is that by legitimising their ideas you accelerate their diffusion in society and worse, you are making them official policy. Is this still the party of the fathers of Europe, who decided to launch the European project to cure our continent forever of the plague of nationalism and hatred?  I have never been – and these are my last words, Mr President – I have never been scared of the extreme right, but when the ideas of the extreme right contaminate the parties that were at the heart of European democracy, we are all in danger.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, first of all allow me to express once again GUE/NGL's support for the fair fight of interpreters in Parliament, who are on the 29th day of their strikes. At the same time, ladies and gentlemen, we also support the struggle of Austrian workers against the orchestrated efforts of your government, Chancellor, and employers' organisations to abolish the eight-hour period, to introduce up to twelve hours of work a day, 60 hours a week.  We send our solidarity to the Austrian workers, 100,000 of whom took part in last Saturday's militant demonstrations in Vienna, defending the eight-hour period. The austrian presidency's slogan is 'Europe to protect'. Who should the European Union protect from, Chancellor? Of the poor workers whose most basic achievements are threatened by your own government, who are about to assume the presidency of the Council? From the poor workers for whom you do not want to introduce a social safety net at European Union level? Of the Community workers in Austria, whom you treat as second-class citizens? Who else does the European Union need to protect, Chancellor? From the persecuted refugees from the wars? Of the desperate, all they want is the right to a peaceful and better life? Your Austrian Government has taken the lead in the recent Council decisions on more fortress Europe, for more dead in the Mediterranean, for internment in warehouses of people inside and outside the European Union, in concentration camps for migrants and refugees, promoting illegal repulsions of migrants and refugees, promoting the externalisation of borders with border guards in war-torn and destroyed countries such as Libya, creating boarding platforms there and violating the internationally guaranteed right to asylum, which continues to trade in human souls under the European Union-Turkey Agreement.  The decision of conservatives with the participation of, I would say, far-right parties and EPP parties, like your government, i.e. decisions to close borders, is contrary to the legal and moral obligations of the Member States. At the same time, it means that some Member States take a disproportionately larger share of the responsibility that all the Member States of the Union had to share. Notorious solidarity remains an empty letter. As GUE, we join our voice with all those who argue that the danger to Europe is not refugees and migrants – it is wars and imperialist interventions, which the Union and the Member States have supported in practice, are increasing economic and social inequalities, racism and xenophobia.  What is needed are initiatives to immediately end the wars and bloodshed in the Middle East and North Africa, for real and substantial development aid and support to the countries of Africa. We again emphatically call for the abolition of the Dublin Agreement and the creation of legal and safe routes for refugees.
