All Member States of the Union must participate in the accommodation of refugees, depending on their potential, on the basis of the principle of solidarity. As GUE, we remain firm in our positions on a social Europe, on social cohesion, on a Europe of solidarity and peace.

name: Presidente. –
text: I would like to remind the speakers on behalf of the groups that, if they extend their speeches, they take up catch-the-eye space. So take your voice away from your colleagues.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I say to Mr Kurz: at least we’ve got somebody in this Chamber who believes in the Judeo-Christian culture of Europe, which makes a very welcome change. So perhaps you understand why the EU’s asylum policy has been the complete disaster that it is, as citizens look on at changes in their communities that none of them ever asked for. But I think it is unfair that everyone is blaming Ms Merkel for this. Credit is due, I think, to the man on my left, Jean-Claude Juncker, it was he that opened the doors back in 2015 to a million people crossing the Mediterranean. So I think credit really is due to Mr Juncker for this catastrophe. And as borders and walls are being constructed all over Europe, isn’t it about time that everybody here faced a couple of realities? The Schengen area is a theoretical concept that now needs to be dismantled and that the total free movement of people within the European Union, especially in an age of terrorism, is something that voters will not allow to continue. This, folks, is why Brexit happened. Nations want to be responsible for their own actions and not to pay the price of the mistakes of others – I think the Italian elections show you this. And now in an attempt to survive, Ms Merkel is going to set up detention centres in the south of Germany, exactly the same policy put in place by Donald J. Trump in America. You all screamed at Trump. Will you scream at Merkel? How can you expect people who caused the problems to solve them? The old order is being swept away, and with it, Mr Verhofstadt, the vision of a united states of Europe is dying, thankfully, before our eyes. (Applause)

name: Harald Vilimsky
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the As an Austrian, I would like to take this opportunity to warmly welcome Chancellor Sebastian Kurz here, and I would also like to find words of apology for the fact that the left-wing groups here do not even take over the Presidency of the Council to show respect for the Republic of Austria too, and that this is a cheap polemic. This culminates in a Verhofstadt that does not even have the collegial kindness to stick to its speaking time, but simply keeps talking despite the President's multiple urges. But they are unconcerned about that. We have a different view of things. Austria is a small country with only eight million inhabitants. But I think that Austria is an important country, because Austria is something of a hub, because Austria is a hub between the interests of East and West, and because Austria has always been a meeting place to bring different interests here into a common whole in such a way that all those involved had something of it. The current situation in Europe and the European Union is demonstrably not the best. The EU is failing to deliver solutions to the very large areas, but on the other hand, it is producing things with regulations, with bureaucracy and with standards, where many people lack insight. In my view, we must now provide solutions in three major areas: the first is the European Union's self-image. You know that, following the shock of the Brexit referendum, the European Commission has written a White Paper here with five different scenarios for a good future for the European Union. This starts with the internal market scenario and goes all the way to total communitarisation. In its programme, Austria has set out the number four scenario, i.e. less cooperation, but more efficient. Only this House and the institutions of the European Union are afraid to commit themselves to a scenario. One often gets the impression that one says: it goes long here, and the other says: it goes on for a long time. If we succeed in reaching a consensus on this, then we will also have a good chance of developing the European Community project in a prosperous way. The second is the European Union's view of the internal. The very idea behind this European unification was to bring peace, freedom and prosperity across this continent. In many cases, strife, strife and resentment reign today. That is the wrong way to go. We need to understand how to look for common ground and not always work to define more and more differences. However, this succeeds in responding to the rapidly growing support from the European populations to return competences to their countries, also in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, which would also be a key to a successful future. The third point is the European Union to the outside world, where, in my view, it is the wrong way to go – if I look at the two great powers, the United States and Russia – to put one President in the Klamauk and only to consider the other with sanctions. It would be a good way if Austria, the European Union, tried to show respect for these great powers. I am convinced that the Austrians must bring their Presidency, which has an ambitious programme, with appropriate professionalism and neutrality, to a good end here.

name: David Borrelli (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Austrian Government's decision to focus its action on a Europe that protects is an absolutely ambitious choice. But I would like to remind you that the concrete value of the concept of protection takes on different shapes and dimensions according to the real needs of the recipient. The protection that our small and medium-sized enterprises require is quite different from what our fellow citizens living in run-down neighbourhoods are demanding, and the protection that our young job seekers require is different from that sought by those seeking social support against illness or old age. This presidency will only be able to say that it has contributed to the process of European unification if it has been able to activate protection without discrimination. In other words, whether the ability to protect will benefit all citizens, even if in a different way.

name: Othmar Karas (PPE).
text: Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Welcome to the Civic Chamber of Europe, the only directly elected transnational parliament in the world! Chancellor, to us, you represent not only our common country, Austria, but the strengths and weaknesses of all the Member States in the Council, the legislator on an equal footing with the European Parliament. This is a challenging, difficult work that we can only successfully master together – the Council and the European Parliament. You have taken over the captaincy in the Council since Sunday, and you are also to take on the role of playmaker – as an adepute, a good host, a committed consensus builder and a courageous pacemaker. The outcome of your Presidency of the Council is a major influence on the starting point for the next european parliament election , as you have pointed out. What you - we - don't finish will not happen before the election. As the European Parliament, we want the citizens to feel better after these six months that we are the European Union. Any demand on the EU is also a demand for ourselves. A more effective European Union is in all our interests. Reject every single-handed, nationalist, populist, selfish response to our common European and global challenges. Give the idea of Europe back its soul in the Council. The violation or ignorance of European law and our universal values in some Member States is the poison of credible cooperation and an EU capable of action. Unanimity blocks, blackmails, delays a credible foreign, security and defence policy, hinders our fight against tax avoidance, tax evasion, tax havens and corruption, weakens European democracy, transparency and all parliaments. Let us take a step forward towards the abolition of unanimity! Let us develop concrete solutions, results. An effective Council is in all our interests. Best wishes! We look forward to working together.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to the Chancellor that Austria has an ambitious motto for its Presidency, which is to protect Europe. But I must say that I am concerned by some signs of hesitation on the part of the Presidency. Let me be clear: this is a moment where we should not go for mid—range solutions or small arrangements. The choice is clear for the European Union and for the Austrian Presidency. You have one choice, which is to follow those voices calling for national solutions and the closure of borders to protect people: that is one road. And then we have the other road, which is to push for real European solutions: bold, ambitious and turned to the future. This is the expectation we should have regarding the Austrian Presidency. Let me be clear: what are the things on which you should be able to deliver, all through your Presidency, in order really to protect people? First, a European social pillar of rights, which is important, inter alia, in terms of coping with the digital revolution, labour contracts and social protection for all citizens. Second, making sure that the Community budget brings back cohesion to the European Union. Third, reform of economic and monetary union, restoring upward convergence, not divergence. Lastly, we need a European policy to cope with the refugee and migration situation in such a way that we are again proud to be European and proud of our human values. That means having a search and rescue system at European level, a reorganised European border and also a European asylum system. We know, of course, that we need to work with countries of origin. But, Mr Chancellor, these are real European solutions, and we want the Austrian Presidency to move in these directions.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: Mr President, a Union that protects, that is the motto of the Austrian Presidency. In so doing, the Presidency is demonstrating that it is focusing on the issue that citizens expect Europe to address. Nothing more, nothing less. We as N-VA can only welcome that.  A presidency that also dares to name the problems, such as on security and migration. To my great surprise, I have to say that many people think that we have no problem with that.  But also a presidency that dares to think out of the box because the challenges we face today, they also demand it. No unison hurrah communication. We must be critically evaluated to improve. So thinking, daring and doing is the only way to maintain support for European cooperation. Thank you and good luck.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, well, the Council meeting last week was clearly disappointing in many ways. Asylum and migration were put at the top of the agenda but there was no achievement at the end of the day. Let me be clear: there is no migration crisis today, but there is a crisis – a crisis of lack of political leadership, lack of vision, lack of commitment. So there is a political crisis after the migration crisis, that is very clear. Instead of an agreement on a resilient asylum policy that would truly resolve the situation in the European Union, the Council decision, is focusing on the externalisation of our responsibilities to third countries. Let me ask you what makes you believe that that which we, as 28 EU Member States, cannot resolve together could be better resolved by, Tunisia, Morocco or Albania? The Austrian Presidency’s responsibility will be to be an honest broker and to start to work towards a truly European solution, towards an asylum policy that is not in place today. We owe it to our citizens and – we need only look at the Eurobarometer – we need to deliver on it. The price of not delivering is far too high.

name: Michel Reimon (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Chancellor, I would like to thank the Welcome to the European Parliament, where we are working on solutions that do not work at national level, where eight political groups are sitting – seven of them are working together at European level, with one we cannot work constructively here, because it is far-right, because it is anti-Semitic, because it is anti-European. And you are putting this Parliament in a difficult situation with a coalition partner who sits in this group and who now plays an important role in the Presidency of the Council. For the first time, a far-right party will sit in the Presidency of the Council and negotiate with the European Parliament in the trialogues. This is a pan-European problem. But the problem is not the far-right, the problem is if the Conservatives adopt this policy and carry it on. We have big European issues: we have climate change, which we cannot solve nationally, we have unemployment that we cannot solve nationally, we have the tax evasion of large corporations that we cannot solve nationally. These are all European issues that we can tackle together. All I hear from you is borders, borders, borders, borders. This is a very limited horizon, a very limited access to the subject of Europe. I hope that you will be better able to do so in the next six months. In the first two days of this Presidency, 250 people have drowned in the Mediterranean, and in the end there will be thousands. I hope that you will put as little of it on your conscience as possible.

name: Δημήτριος Παπαδημούλης (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, Chancellor Kurz, I have read the programme on the priorities of the Austrian Presidency. I have read the word 'security' countless times, I have read the word 'unemployment', the word 'democracy', the words 'human rights', the words 'sustainable development', the word 'racism'. You are a young politician and you have to choose which ideas you want to serve. You have two paths ahead of you: the first is to work with the European Parliament and the Commission to find solutions from the Council to the refugee issue, to asylum policies, to the Brexit negotiations, to the new multiannual financial framework, to the social agenda. And the second way is to turn out to be an Orbán or a Salvini with a childish face, who merely seeks the applause of his government partner, who belongs to the far right. You have to choose between two roads. Because the European People's Party is the party to which Mr Juncker belongs and, as you have seen, he has spoken very differently from you, as has Mr Karas, who belongs to the same party as you, to the Austrian People's Party. So choose, Mr Kurz: do you want to be a centre-right European leader or a Salvini with a childish face?

name: President. –
text: There is a request for a blue-card question. However, because the debate started late and is over-running, I am going to try and take comments at the end via ‘catch the eye’, so no blue cards.

name: Laura Agea (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Chancellor Kurz, the Austrian Presidency's motto for the six months is 'a Europe that protects'. Well, but protect exactly from what? Because you see, ladies and gentlemen, the feeling is that we must protect ourselves here precisely from Europe and, in particular, from its sad selfishness. And where the selfishness of the Member States takes us, we have seen it with the management of migratory flows, a great, now classic example of European failure. Yet, Mr Kurz, I would like to point out that the word 'solidarity' is never mentioned in the seventy pages of your Austrian Presidency's policy document. I hope this is simply an oversight. Let me tell you quite clearly: do not make the mistake of thinking about leaving the countries of first port alone; do not commit the nonsense of making Italy europe's refugee camp. The commitments made at the last European Council, thanks to the skilled work of an Italian Government that is finally attentive and competent, must be respected and continued. Shared actions between the Member States and the reform of the Dublin Regulation, on the basis of a balance between responsibility and solidarity, are just some of these commitments and on this, if you remember, we will not give up an inch. However, we welcome the commitments on competitiveness, digitalisation, the fight against terrorism and organised crime. But let me conclude by talking about work: you have written that it is necessary to ensure the right working conditions for everyone. Just yesterday, the Italian Government adopted a measure of the Ministry of Labour with a very specific name, "dignity decree", to combat, among other things, the precarious. Well, Europe too must not forget this social scourge and begin to restore citizens' rights. A Europe that protects against precariousness, austerity and unemployment would be a great achievement for your Presidency. I wish you well in your work.

name: Marcel de Graaff (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mr Kurz and Austria on the Presidency of the European Council. The EU is entering a very difficult phase and the presidency will certainly not be easy. There are plenty of challenges. The relationship with Turkey will need to be reviewed. The problems with the euro will certainly not diminish and mass immigration and its consequences must be addressed.  That is why it is good that the Presidency should be held by Austria, where realism has now come to power in the government of ÖVP and FPÖ. If the EU wants to continue to exist, it can only do so with solutions that come from realistic parties. The pursuit of illusions has brought the EU to the brink of collapse.  No covenant can remain when one, the northern half has to constantly pay for the cost of the other half. No alliance can survive if Germany calls on millions of fortune-seekers and profiteers to come to the EU and then leaves all other Member States to pay for the consequences. No alliance can remain in place if it allows people to be indoctrinated in mosques under Turkish state control with hatred of the West.  The Austrian Government is showing that it is serious about tackling these problems. It is an example for the rest of the EU. It closes its borders, it rejects radical imams and shuts down state-dangerous mosques. It is prepared, if necessary, to provide military support to combat mass immigration. The Austrian Government is rightly strongly opposed to Turkey's accession to the European Union. In short, in Austria realism is in power and realism is the salvation of Europe.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr Chancellor, I would like to thank the On your side of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, I read: 'The commitment to human rights is a core concern of Austria's foreign policy'. However, I have not heard anything about this in your announcements today. After all, you also write that you, together with the EU, intervene every year in hundreds of cases to protect vulnerable individuals in all parts of the world. In concrete terms, however, in 2017, you have handed down 214 charges and 119 convictions for violations of the Antiquated Prohibition Act at home. In the neighbouring country, in my own country, Germany, more than 12 000 investigations take place every year for offences of opinion. 1 138 patriots are imprisoned in Germany only because of their opinion. They did not commit a terrorist attack. Eighty-year-olds like Horst Mahler, Mrs. Ursula Haverbeck are thrown into prison in handcuffs. It would be a time for you, for Austria, to now put an end to the persecution of patriots in your country and throughout Europe.

name: Daniel Caspary (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her A Europe that protects – a very fitting motto in difficult times. Chancellor, ladies and gentlemen, people are looking for support and guidance, they are seeking protection in these troubled times. Just two examples: one is protection from large global corporations and unregulated globalization, in which the greatest, the strongest, the most unfair, prevails, or protection from the chaos that President Trump wants to spread globally at the moment. We want to regulate globalisation. For this we need good agreements, therefore not criticism, like my colleague from the Greens, but warm thanks and congratulations for having ratified the trade agreement with Canada in Austria. Please help to ensure that, during your Presidency, our agreements with Japan, with Singapore, with Vietnam can be coordinated by the European Parliament, so that we can not only use words, but also deeds and maintain the good global order. Secondly, people seek protection from civil war, from oppression and from freedom. But many people also want protection against unregulated migration, and our colleague from the Greens has criticised you for the exercises of your border police. I would like to say thank you. Training helps the police men who have to do this difficult job, and the images give confidence to insecure people. I have the impression that, with your Federal Government, you have largely managed to pacify the population on the migration issue in Austria. We also need this in the European Union, and that is why I ask you to launch an initiative in the Council to pass on the results of last weekend. Please help by placing the now well-trained border guards at Frontex, perhaps, so that we secure europe's external borders in the short term, so that we can really maintain Schengen and then, if possible, no longer need unnecessary border controls within the European Union.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Welcome to the European Parliament, Chancellor! The Austrian Presidency is taking place one year before the next election, and many legislative projects have yet to be completed. It is in all our interests that this works, and we, as Austrian Social Democrats, will, of course, support you in this. You have put your Presidency under the motto 'For a Europe that protects'. Right! Many people in our Europe feel insecure. They are afraid of the future, and they feel let down. If we want to protect people, but we must not confuse them on the grounds of political calculation, then we must prove that we can solve their problems, for example on the all-dominant issue of migration. The Council has been blocking Parliament's proposals for months. Negotiate with us on an equal footing, Chancellor! Our proposals are balanced and offer concrete solutions. Together and not against each other! Yes, we need more cooperation. For us, this means strengthening the social pillar. We do not want the European House to collapse. Only a social Europe is a Europe that protects. But protecting people also means strengthening the foundations of the rule of law. Not only, but especially in Hungary and Poland, threatening things are happening. Help us to turn these countries around. The Austrian Presidency could go down in history if you are prepared to do so.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, the activities presented by the Austrian Presidency encourage me because I think they are focused on the right challenges and will be approached correctly. It is in no one's interest to continue to deal with pressing problems in gloves or, worse, to ignore them altogether. Chancellor Kurz and his government's approach to migration, enlargement and the future functioning of the Union can only be welcomed. We need less Europe and more subsidiarity. The European Union should not accept uncontrolled numbers of migrants and then to smack each other over their redistribution, but must reform the asylum system and protect its external borders. Since Croatia has the longest external land border, I expect Austria and other members to help Croatia provide all the resources needed for effective monitoring.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, Mr Federal Chancellor, the Austrian Presidency has to contend with several huge boulders that the European Union has been pushing in front of it for several years. The biggest, of course, is migration. While the Council's results have provided many incentives, a clear solution is still in sight. Moreover, Angela Merkel has not reassured the CSU to the extent she had hoped, which will cause nervousness in the rest of the European Union. The European Union must now find a way to deal with mass migration not only within Schengen, but also within borders outside the EU.  The debate over Brexit and the future of THE UK's relationship with the European Union will also be at its peak. Brexit, on the one hand, is very simple, but it contains fundamental questions. And, as elsewhere with him, more than ever, until everything is agreed, nothing is agreed. The negotiations on the Union's Multiannual Financial Framework will once again take a lot of power from the Austrian Presidency, as it will certainly be very intense and will point to many different interests in the European Union. Our new Czech government will also have the task of fighting as much as possible for Czech interests, as it must fight for the interests of Czech municipalities and regions. And the forthcoming European elections will mean that many important documents will need to be resolved in the near future. Documents that I am working on, such as CO2 emissions for cars or the HTA project within the health sector, are things that we are waiting for. And I trust you, Mr Federal Chancellor, that your Presidency will bring this to an end. I wish you every success and hope that you will succeed as you have made your way.

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for And now I've seen this happen so many times, I have to say something about it. You in the first row: Mr Verhofstadt, Mr Lamberts, Mr Weber, Mr Bullmann, all of you who sit in the front row; what is it that you think gives you the right to steal speaking time from your colleagues in this house?  Is it because you think you are more important and bigger or is it simply that your ego has become so inflated that you completely ignore your colleagues in the house and think you can behave exactly how you want? It is shameful your actions. And you would deal with it from the Bureau, because that is too bad what is going on.  And now I will turn to Chancellor Kurz: Welcome here Chancellor Kurz. To the circus in the House of Europe. You see how it works in here, I am extremely grateful that you come in with a country's presidency. Finally, a presidency with sound values, a presidency that does not suffer from the politically correct blinders, I look forward to your Presidency.

name: Andrzej Grzyb (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Mr Chancellor, i would like to thank you for your comments. I would like to thank the Austrian Presidency very warmly for its motto: 'A Europe that protects'. It is very eloquent, but on the other hand it is also very large. I think that your declaration, which accompanies the presentation at the same time and which says that you want to continue the tasks undertaken by the Bulgarian Presidency, can be approved. I thank you first of all for focusing on an important task for the Union – which is important above all for citizens – which is security, including the security of the external borders, including regulating illegal immigration. Without this, it is impossible to obtain approval for other solutions, such as the revision of the Dublin process. The European way of life, you say, combined with the competitiveness of the European economy, is important for all citizens of the Member States of the European Union. I fully agree with this – without rebuilding, for example, European industry, without its significant contribution to the creation of gross domestic product, it will be difficult to talk about accepting the changes that affect the European economy, including its modernisation and modernity. It also seems important to me to approach the challenges to be based on the principle of subsidiarity within the Presidency. In order to make progress, it is necessary to resolve the issues that unite, which are the most important, and to omit those that divide and which are often of a minor nature. I would also like to thank you for maintaining the priority of the future of the Western Balkans. Without solving this problem, it will be difficult to talk about stability in Europe itself, and at the same time it is our moral duty to focus on a special commitment to Europe's neighbours, including to our neighbours in Southern Europe. At the same time, it is right that we will focus on the final issue of Brexit, which is going to result in an agreement between the European Union and the outgoing United Kingdom. It seems to me that this is needed by all parties in the European Union.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Chancellor, first of all I would like to remind you – everyone has spoken about the issue of migrants, you have told us that you want to resolve it by means of a vote on Dublin – that a Reform of Dublin is only possible if you agree to vote by majority vote and not unanimously, as you have undertaken to do. Secondly, you are trying to bring the multiannual financial framework to a conclusion. How do you intend to reconcile the new issues – defence, security, migrants, the new resources for Africa's development, which you mentioned – with the traditional policies of the European Union that produce cohesion without an increase in resources? I would really like to understand from you how you intend to reconcile the two elements and find a solution. Thirdly, I would like to ask you a question: you come, like me, from a mountain region, in your case, from a mountain country. At the next part-session, at the beginning of September, we will vote on a resolution on rural and mountain areas, an agenda for areas with low populations and structural problems: do you think you can make every effort to get this agenda off the road and, if possible, defined before the next programming? You want to try?

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I appreciate that Austria has chosen as one of its priorities security and the fight against illegal migration, but I have a question to pose. What would you say if I told you that a Member State issued 300 Schengen visas every day, including Sundays? How would you react if a standard 14-day period for issuance was narrowed to just 1.5 days? Would you stay calm if this happened in one of our Member State’s consulates in Tripoli, which is in Libya?  But what I say is not a joke: this is the current condition of Schengen area security, which was supposed to be safe for all EU citizens. The Maltese authorities have allegedly issued and sold 88 000 Schengen visas to Libyan nationals and an unknown number of medical visas. The Maltese authorities are refusing to investigate the scandal, and the Commission – otherwise very active when it comes to the rule of law – turns a blind eye. Members that so blatantly break the basic rule of common security must be temporarily suspended and the case thoroughly investigated. I insist.  In view of its priorities, I call upon your Presidency to stop this madness and get the Schengen safe.  (Applause)

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: – Dear President, Mr Chancellor, first of all, I congratulate the Austrian people, who, like my Lithuania, mark the centenary of the creation of an independent state. I am pleased that Austria has chosen the public slogan 'Europe that protects'. I wish that this slogan would not remain only three blank words, but would become the basis for the restoration of democracy. I also wish and call: firstly, to increase funding for cohesion and agricultural policy in the 21-77-year Budget of the European Union; secondly, to unify, after all and once and for all, direct payments to farmers; thirdly– pay particular attention to social welfare issues– this is particularly important for countries such as Lithuania, where social exclusion is one of the highest in the European Union. I hope that the vortex of Vienna will bring a gust of new ideas and reforms and the consensus that Europe is capable of protecting its borders, guarantees the security of citizens, and will not remain just a winged phrase.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE).
text: – Madam President, to start with, I would like to welcome the Chancellor. I’m not going to refer to your motto because there were so many mentions of the motto of the Austrian Presidency that there is no need now. I want to refer to the two major priorities, which are migration and digitalisation. Both of them are absolutely big issues which require a joint solution. On the migration aspect, I want to insist on the aspects of the idea of a joint solution. But to reach a joint solution we need to have long-term thinking, and this is something lacking on that issue. There are normally just short-term solutions, which are absolutely necessary since there’s a number of problems that must be solved: humanitarianism is necessary, based on working solutions, but you we don’t have long-term solutions. If we don’t approach countries of origins and don’t address sustainable development by converting sustainable development from a mantra into real projects, we are not going to succeed. This requires a great deal of leadership, vision and there is a possibility for the Austrian Presidency and for you yourself to greatly contribute in that direction. I must say, failure is not written in the stars. Success depends on human decisions, and the actions must be the right ones. So here is the opportunity. Please don’t miss it. We are looking forward to see what is going to happen.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I hope that the EU Presidency will be a success. It's about too much. A Europe that protects protects our way of life, our quality of life. It is a Europe that protects socially. This is about wages, it is about the fight against tax dumping and wage dumping. There are 200 dossiers on the table. It is about the digital tax, the corporation tax. There is so much else at stake that you did not mention. We are talking about a European labour market authority that controls when social security is not paid. In other words, there is a great deal on the table that is important to us European citizens. And it's important that you don't just do a PR show, but that you really do this bone work when it comes to working through the dossiers piece by piece.  It is also a question of there being no contradiction to what is happening domestically,.B for example in Austria, if you are committed to the 60-hour week and the 12-hour day and, on the other hand, we want to achieve precisely these improvements in the quality of life in terms of work-life balance. There are such nice proposals on the table here. Continue to do so, constructively.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Chancellor, we thank you for this wide-ranging speech and we welcome the Austrian Presidency, which is certainly dealing with a time of crucial choices for the whole of Europe. We really like the motto you have chosen 'the Europe that protects': it is extremely topical and responds to the priority needs of our citizens. The fight against illegal immigration, the protection of external borders, as well as the commitment to create development in Africa, prospects for the young people of that continent, are all priorities, especially for my country, which is Italy. Italy must no longer suffer the loneliness it has suffered in recent years; Italy cannot become that migratory ghetto that would become if this loneliness continued.  That is why we are concerned about what has already been mentioned, the decision to change Dublin unanimously, and I would like to hear your thoughts. I also have a question for you: do you not think that, in addition to the means that President Juncker spoke about for Frontex, should we also rethink the political mandate of that agency? And to those who accuse us, even today in this House, of nationalism, I would like to respond with the words of John Paul II on the homeland, "When I think homeland I express myself; it is the voice of the heart, a secret frontier that branches off from me to others to embrace them all, up to the oldest past of all". Dear gentlemen, country is love, not only for our citizens but also for others. You are the sowers of hate!

name: Eric Andrieu (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Chancellor, excuse me for going back to your slogan of a 'Europe that protects' because indeed it is at the heart of our discussions. If it is indeed a question of protecting European citizens from fraud and tax evasion in order to ensure the social pillar of the European Union, I agree with your vision of protection. If it is to protect European workers from the financialisation of our European economy, then I also agree with this model of protection. If it is to strengthen the means at the Union's external borders, I also agree with you. But if it is to maintain the confusion between the right of asylum, the right of refugees and the security of European citizens, then I do not agree with you. At no time, Mr. Chancellor, will the barbed wire ever have prevented the air from passing.  Take our concrete position to reform Dublin and you will move the European Union forward collectively. On the bridges you are creating with Africa, I fear that there will also be confusion between bridges and walls. But if it's bridges, we need more resources. And here I would like to ask you about your vision of the multi-year financial framework. Are you going to exceed 1.114 per cent of the state contribution budget and finally have an ambitious European policy that is up to our European and international challenges?

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European On behalf of the Hungarian Fidesz-KDNP people's party delegation, I welcome the priorities of the Austrian Presidency, in particular the fight against illegal migration. For years, we have stressed in this house that Europe should focus on protecting its external borders rather than inviting migrants to blank. We must also be able to protect our own borders and provide security for our citizens. Unfortunately, we Hungarians have experienced what it is like to have tens of thousands of uncontrolled migrants flooding our country, our capital's railway stations and main squares, as well as the security that can be provided if we can protect our borders and thus prevent illegal migration.   Austria's ambition is to focus on areas where cooperation is possible and to respect the principle of subsidiarity. That's our position, too.   We say no to mandatory resettlement quotas and say yes to border protection, and we are also committed to helping our fellow human beings in their own country. You can count on our support in this, Chancellor.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are always high expectations behind the start of each Presidency, especially if what is at stake is an issue that has been on the Council's agenda since 2015: immigration. Here, on how to manage the migration phenomenon in recent years we have heard everything from the most impracticable hypotheses to the most difficult solutions to human rights and fundamental freedoms. We thought that we had reached the limit of decency and instead, just a week ago, the umpteenth conclusion that the principle of solidarity, making it flexible, and the amendment of the Dublin Regulation, which was miserably shelved and which enshrines the principle of the country of first arrival, foundered once and for all. Those arriving in Italy stay in Italy. Your motto is 'the Europe that protects'. Here, protect us from those who foment hatred and unjustified fears and show us that we protect every individual, regardless of legal status. People, first of all. We want a Europe of solidarity, inclusive, welcoming and one that is not afraid to open up to the outside world. We want a multicultural Europe.

name: Eugen Freund (S&D).
text: Madam President, Chancellor, I would like to thank the President-in-The-European President- I do not think there is anyone who would not wish you luck or luck better for the Austrian Presidency. The word migration has often been used today, it seems to stick to you wherever you appear. But I also see a contradiction in your argument. You have practically won the election campaign by claiming that you have closed the Balkan route. And yet you are now moving up, down and warning of a wave of refugees that a) do not exist – as the latest figures prove – and the b) probably cannot come over the closed route, or c) it is not closed at all. If you, Chancellor, want the applause of the whole House, it would be good not to scare the people in the next six months, but to do everything possible to ensure that people do not have to flee first. Start by drawing up a Marshall Plan for Africa. In this way, you can stop a wave of refugees in the long term, and so you also get an entry in the history books of which you can be proud.

name: Monika Beňová (S&D).
text: – Madam President, you started the presentation of the Austrian Presidency with a nice sentence. That sentence was that 'the European Union is an important project that still needs to be worked on', and I agree with you and agree with you that it is a project worthy of seeking common solutions and working on it. I would like to put social policy in the slogan of your Presidency's 'Europe that protects', because the European Union needs to look for solutions in the field of social policy, and in this context it seems unfair to me if your Government comes up with a proposal to create once again a kind of double category of citizens in the European Union, by wanting to reduce family allowances for slovak carers in your country for their children. All children in the European Union are the same, whether they are Slovak or your Austrian. And I would like to draw attention, Chancellor, to one problem that we have here, which is how we treat Romania, Bulgaria and Croatia. These are countries that are Member States of the European Union, and yet we have not yet found the courage to become members of the Schengen area. Therefore, if we want to build a strong Schengen area, then only with these countries.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Chancellor, I very much appreciate your attitude and responsibility. A Europe that protects is what our citizens expect from the European Union. And, of course, solidarity between Member States will be possible if they know that the European Union is well protected at its external Schengen border.  What intrigued me in your speech was the ambition that we should work with Russia. I want to ask you: Yes, let us cooperate, but we must insist on the conditions for compliance with the Minsk agreements. We must insist that Russia stop occupying Crimea. I do not think that the European Union can recognise this occupation and cooperate with Russia without conditions. I'd like to appeal to you on this one. In any case, I wish you a lot of strength and energy to achieve this goal so that Europe can truly protect.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Madam President, we have witnessed an interesting debate, but when we are talking about protecting Europe, Europe's most ambitious, we need to be aware that we cannot do more with fewer resources.  That is why the financial perspectives being discussed — the Multiannual Financial Framework — are a good opportunity to bet precisely on protecting Europe more, to make the necessary policies and address those challenges we have, these new challenges, such as the fight against climate change, such as tackling immigration, such as tackling the technology industry , such as tackacking the common European defence. These are big challenges to protect people, workers and our borders, and address our challenges. But that's not done with dwindling resources.  That is why, Mr Prime Minister, I invite you to join those countries which want to make a greater effort to ensure that there is greater European construction with more resources to enable us to meet the new challenges.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, Mr Chancellor of Austria, Mr Kurz, you said that the Austrian Presidency wants a European Union that protects its citizens. I would therefore like to ask you what the Austrian Presidency's attitude towards Turkey will be. Turkey, which violates Greece's sovereign rights, Turkey, which holds 37% of Cypriot territory, Turkey, which with Mr. Erdogan is challenging the Lausanne Treaty, is violating Greece's airspace, violating Greece's territorial waters, and we want a position of yours on it.  In particular, what will be the attitude of the Austrian Presidency and what will you do to finally free the two Greek soldiers, who have been illegally detained for 125 days, to date, in Turkey's maximum security prisons. We would like a statement of your position, Chancellor Kurz, on this matter.

name: Thomas Waitz (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Good morning, Chancellor. Migration is a wonderful way to make domestic policy. We have all seen that here. But our social peace in Austria and our prosperity are threatened above all by climate change – these are the challenges. They are threatened by the tax evasion of the super-rich and a number of multinational companies. They threaten our social peace and prosperity. I would like to ask you one question: next year's common agricultural policy will be discussed here in this House and also under your Presidency. Will you work to protect European farmers from world market dumping? Will you work to fund European taxpayers' money for European production of healthy food for our citizens? Can we expect that from you? And can we expect you to work for a climate-friendly and environmentally friendly agriculture that leaves something to our next generation of our nature? Please answer that.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Madam President, welcome, Chancellor, as the first priority of your country's presidency you mentioned tackling illegal immigration and rightly pointed out that, in order to be successful in this effort, external borders must be protected. As far as Greece is concerned, this is not the case. Frontex has proved to be completely ineffective and it makes sense, because with what incentive, for example, will an Austrian protect the Greek border, even if he regards it as Europe's external borders? Do you therefore agree that in order to ensure this security, this serious task must be entrusted to the competent and responsible countries? Do you agree that the anachronistic Dublin Treaty should be abolished so that the entry countries do not turn into camps for the concentration of impoverished illegal immigrants? And finally, because Turkey continues to send thousands of illegal immigrants to Greece, what measures do you think should be taken against Turkey? Do you think that the European Union should impose against Turkey the measures it has imposed against Russia?

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Madam President, Chancellor, I would like to ask you the following questions: Do you really consider solidarity to be a two-way street? And, if so, what does the Austrian Presidency intend to do about the Commission's proposal to remove Community funds from the Member States of the European Union which refuse to assume their responsibility for the refugee crisis? Also, how quickly will you promote dublin regime change legislation and what concrete steps will you take to ensure that in 2020 we have a strengthened European border guard with 10,000 men and women, but also with vehicles and similar ships?

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, President Juncker, Chancellor, I congratulate you on taking over the Presidency. Sure, I know your country very well. You have a beautiful country. I love Austria – that doesn't mean the current government. Commissioner, you are talking about creating bridges. You talked about the fact that you need to protect. But how do you protect, when you have declared – simply, you have declared – that workers in your country, Romanians, are not entitled to child benefit, like others? It's discrimination. Do you want to defend by practicing nationalism or what? Of course, I would like Romania, when it takes over from you, to be able to carry forward some things related to a united Europe, so treating citizens equally, a Schengen area in which my country and Bulgaria will be. And don't make any more fences, Chancellor! You got off on the wrong foot. You are young, the youngest leader and you should correct yourself in terms of the treatment of European citizens.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Mr President of the Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to comment on an issue that has been raised here several times, and that concerns the issue of subsidiarity. That is one of the main concerns of the Austrian Presidency and also of the Chancellor in person. I would like to point out that we have set up a working group headed by first Vice-President Frans Timmermans. An Austrian Member of Parliament is also taking part in this work. I would like this work to be completed quickly, and then, under Austrian leadership, we will deal with the content requirements, warnings and indications from this Commission, this working group. For me, this is an important issue. The Commission has also done a great deal in this regard. This Commission proposes an average of 20 to 23 legislative proposals, initiatives per year. The previous commissions had proposed 120, 130 initiatives. Nobody really recognises that we are doing less because we do not need more Europe, but a better Europe. We withdrew 51 legislative proposals and streamlined 151. I would ask that this be noted. And I object to Mrs Trebesius constantly telling lies here. Yes! I do not know which party you belong to. I know which group you belong to, and you should not. For to say – please do not confuse me with Mr Verhofstadt, whom I hold in high esteem – that I am in favour of the United States of Europe is an untrue claim. In my entire vita, with the exception of the first 20 years, you find no indication that I am in favour of the United States of Europe, because I am against giving the impression that the European Union is on the road to nationalisation. That is not what the people of Europe want. And I don't want that either. So please put these slogans in place, because I will ask you every time you claim this to be untrue.

name: Sebastian Kurz
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Manfred Weber and Othmar Karas said: Let's make progress together! That is precisely the aim of the Austrian Presidency. Together with you in Parliament, together with the Commission and, of course, together with the Council, we want to try to bring many of the issues that have been raised today to the ground. There is enough to do. I would ask you to understand that in five minutes' speaking time I cannot deal with every issue that has now been raised. However, I believe that many issues have been mentioned on which we, as the European Union, must make progress. A Europe that protects, of course, does not just mean maintaining internal security, order and stability. This also means giving social security, which means ensuring competitiveness, so that we remain competitive even in a changing time. And, as I mentioned in my opening remarks, this does not end at our external borders, but security and stability can only be made through engagement outside our borders. The broad debate that has taken place here also reflects the range of opinions that exist among the European population. In this respect, I think it is quite positive that there is such a lively debate in the European Parliament. However, I hope – and I believe that Mr Verhofstadt has said this – that there is also the necessary willingness to compromise when it comes to finding common solutions. Because we, as the European Union, will only make progress if we also have the greatness of working together between the Council, the Commission and Parliament, and if we are prepared to reach consensus across the political groups. However, I am very optimistic because I believe that, in reality, there is much, much more in the European Union that unites us than things that could ever separate us. You have, rightly, I believe, had a very broad debate here today on a wide range of issues. However, I believe that it is important that we are all honest with each other on the subject of migration. And here I would like to mention what Mr Bullmann said. You mentioned that national measures were now being taken in Austria, and you also criticised what I have said as a project for our Presidency. I would just like to make three points, because I think it is important. Firstly, what I have said as the Presidency and what we intend to do over the next six months is exactly what the European Council unanimously decided last week. So if you blame me for wanting to work through what the European Council has decided, then you can do that. Please do not, however, make the mistake of denying that it was a unanimous decision. This shows that there is a common line here, a reversal of the trend at European level. And I think that is very positive. Secondly, the key word is national measures. If I am properly informed, then social democracy is part of the German Government. We do not yet know the german government's line, because I believe that there is only an agreement between the CDU and the CSU here and that there has not yet been a coordination with the SPD. We expect that there will soon be clarity in the German Government. If this is handled as currently announced, it is the country of Germany that is taking national measures here, and other countries, such as Austria, will of course react accordingly. The third point is very important to me: I want to make a promise today as someone who grew up with the Europe without borders inward. I promise you that, as the Austrian Presidency, we will do everything in our power to ensure, in the long term, that there is a Europe without internal borders. (Applause) I cannot promise you how quickly this will happen. Nor can I predict whether national measures will be taken first, as announced by Germany. But what I can promise you is that we will fight to ensure that, in the medium to long term, the Europe without internal borders with proper external borders is once again taken for granted. And I am also optimistic that we will succeed together if we want to. Finally, i would like to make a point which I consider to be very important. I am a friend of the debate, of the discourse, also of the political debate. But I believe that it is important that the discourse always takes place on an equal footing. In the European Union, I sometimes have the feeling that we are in a downward spiral run. I have the feeling that far too often the Council complains about the Commission, Parliament complains about the Council, and that this does not really help us, because it is more a surrender of responsibility than cooperation on the matter. And I have the feeling that there is far too much torn among the Member States that some are complaining about the others, the north over the south, the west over the east and vice versa. On the contrary, I believe in a common Europe, in a Europe of cooperation and in a Europe in which there are no first- and second-class Member States. I always remember a discussion that I experienced in Germany, where I was allowed to be a guest and then someone in the room said: well, he still cannot imagine living in a Europe where Switzerland and Great Britain are not members, but countries like Hungary and Romania do. I was, I think, the only one in the room who was negatively affected at the time, because I thought: how would Romanians or Hungarians feel in this room now? I believe that this experience is precisely the Europe we do not want. We need a Europe of cooperation, we need a Europe where we discuss on an equal footing, even if there are different nationalities and political groups, and we need a Europe that we want to move forward together. We, as the Austrian Presidency, would like to make our contribution here as we can. I hope that you, as the European Parliament, will work well together. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: Thank you, Chancellor. I too appreciated what you said about the need not to have closed internal borders but, above all, to focus on defending Europe's external borders. This seems to me to be a very positive message from the Austrian Presidency. On this issue, as on the reform of the right of asylum, it will have the full support of the European Parliament. I wish you well in your work. The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. – Chancellor Kurz wants to make Europe stronger during the Austrian EU Presidency: a safer Europe, with a stronger economy and also an EU that takes its international responsibility. Kurz wants to step up cooperation with Africa. These are all priorities that we fully support. Kurz also wants to work on more tax justice: the big Internet companies, like everyone else, have to pay taxes correctly. That too is good news. Kurz is young and new, but is already a bridge builder, who can bridge the gap with some in Central and Eastern Europe. He is rightly betting on a Europe that protects, inward and outward. He has done an excellent job of the Austrian Presidency of the EU.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – I thank the Prime Minister for the programme priorities presented, but I miss very important issues that directly affect people and affect their daily lives.  1) Firstly, the reconciliation of private and work life – as you know – the Commission last year presented a package of legal and non-legislative measures to provide equal opportunities and better conditions for working families, both mothers and fathers. In Parliament, we have almost prepared our position on this directive and we are ready to sit at the negotiating table with the Member States (The Council). Will Austria, as the Presidency, take all necessary measures on this issue of interest to all people in order to achieve the best possible outcome and to prevent this issue from being delayed or, worse, blocked?  (2) Secondly, the Directive on quotas for women on company boards. The European Parliament adopted its position already in 2013, but so far this directive has been blocked in the Council. Would it be possible for Austria to enter into discussions with the Member States on this directive, with all the forces and political wills? 3) Finally, with regard to the Istanbul Convention, I very much hope that Austria will finally ratify this Convention in the next half of its Presidency in order to combat violence against women and girls.  I wish you the best of luck!

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. Europe faces countless challenges. I hope that Mr Kurz will be able to successfully address many of these challenges during the Austrian Presidency. In addition to the obvious problems facing the European Union, it must once again be the task of the European Union to mediate a framework of values. Europe must provide people with support and guidance. This also means that we do not close ourselves off, but find common solutions to deal with the refugee crisis. What we must not forget, however, in the discussion on border controls, deportations and refugee quotas, is that it is about people and their fate.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – On 1 July Austria assumed the six-month presidency of the Council of the European Union for the third time. Welcoming Austria’s priorities on building a more streamlined, united and focused Europe, I would like to underline how important it is to increase cooperation with all EU Member States and institutions. At the heart of Europe, Austria plays the role of an essential bridge—builder in the EU, and at this delicate time, as we are confronted with challenges that are global in nature and scale, such as a lack of resources, climate change and environmental deterioration, massive migration, the fight against poverty, and terrorism, we require a joint multilateral solution. Taking into account the need to reduce irregular migration and increase EU citizensʼ security, we hope that, during the Austrian Presidency, the EU is going to incorporate its eastern border, including Romania and Bulgaria, into the Schengen area. Therefore, I am pleased to see that the Presidency plans to focus on the fight against illegal migration, securing prosperity and competitiveness through digitalisation and stability in the neighbourhood. I express my confidence that the Austrian Presidency will strengthen the social dimension of the EU, taking decisions for the good of citizens.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: in writing. – Europe needs migrants to compensate for the demographic decline and illegal intakes have fallen by 95 per cent since 2015.  The Austrian Presidency has, instills fears and serves a very dangerous populist agenda - the same one that opens up internment camps for refugees in southern Germany.  Mr Prime Minister, if you want to control the external borders, why don't you try to get the EU to open legal, controlled avenues for refugees and migrants, instead of continuing to feed the business of traffickers, who manage routes and inflows?  If you want a "Europe That Protects", why not give priority to the VAT reform proposed by the Commission, so as not to let almost a third of the EU and Member State budget (EUR 60 billion a year) continue to finance mafias and terrorist groups through 'carrot fraud'?  Why does it continue to leave Austria functioning as a "laundry" for kleptocrats from the Kremlin, Ukraine, the Balkans and other countries?

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. We are living in a special time with the emergence, throughout Europe and the world, of those who advocate exclusion and hatred. The European Union, let alone its Council, must show that there is no place here for far-right ideas. But now the state that presides over this Council has allied itself with a far-right party, offering them the crucial ministries of the interior and foreign affairs. How can we accept it? This is contrary to the values of Europe, to our treaties and to our humanist principles. I am already watching with concern the effect of such a presidency, starting with asylum. Our proposal on Dublin is simply abandoned, which shows a total disregard for our work, and replaced by security measures at the external borders: the so-called "axis" with the Italian and German ministers. Do you think you are flattering public opinion? You are wrong, citizens want sustainable solutions and, in this, you do not solve anything! I am also concerned about your positions on social issues: how are you going to work on the texts of the mobility package that we are going to vote on tomorrow? Will you defend workers' rights and measures for fair competition in this sector?

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – The priorities set by the Austrian Government for its EU Presidency under the slogan ‘A Europe that protects’ are security, the fight against illegal migration, enhancing competitiveness through digitalisation and promoting stability in the European neighbourhood. Moreover, the main challenge for the Presidency will be to bridge the differences among Member States while preserving a European political coherence. On too many policy areas, divergences are deepening in the EU: surely, between the north and south of the European Union on economic matters; this has been sharpened by the euro area’s operational rules. But also, rifts between the west and the east have become clear, driven by the migration crisis, a growing economic disparity and different governance philosophies.  Austria’s approach will be based on enhancing the principle of subsidiarity. I agree that by involving more national and local authorities, the divergences could be better tackled. However, in doing so, the European Union institutions should not be shorn of their powers and responsibilities as defined ... neither more nor less... by the Treaties. By putting as a priority social and economic cohesion, the Austrian Presidency could help to lay the basis for an effective consolidation of EU decision-making ahead of the European elections next year.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – 'A Europe that protects', ensuring prosperity, security are the beautiful objectives of the Austrian Presidency. Let us remember, however, that security is not only border security – it should be understood very broadly, because we have different forms of security, e.g. food security, which is the basis of our existence. It is ensured by the Common Agricultural Policy.  The Austrian Presidency is discussing the reform of the CAP. The share of young farmers is decreasing in Europe. The reasons should be seen in the low level of income achieved in agriculture, which is estimated at 50% of the average income of other professional groups. In addition, farmers are burdened with greening requirements, which entails not only an administrative burden but also reduced competitiveness on the world market.  The question arises whether the CAP budget can be reduced in such a situation and what could be the consequences? It is often said that Europe needs a bigger budget – what about Chancellor Kurz as President of the Presidency? Do you not think that it is time to lift the Russian embargo in response to the sanctions that the European Union imposes on Russia over its aggression against Ukraine? These sanctions are not burdensome and ineffective and, as you know, the main victims of the embargo are EU farmers.  Finally, as you know, as a result of globalisation and the functioning of the world market, the impact of external conditions on the situation of agriculture and farmers in Europe is increasing.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – In itself, I consider it natural for the Austrian Government to focus its activities as EU President on a small number of issues that are currently most important for the future of the EU. I also agree that, in addition to digital competitiveness and the integration of the western Balkan countries, it also includes security, border protection and migration. I would warn, however, that the current presidency must operate in accordance with the 'honest broker' principle. This may also mean that, on the issue of refugees and migration, which is now particularly sensitive, the Austrian Government cannot give in to its own domestic policy aspects or to the pressures of certain nationalist, populist political forces and governments, but we expect maximum efforts from it to make practical progress in the negotiations for the establishment of a Common European Asylum System.  As a Socialist politician and a European citizen, I also resent the fact that, among the declared priorities of the Austrian Presidency, I do not see any current steps to concretely implement the European Social Pillar. I would like to recall that in Gothenburg, EU leaders, in their important agreement in principle, have identified this as an important task of the Commission and, on a pro rata basis, of the Council Presidencies. Promoting social integration, which has the most immediate impact on the lives of European citizens and the future of the Union and its public image, is a political challenge of particular gravity at the start of the EP election campaign, and I therefore urge the Austrian Presidency to consider its concrete success as the main evaluation aspect of its work.

name: László Tőkés (PPE)
text: Writing. – I warmly welcome the takeover of the EU Presidency by Austria. This is happening in the midst of europe's migrant crisis, which poses an extraordinary challenge for our Austrian neighbours. However, it is a positive fact that, after prolonged labor, at last week's European Council summit, an agreement has finally been reached on migration, which can be assessed as the first decisive step – a real paradigm shift – in the transformation of European immigration policy.  Austria can play a real key role in this process. As a member of the Visegrad Four and the Central European region, Hungary is also a committed supporter of the Austrian Presidency's 'Protecting Europe' Presidency programme: strengthening European security and defence policy, combating illegal migration and rejecting mandatory allocation quotas. I wish Austria every success, President Sebastian Kurz.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. – Dear Chancellor, good ly in the European Parliament. Thank you for your presentation, which is extremely ambitious. Your priority topic on migration in this house raises different feelings. I'm just glad there's finally someone who wants action, not just words. The migration policy appears to have suffered a fiash under the tact of Europe's biggest countries. Some of the measures that we have also taken in the European Parliament are too few to effectively stem the influx of people from the Middle East and Africa. The European Union is still made up of 28 countries, each entitled to its own opinion and position. No coma or punishment of otherwise-minded countries will solve illegal migration. Unfortunately, migration is increasingly a big deal, even about human trafficking. The criminals who do this could not be so successful if we did not have the help or at least the silent landing of politics. The topic must be tackled with all the determination we have. Thanks.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt (S&D)
text: Written. – Three things have stayed with me from your speech. You want to close Europe's borders; stability and security in neighbouring countries; and more cooperation with Africa. I wonder how you're going to solve the puzzle. In order to close European borders, the European Council decided to set up 'disembarkment platforms' in Africa. However, you have not discussed this in advance with any country. What's more, the African Union opposes the principle. Can you tell me how you want to close the borders with diplomatic misfits like this? Or how to complete 'African cooperation'? For the time being, this still resembles African imposition. On top of that, you want stability and security in neighbouring countries. I do not need to tell you that the actions to stop the migration from Libya have thrown oil on the fire on the ground. Ms. Mogherini picked up the gauntlet and set up a rescue operation with Niger. Only now it appears that our Member States are once again lingering to resettle refugees from Niger, which threatens to undermine the whole operation. Many countries of origin or transit of migrants are fragile. Intervening there without any real ambition for resettlement is not a solution, but a recipe for new instability.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Dear Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I am pleased to inform you that a delegation from Australia, chaired by Australian Governor-General Peter Cosgrove and Minister John McVeigh, has taken up a seat on the grandstand of honour. I understand that several fruitful meetings have already taken place, including with members of the Committee on International Trade, and you will continue your programme today, and in particular you will meet with members of the Delegation on Relations with Australia and New Zealand.  Relations between the European Union and Australia are an important priority in our international relations agenda, and the European Parliament strongly supports enhanced cooperation with Australia. I therefore have the great pleasure of warmly welcoming you to Parliament and wishing you all all the best later in your stay. I greet you warmly!

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The Committee on Legal Affairs reviewed the mandates of Karine Gloanec Maurin and Mrs Mirji Vehkaperä and proposed that their mandates be valid with effect from 11 and 12 June 2018 respectively. Are there any comments? I don't see. These mandates are therefore important.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, a procedural motion because, as you know, four Members of this House – the GUE/NGL Group, the Socialist Group and the Verts/ALE Group – are now aboard the Open Arms rescue ship.  The ship also travels with sixty people rescued from the high seas, lives that have been saved thanks to their work. But now the ship is sailing with a shortage of fuel and food because the authorities of Italy and Malta have not let their ports refuel. At the same time, a hundred other people and three babies have drowned in the Mediterranean because they did not let themselves act.  I ask you, Mr President, to address the Italian and Maltese authorities immediately to open their ports.  Stop criminalizing the one who saves lives!... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: This is not an item on the agenda, and I therefore propose an interruption.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the vote. (Results and other details of the vote: see minutes of the meeting)

name: Reinhard Bütikofer (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has Referring to Rule 59(3) of the Rules of Procedure, I would like to request that, before the vote on the provisional outcome of the interinstitutional negotiations, a vote be taken on the five amendments that I have tabled on behalf of my group, which aim to enforce and prevent a minimum of parliamentary control of the EU's arms programme, a minimum of transparency with regard to arms projects and compliance with the EU's eight criteria for arms exports. , which should benefit fully autonomous lethal weapons from EU funding.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I hereby close the vote.

name: Curzio Maltese (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, (start of speech without microphone) ... and then universal human rights. From the outset, therefore, cities have been the most important and innovative political laboratory in Europe and have today returned to play an essential role as a bastion of rights, with the crisis in nation states and the decline of our democracies, threatened, on the one hand, by the loss of popular sovereignty imposed by an oligarchic model of the Union and, on the other, by the advance of reactionary impulses and closure to the outside world. We voted in favour of this report because it is a first step towards recognising the networks of European cities, the role they deserve and the possible creative role they can play in bringing citizens closer to our institutions.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur I don't know if there's any point in speaking out in this disdaiing. Maybe we will wait a minute for MEPs to leave the room, because we do not hear each other. (President's request to leave the Chamber addressed to Members) I have been president of a big city for eleven years, and I know how social capital, economic capital, and one that is important for the future of Europe is built. I welcome this report for two reasons – firstly because it notes this and, secondly, because it indicates or proposes that, in large cities relevant to Europe's development, european issues should be represented not only by the specific activity of these cities, but also by certain people who... (end of speech outside the microphone)

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted today in favour of the report on the role of cities in the institutional framework of the European Union, because I believe that the resolution is a great opportunity to highlight EU programmes and policies aimed at urban agglomerations. It is the right time to reflect on how to bring city dwellers closer to EU programmes. Do we know how many Parisians, Berliners, Warsaw residents or opoles have arrived with information about initiatives such as URBAN, the European Capital of Innovation, the Covenant of Mayors or the concept of "Smart Cities and Communities"?  I am fortunate that one of the cities I represent here in Parliament – Wrocław – is represented by the European Parliament and the European Commission. This certainly gives more opportunities to reach a wider audience with reliable information about the work of the EU institutions, as well as a better chance of debunking fake news. However, many citizens are beyond the reach of this information. This is evidenced by the turnout in the European elections. Too often, I meet citizens who are surprised by the competences and responsibilities of MEPs.  We should think seriously about how to support the activities of European delegations, perhaps thinking about mobile offices, so that more cities have closer contact with the institutions. Representatives of the city in the office in Wroclaw proposed to create suitable online applications, and these are certainly initiatives worth attention. Once again, I congratulate the report and the very interesting opinion of the REGI Committee by Jan Olbrycht.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also supported this material. I consider it important to address the issue of the involvement of cities and municipalities in the decision-making process in the European Union, as well as in individual European policies, in particular cohesion policy. I think it is right if we are not only debating that individual regions should be involved in cohesion policy, but also individual major cities. I see this in the Czech Republic in relation to Prague as our capital city, where we are dealing with a number of investment projects and we would like to use some other possibilities from European money to co-finance these projects, such as the issue of the completion of another metro line. So I very much welcome this, I also welcome the idea that is described in the material, which concerns participation in the composition of the Committee of the Regions, how to involve individual local authorities more in this body, not just regions. Of course, the idea is certainly right, I hope that it will not lead to some contention between municipalities and between regions over what representation they will have in this body.
