name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have also supported this material. I consider the role of cities to be extremely important for our future. Up to 80% of europe's population will live in europe's largest cities within a few years. And this is a truly stunning challenge for quality of life, affordable infrastructure, sufficient public services in these cities, mastery of spatial planning and generally sustainable development of cities and municipalities. This is indeed a very significant challenge for our future period.  May I also recall the problem of suburbanised areas, these are the territories that adjoin the largest cities in the form of agglomeration rings. And in these rings there are indeed very fundamental themes for further development. I am glad that the report describes these issues, and I am glad that it has not avoided a very serious problem, and that is the representation in the Committee of the Regions, where I firmly believe that there should be a change of representation in this advisory body in the coming period.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I don’t always enjoy being the wicked fairy who turns up at the end of the christening and puts a damper on things. But I have to ask, as so often: what on earth is the European Union doing having a policy on telling cities what to do and what to debate and what to fund? I suppose that for some Members – and I understand this – there is a romantic historical appeal, a vision of a pre-nation states Europe where there is a loose confederation of city states innovating within the nexus of some Holy Roman Empire, or whatever. For the practical consequence, as with all these initiatives, is you end up just creating some new bureaucracy. You create a new group of people who become financially dependent on the European Union; you start getting an EU officer in every place who knows that he has to look to the Brussels institutions for every improvement in life. The paradox is that it was precisely the diversity, the variety of the pluralism of Europe that first elevated this continent above the run of humanity. And that is the tradition on which we seem to have turned our backs.

name: Alex Mayer (S&D).
text: –Mr President, I was recently in Anglia Ruskin University in my constituency seeing 3D printing in action, and they told me how they were about to print a whole mini Chelmsford from a topographical map so that they can use it to test different scenarios – particularly for flooding. I found out how manufacturing is being revolutionised: 3D printing is already being used for car components, we have seen the first 3D bridge, and you can 3D print chocolate hips and things like that as well. In fact, in front of us, we see a world of personalised medicine and shoes that don’t rub your toes.  But, Mr President, there are problems too. We have also seen the first 3D printed gun, and it is vital that legislators get ahead of the game. What about copyrights, patents and intellectual property, environmental costs, or the ethics, for example, if human tissue is printed? Who is responsible if a 3D printed bike helmet fails, leaving a child injured? The printer’s manufacturers, the person who printed it, or the designer of the CAD file? These are all questions that need serious thought as we embrace a more bespoke future.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I note a certain satisfaction at the outset. We can say that we are keeping up with technology, about changes in civilization. 3D printing is a novelty, maybe not the one of recent weeks, but the fact that we have considered this report and that the JURI committee was prepared for this novelty is a kind of progress. I would like to draw attention to only one element – in order to anticipate problems related to intellectual property infringement, with 3D printing, of course, the committee must be prepared to adopt new legislation and adapt the existing legislation to specific, I stress, specific printing cases. They were exchanged in the room. Secondly, the decisions of the European Union Intellectual Property Office and the relevant case-law of the courts of the European Union and the Member States must be taken into account in this process, because it is already there. If we take them into account, we will have some satisfaction in solving the problems associated with technologies that rapidly change our reality.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also supported, with my vote, this report by Mrs Bergeron, which draws attention to the issue of 3D printing and calls on the Commission to consider specific legislation on certain aspects.  I think we all recognise that 3D printing is a great opportunity, it promotes innovation, it streamlines production, it is therefore beneficial for both businesses and consumers, and it is also very beneficial from an environmental point of view. But it needs to know that it has its risks, and above all in terms of security, protection of intellectual property rights and legal liability. I therefore believe that consideration should be given to whether common rules can be found at European level in order to avoid the easy and impunity of counterfeiting of works of art and other works.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I will continue where my colleague Shojdrová left off. Indeed, the protection of intellectual property is a certain notorieta on which we are based in our civilizational circle.  This means that not only do rightholders have their rights, they should indeed be indisputable, but also users have not only rights, but also obligations, of course. The right of access to these works, the simple settlement of those rights, the ease of availability, the clarity of the modification. Indeed, the new technologies ahead pose a huge challenge. It is an opportunity to apply innovation, to find far more efficient solutions in the production or provision of services. It has been proven that 3D printing is many times greener, which are all aspects that we really have to deal with, so to say the case, but we must respect what is paramount. And that is to protect the rights of those who have them, that is, rightholders.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, innovators are always far ahead of regulators. The entrepreneurs are designing these wonderful innovations, leaving governments panting and wheezing several furlongs behind: as in 3D printing, the current inventions in biotech, in AI, vaping, whatever. Now, some in this House regard that distance as regrettable, because they see unregulated as synonymous with illegal. Me? I see it as the most hopeful sign that, despite the best efforts of politicians everywhere, economies will continue to grow. As long as you switch the tap off and as long as you stop adding new regulations, old ones become redundant over time. Who cares these days what the regulations are on steamboats or fax machines? Always, the innovator is in front of the regulator. Think of the state as being like one of those old temples swallowed up in the rainforests in India or in Central America. The green shoots are vibrant with the life of the inventive entrepreneur and the pillars and flagstones are what’s left of the old regulatory structure.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by On this occasion, I would like to draw attention to one particularly important thing. At the outset, during the pilot period, this programme has half a billion euros. It is good that, at the same time, it was during this period that a ceiling of at least three countries and three companies – three companies from three countries – was set for this project to be implemented and financed from this very pool. However, I would like to draw attention to one important thing – this programme has a future. It has already been set out in this report. We will talk about the next perspective and, in this seven-year perspective, the value of the whole programme is expected to be as high as EUR 5 billion. I would like to draw attention to this, because the conditions that we have discussed in this report, in the next perspective, should be even more precise, even more valued from the point of view of the legal framework, but I stress – Europe is finally dealing with security and defence by allocating very specific amounts.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, EUR 500 million, EUR 500 million is the amount the European Union expects to spend on producing weapons. When money is supposedly not available to fund social policies, they suddenly find themselves, almost magically, or magically, hundreds of millions of public money to give away to the industrial military complex. They do so even in breach of the Treaties of the European Union themselves, which prohibit the use of a European budget for military spending. But of course, you have decorated it with beautiful words: innovation, technology, excellence even, but what we are talking about is smart missiles, drones, bombs, and the dead, after all. The creation of the European Defence Industrial Development Programme leads us to further militarisation of the European Union. Anyway, under the false excuse of increasing our security, what we do is throw firewood, fatten the arms industry to end up exporting weapons to conflict zones. Ladies and gentlemen, we need no more weapons, but more firm commitment to peace.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I very much welcome establishing the European Defence Industrial Development Programme, which will, for the first time, finance and facilitate cross-border cooperation between defence industrial undertakings of the Member States. I believe that this will boost the competitiveness and innovation of the EU defence industry, and, most importantly, align development of defence technologies with the European Union’s defence capability priorities, emphasising through this the EU’s strong commitment to security and stability.  These two aspects are crucial to stepping up the European Union’s defence capabilities in the current political context.  Finally, I am convinced that it is for the benefit of European citizens and enterprises if the European defence industry remains in Europe as a source of new workplaces and business opportunities, to say nothing of greater stability in our continent.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We have just had the dubious pleasure of hearing the criticism of this programme. I would therefore like to remind you that the threat of armed conflicts, even wars, is increasing all over the world. Also in Europe. Hybrid activities, including cyberspace, are starting to become more widespread. All this is compounded by the fact that Europe, and in fact the Member States of the European Union, are losing their defence capabilities. If we add to this the fact that we can count less and less on our existing allies – I am thinking here not only of Turkey, but above all of the United States – how can we criticise this programme? How can the idea of strengthening the European Union be criticised so that it can defend itself in the future in the event of a possible conflict? This programme is worthy of support.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the European military-industrial complex is celebrating. It celebrates the further militarization of the European Union, it celebrates why it will be strengthened with funds from the European budget, funds which were just for peaceful use, it celebrates because it makes the peoples also contribute to the support by subsidies of Europe's well-known war industries, those industries that sell arms to Turkey. No one forgets that in Afrin the Turkish army invaded and had over 70 Leopards of German construction. Thus, in practice, through the back door, the Turkish war industry will also be able to participate in the subsidies and cooperation and money that will be given by the European Union. We must therefore put an end to this unacceptable situation, the funds must be given for peaceful purposes.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I also supported this report – that is, this legislative process was completed at first reading – also because, firstly, I consider this initiative to be the right one, this legislation. The three-company, three-state rule, I think is a sufficient answer to how resources are to be sought, it will really promote competitiveness and innovation.  Of course, we should bet on peace, but we must also be prepared for what the outside world is like. And hybrid warfare, that's the reality now. Russia is waging a hybrid war on many fronts, and we must be prepared to find new technological solutions, and europe's defence industry has largely lagged behind. Donald Trump has made us look a little bit in our own mirror and see that our picture is a little convised, that we need to be better prepared, and I think whoever's more prepared is less surprised. And that's what this fund is supposed to do.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I rather agreed with the comrades in the Communist group who saw this as being the basis of a militarisation of the EU. I wouldn’t have used exactly their vocabulary, but it is certainly the case that defence integration and procurement integration is not being pursued in a bottom-up pragmatic way, driven by looking for economies of scale, but is seen as being about the assimilation or amalgamation of European industry as an end in itself because the European Union ought to have a military capacity.  Of course, this is very soon going to cease to be the United Kingdom’s issue – I won’t say ‘problem’; that would be a loaded word. It has been made very clear during the talks that, for example, a consequence of Brexit is that we are not considered a security partner in terms of Galileo and all the rest of it. From my point of view, that makes me very comfortable: I was against our participation in Galileo in the first place; I think we should have our own satellite system. But it does have consequences in terms of the UK’s general strategic positioning. If the European Union wants to have an integrated military bloc it will be, I hope, a friendly neighbour, but it’s going to be completely outside our military structures.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Mr President, some people see conspiracies in all sorts of places where there are not necessarily any, and I think this is an important time to support this report, particularly in the context of the debate we had last month about EU-NATO relations. Europe, in the face of a reluctant United States, needs to step up to the plate in its own defence, and cooperation is essential in terms of improving industrial efficiency and economies of scale. I am very concerned at the consequences of Brexit, as flagged up by Airbus Industries, affecting 60-odd organisations in their supply chain in my constituency. This is a hugely important defence contractor where jobs are now under threat in Portsmouth and where we have disruption, potentially at a key time for Europe’s defence. This can all be avoided with sensible arrangements for British cooperation and continued participation in the single market and the Customs Union. I hope all the negotiators take that on board.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against this resolution because I believe that the militarisation of an organisation controlled by the extreme left, so extremely ideologised and a tool of left-wing propaganda and, by the way, a tool of German hegemony in Europe, is simply dangerous. I support our countries' cooperation within NATO because it is not ideologised. NATO does not instruct member states to endure the death penalty or introduce any laws for homosexuals, it does not admonish them on gender equality, abortion, etc. I support cooperation within NATO because it is led by the United States, not Germany: a country that is trying to lure Poland, abolish its independence and circumvent the restrictions imposed after World War II on its militarisation and militarisation of Germany. And knowing life, the division will look like that to avoid mirroring, the Germans will buy tanks, and they tell us to buy shovels. That is how we will come out on this cooperation.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, agrostatistics is an extremely important element on which the common agricultural policy depends. Timely and accurate information is extremely important in critical situations because, unlike other sectors, average pay in agriculture is about 20% lower than other sectors. Therefore, rapid intervention and crisis assistance mechanisms are needed, as is now the plague of small ruminants in my country in the Strandzha region.  I also think it is extremely important to reflect specific cultures and livelihoods in different countries. I find it regrettable that equidae such as horses were not included in the scope of agrarian statistics, nor were pigs free grazing, such as the East Balkan pig, but I hope that the Bulgarian authorities will not allow these animals to disappear from the statistics at national level, and with them from the country. I am pleased that my proposal to include buffaloes in agrostatistics has been adopted and will become a fact in the new agricultural statistics. Bialo-farming provides unique products and with the statistical information collected we can adequately plan and develop the sector.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. I voted in favour of this report, as the prerequisite for comparability and coherence of EU statistics on the structure of European farms is the development of infrastructure for smart solutions, in particular broadband internet, and the promotion of digital skills. Without it, on the one hand, we have no idea how investments are being made towards rural communities, and on the other hand, the system is thus a hotbed of corruption.  I am pleased that the 'smart villages' pilot project I have initiated is coming to the end of a successful implementation and that the second so-called preparatory action is about to start and that, in parallel, the proposal on the future of the common agricultural policy already shows the so-called 'smart villages results indicator'. Let us extend this to all other funds in the countryside, in particular the regional and social funds. Thank you very much.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, statistics on agricultural holdings could be useful, provided that they give data on the social and economic impact on the rural economy as a result of the liberalisation of trade which has been reinforced by European Union policy. Because we have to have statistics on what happens to products of designation of origin, which are really at risk because of CETA, because of the European Union's agreement with southern Africa, because of the high imports of Tunisian oil.  These must therefore be derived from the statistics, as well as from the statistics, what has happened to livestock farming in the European Union, which is also affected by the high imports of livestock and dairy products from third countries, such as Ukraine, and I think that all this unfortunately is not attributed by the specific resolution we have discussed.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, indigenous peoples are ahead of us in the search for harmony with nature. We have much to learn from these peoples, but this cannot be done without restoring them to their rights, as these peoples, in all points of the world, suffer the domination of a capitalist and productive model that threatens them in their very existence. France, which carries indigenous peoples within it, must take on this issue and ratify the ILO Convention and, like the Earth Summit in Rio in 1992, take the initiative of a global conference to launch a founding process of international governance for the respect of the rights of indigenous peoples. It's a civilization issue.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, Volkswagen, Iberdrola, Gas Natural Fenosa or Abengoa, all companies in the European Union, have been accused of violating human and environmental rights in Latin America. And I am not saying this, says Coris, a consultant who produced a report for the European Commission itself. Miners, hydroelectric plants, palm monocultures and other species, or megatourism, are new forms of colonialism, of which the European Union is complicit. But let us not look condescensed to indigenous peoples, because they are the light of this world, because their ideas and wisdom are the wall against which neoliberalism, the same neoliberalism that attacks our rights here in the West, collides daily. That is why Europe must go beyond simple recommendations. We must demand compliance with human rights as an indispensable condition of all trade treaties that are negotiated in the world. Only then will we get humanity to overcome. Only then will we preserve the life of the planet.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of this report because I consider it an essential tool for the recognition and promotion of the rights of indigenous peoples, at a time of backward protection and increased intimidation, aggression and murder by defenders of their rights.  In the 21st century, indigenous peoples continue to fall victim to discrimination and social exclusion, to be threatened by property rights over their ancestral lands and their resources and are now especially vulnerable to climate change.  I therefore believe that the European Union must strengthen dialogue and consultation processes with indigenous communities and ensure that its trade, investment and cooperation policies respect the human and environmental rights of those communities and peoples.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We're talking about indigenous peoples, we're using that concept. I feel some discomfort, because it is as if we are talking about people of a different category or category two, and these are simply full citizens of the countries in which they live, and as such they should be subject to all laws, including principles, including human rights, in the countries concerned. If we, as the European Union, maintain diplomatic, economic and political relations with these countries, we obviously also require that the citizens of these countries be subject to all the values that we Europeans respect. Moreover, I see and praise here the solutions that have been adopted, for example, in Canada, New Zealand or Australia for this population. I hope that other countries will follow the example of these countries.

name: Molly Scott Cato (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, there was a time when we were all indigenous people, when we all lived close to the land and felt ourselves to be a part of it. An estimated 370 million indigenous people still live in close communion with our planet. Their territory comprises some 27% of the world’s land surface but, strikingly, it holds 80% of the planet’s remaining biodiversity. The rights of indigenous people to the land they depend on are protected in a special UN declaration, but this protection is routinely ignored by multinational corporations who steal their land and sometimes pay death squads to kill them. More than 200 environmental defenders were killed in 2016, many of them indigenous people. Last year I supported Lolita Chávez for the Sakharov Prize. She is a Maya elder and knowing her has been deeply inspiring. I had a glimpse into the world view of somebody who believes that, rather than the land belonging to us, we belong to the land. Of course we should protect indigenous communities for their own sake, but also for ours because, if we are going to find a way to live in balance with the planet we share, they have much to teach us.

name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I voted against the report on climate diplomacy, which, although it raises important issues such as the link between climate change and natural disasters and the achievement of the objectives of the Paris Agreement, also raises issues that are difficult to accept, such as linking climate change to migration.  The exploitation of natural resources in countries such as Africa, Asia and South America, including land purchases and deforestation, is the result of global business and concerns being exploited, which should be curtailed and controlled by helping the people of these countries and through such activities improve the liveness of peoples and indigenous peoples.  It would be worth while making Union citizens aware of the link between global business, migration, poverty and conflicts over access to resources, which consequently leads to environmental destruction.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, from this report, the most important thing we believe is the reference to the gender perspective in climate diplomacy, especially the mention of women producers and indigenous people, because they have a very close relationship to the land, have specific knowledge about natural resources and lead family and ecological agriculture. Its source of knowledge must therefore be enhanced in the fight against climate change.  While Members of this Parliament are debating clauses on climate change in free trade agreements, millions of people out there are shouting at us that there is a structural contradiction between capital accumulation in fewer and fewer hands and the sustainability of life.  We must also reduce the power of energy lobbies and multinationals that often decide and speak for many of our governments.  The European Union can be covered in a very friendly green suit, but as long as we do not change the neoliberizing roadmap, we will be complicit in all aggressions to our planet.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr. Chairman, I am pleased to have been able to co-report in the shadows to Mr. Lietz and Mr. Leinen, I think this is a fairly balanced agreement, that is, a report. The fact is that the Paris Agreement is in force, that its provisions need to be implemented, which is not at work at the moment in all countries. Much greater coordination between Member States and the Union itself is needed. What is a major threat to the 21st century is the migrations that have been triggered by climate change. As much as many here today don't want to admit it, climate change is at work and the biggest challenge of the 21st century. We have to stand up to this strongly, so I think climate diplomacy is very important, we need to professionalise and strengthen it. I hope this report will contribute to this goal of ours. In any case, I also supported this report as a shadow rapporteur.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It seems to me that climate change is already a matter of course for almost everyone. This was not the case a decade ago – I recall that even some representatives of the world of science questioned this dangerous process for humanity, for Earth. So the time has come for us all to work together, not only here in the European Union, not only here in Europe, but around the world, to take radical action to improve the situation. This is especially necessary now, following the recent decision by the President of the United States to withdraw from the Paris Agreement. Therefore, the European Union should become not only a European, but also a world leader in climate change. This cannot be done without diplomacy, because it is an international, cross-border scale. That is why I supported this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, renewable energy sources, and in particular wind energy, could make a real contribution to climate change, but that means meeting the standards for the licensing and construction of wind farms. I have referred repeatedly to the environmental crime in South Karystia, on Mount Rachi, where 42 wind farms, 700 megawatts of capacity, are planned and proceeded. Environmental protection has really been dismantled in an area of Nakura. We have raised this issue on several occasions and there is a reply on 21 November from the European Commission that it will refer the competent Greek authorities to the European Court of Justice.  The point is that, to date, nothing has been done and in yesterday's speech I asked the Commissioner to finally tell us when the Greek authorities will be referred, as they are in breach of European Union legislation on the issue of licences for the construction of wind farms. Will there finally be some action or will we have companies operating illegally and even doing illegal water abstractions here and now? Finally, we have to have a decision.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I supported this report with my vote. I agree that climate diplomacy should be a strategic priority of EU foreign policy. There is a need for the EU to take the lead in this area, and we must finally develop an EU climate diplomacy agenda.  The Paris Climate Agreement, the 2030 Agenda and the SDGs all give us tasks. However, the commitments need to be put into practice.  I agree that climate-related developments affect geopolitical stability, food and drinking water supplies, and therefore the regional security of the population groups concerned and, of course, they are also linked to migration flows. In addition to taking the lead, let us show smart examples, with smart urban solutions in our own urban areas, while also raising rural communities with the smart villages initiative. Thank you very much.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we have been talking informally about climate refugees for over ten years, and I am therefore pleased that I have been able to vote positively on a report which finally seeks to give greater visibility to the phenomenon and to call for a definitive definition by the United Nations.  Essentially distinct from environmental migrants moving in search of better conditions, climate refugees find themselves without home, without food, without minimum living conditions, risking death from hunger, sea and disease, all due to global phenomena caused by climate change. I speak above all of fires, floods, rising seas and oceans and extreme drought that force populations to exodus, who do not find a full response framed in a human rights context and in the light of international law.  Instead of looking sideways and pretending that these situations do not exist and are not typified, as has been done in the last ten years, the time has come to look at our responsibility in climate diplomacy as Europeans, leading this definition of refugees and creating the necessary mechanisms to protect these citizens.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, ghlacas páirt sa díospóireacht aréir maidir leis an ábhar seo, taidhleoireacht aeráide, agus bhí áthas orm vótáil air a son inniu. Dár ndóigh, is cuid thábhachtach de Chomhaontú Pháras 2015 taidhleoireacht aeráide agus tá sé de dhualgas air chuile tír air domhan a dícheall a dhéanamh chun na hastaíochtaí carbóin a laghdú. Ach dár ndóigh, tá sé níos deacra do thíortha bochta, tríú tíortha mar a thugaimid orthu, ná na tíortha saibhre. Da bhrí sin, tá sé de dhualgas air na tíortha saibhre cabhrú leo agus sin cuid de na moltaí atá againn anseo.  Agus taobh amuigh de sin, tá sé tábhachtach go dtugaimid ceannasaíocht san Aontas agus dá bharr an dul chun cinn atá déanta againn maidir leis an bPacáiste Fuinnimh Ghlain, fuinneamh in-athnuaite agus éifeachtúlacht fuinnimh, tá sé sin á déanamh againn. Dá bhrí sin caithfimid a bheith an-sasta.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I think it is very important that we deal with the situation of climate change and migration, and therefore this debate, too, I think, made sense. I supported the part of the resolution that calls for action at UN level, for the UN to provide a response to the migration of people who expect to leave areas that are severely affected by climate change, and to respond in places where these changes arise, or to help and address the situation there.  I cannot agree with the call for us to change and define a new term for climate refugee in order to ensure an international legal framework and protection. I do not think that this is a solution to give the same international protection to refugees who leave areas affected by climate change as to those fleeing war and persecution.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the european Council and Commission statements on the conclusions of the European Council of 28 and 29 June (2018/2591(RSP)).  I greet President Tusk, but before giving him the floor, I would like to reiterate, as I did this morning, at the beginning and after the speech by the Austrian Chancellor, Mr Kurz, on behalf of Parliament, our strong determination to ask the Council to approve the reform of the right of asylum, as a single package, that is to say the seven points, including the reform of the Dublin Regulation.  The European Parliament has been doing its work for a long time and can only reiterate, as it did at the Council meeting, the vital importance of solving this problem. The European Parliament's proposal is a comprehensive proposal, which also provides for a transitional period, so a great deal of availability in countries that are not in the habit of the arrival of immigrants, especially from the continent from the African continent, and our text, approved by a very large majority, can be an excellent starting point. We are pleased that, at the end of the document approved by the Council, there is a willingness to carry out the reform. I would remind you that the Treaty provides for unanimity not to be compulsory for the approval of this reform, but qualified majority voting is sufficient. So, if you want, you can achieve the goal. I therefore also address my appeal to the Austrian Chancellor to the President-in-Office of the Council, Donald Tusk, whom I thank once again for being here.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, the last European Council took place in a deteriorating geopolitical context. This is why I appealed to the leaders that the EU must get its act together. For me, this means increasing military cooperation, preparing for worst-case scenarios in terms of trade, and – above all – looking for unity in every aspect of European cooperation, including migration and euro area reform. We managed to make progress on all these issues, but there is no hiding the fact that the road ahead of us is still long and, for sure, not easy. We started with a discussion among the leaders and NATO Secretary—General Jens Stoltenberg, with the aim of deepening the cooperation between the EU and NATO. The leaders agreed that the EU must take greater responsibility for its own security, first and foremost because it is in our own interest as Europeans. In order to bolster our common defence, the EU will enhance investment, capability development and operational readiness. Let me mention here the issue of foreign threats to our democracies. The European Council called on the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy and on the Commission to present, by December, concrete proposals for a coordinated EU response to this challenge – and specifically to Russian disinformation attempts – which is currently handled by a very small strategic communications team at the European External Action Service. This is particularly important in the light of the signals about Russia’s role in Brexit. As regards migration, I put forward the following three proposals: disembarkation platforms outside Europe; a dedicated budgetary tool in the next MFF to combat illegal migration; and the boosting of EU support for the Libyan Coast Guard. They were supported univocally by the leaders. We also agreed to support the Maltese authorities by sending a message to all vessels, including those of NGOs, operating in the Mediterranean. The message is clear: respect the law and do not obstruct the operations of the Libyan Coast Guard. Additionally, the leaders accepted the Franco-Italian proposal of controlled centres on EU territory. It is up to the governments to decide whether they want to create such centres. However, any obligations related to the functioning of these centres, including relocation and resettlement, will be undertaken on a voluntary basis. Last but not least, we agreed to launch the next tranche of financing for Turkey, and to transfer EUR 500 million of development money to the EU Trust Fund for Africa. The leaders confirmed their will to take our cooperation with Africa to a new level. This means not only increased public funding but also a new framework enabling private investments to grow. It is the best proof of our intentions, despite unfounded claims that Europe wants to abandon Africa. It is impossible to stop the flow of illegal migrants without close cooperation with African countries. That is why we will use all possible tools, from defence and development to visa and other cooperation, to make it happen. Moving on to the Euro Summit. Last October, in this Chamber, I said the following: ‘I will do everything in my power to take the first very concrete steps, by June. If we don’t reach agreement by June, I will say precisely why it wasn’t possible, and who is responsible.’ Today I can say that the leaders did indeed take the first decisions. This means agreement on further steps to complete the banking union and to strengthen the European Stability Mechanism (ESM). In particular, we agreed that the ESM will be providing the common backstop to the Single Resolution Fund. As a consequence, our banking union will become much stronger. Some of you may say that this is too little, too late. And you would be right, in a sense. But the fact is that, after some years of standstill, we are effectively relaunching the process of deepening economic and monetary union. To make sure that the progress continues, I will organise another Euro Summit in December. The leaders also adopted conclusions advancing EU cooperation on digital matters and innovation, as well as trade. In the context of growing trade tensions, the European Council underlined the importance of preserving and deepening the rules-based multilateral system. The Commission was invited to propose a comprehensive approach to improve, together with like-minded partners, the functioning of the World Trade Organization in crucial areas. The leaders also called for the adoption of the proposal on the screening of foreign direct investments, which is crucially important for the security of our economies and our citizens. It goes without saying that the Commission has the full support of the European Council when it comes to the trade dispute with the USA. I am sure Jean-Claude Juncker will elaborate on that. A final point on Brexit. The 27 leaders shared one concern. Whilst progress has been made in a number of areas, some key aspects still need to be agreed. Since there is much work ahead, with less and less time, I was very honest in my assessment, including when I spoke to Prime Minister May last week. The sooner we get a precise UK proposal on the Irish border, the better the chance of finalising the Brexit negotiations this year. Put simply, we cannot make progress unless a solid backstop is presented by the UK and accepted by our Irish friends. We are now looking forward to the White Paper from the UK and we very much hope that it will bring the necessary clarity, realism and impetus to these negotiations. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: I would also like to inform my fellow Members that during my speech to the Council I insisted, with regard to the next multiannual financial framework, on the importance for the European Parliament of the issue of own resources. I am therefore pleased that President Tusk stressed, in his speech, the importance of this issue for the Council as well. I would also like to thank Mr Juncker for pointing this out this morning at the press conference: EUR 500 million is not enough, more is needed. I will be going to Niger and soon libya to try to make a contribution to the development of democracy on behalf of the European Parliament.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: Mr President of the Commission. – Caro Presidente, Mr. President of the European Council, ladies and gentlemen! After each European Council, the post-war, no, demand is asked: is the glass half full or half empty? I don't know. I think it could have been fuller – without saying it was half empty. We have made important decisions on border management. On the basis of the Commission's proposals, we will send 10 000 border guards of European provenance to the external borders of the European Union by 2020. This is an important decision of the European Council. It was originally thought that we would have to do this by 2027, now we say 2020. And I will make concrete proposals in this regard during the State of the Union address, because there is a need for us to hurry up. I also believe that the mandate of border guards must be extended. These border guards – ours – must also be able to intervene in third countries, but always with the agreement of the third countries concerned. With regard to migration, including the reception camps in North Africa, we should be careful not to give the impression that there is a return to neo-colonial attitudes – that is not good. We do not have to decide on Africa, but we have to decide with Africa and, above all, with North Africa. It was decided in the European Council last Thursday, Friday, that we had to agree on European rapprochement with regard to migration. I strongly believe that this must be the case. I am not sure that the agreements that have now been reached in some Member States are in full line with this, but this will have to be commented on after careful examination of the situation. I am glad that, under Donald's leadership, we have ensured that we have decided on the second tranche of aid to Turkey, which does not go to Turkey, but to those who take care of the refugees in Turkey. This was an important decision to pay two billion from the European budget, one billion from the Member States. I hope that this will be followed up, and I do not really doubt the will of the Member States to do so. As far as Africa is concerned, I am wary of all demagogic statements. Everyone is talking about Africa. Who is doing what for Africa? We have increased the African trust fund to EUR 4.1 billion. That was not the original plan, but we have now released EUR 500 million from the European Development Fund, not to stop projects that do not actually exist, but to provide money. And the Member States have pledged to raise at least EUR 500 million so that the plans related to the African Trust Fund can be implemented, particularly in Libya. Trust Fund is also called Libya. And I think we're making progress. I am somewhat disappointed – but President Donald knows this – that, with regard to the legislative proposals put forward by the Commission, on which there is agreement – five out of seven – we are unable to persuade the European Council to ask the Council, the Council of Ministers, to do so before the end of July. So where we actually agree, we don't even agree that we agree. This is ridiculous, and that is why the Austrian Presidency should tackle this in the near future. I proposed that we should manage the two outstanding areas that you know by the end of December. There is also criticism at member level that we are not making any progress, and we are not prepared to take responsibility for the seven proposals, five in July and two others in December. I say again – without being on an ego trip, I am too old for ego trips: if the Commission's proposals of February 2015 had been adopted, we would not be in the predicament we find ourselves in today, and that is why we should hurry rather than linger. Ce n'est pas traduisible dans les autres langues, c'est un jeu de mots: "il faut se dépécher au lieu de freiner notre ardeur". Sur tout ce qui concerne l'Union économique et monétaire, Donald Tusk a fait en sorte que nous puissions avoir une bonne décision pour ce qui concerne le dispositif de soutien du mécanisme européen de stabilité par rapport aux résolutions européennes. Il s'agit d'une bonne décision dont il convient de féliciter le Conseil européen. J'aurais voulu que nous progressions plus rapidement sur tout cela. On m'a promis – mais cela ne figure pas dans les conclusions – qu'en octobre-novembre, le Conseil européen reviendrait sur toutes les questions qui restent ouvertes pour ce qui est de l'Union économique et monétaire, notamment sur les garanties de dépéts. Je crois qu'il est essentiel, pour parfaire l'union bancaire, de nous mettre d'accord sur ce point. Il n'existe aucune zone monétaire au monde o il n'y a pas de garantie de dépét. Il faudra que nous nous dépéchions sur ce point. Nous n'avons pas discuté du budget pour la zone euro, parce que ceux qui le pr nent n'ont pas trouvé d'accord. La Commission avait proposé d'introduire dans le budget général de l'Union européenne des lignes spécifiquement dédiées a la zone euro. La déclaration de Meseberg, qui est devenue la référence centrale du devenir européen, pr ne un budget de la zone euro, sans toutefois en afficher les détails, qui n'existent d'ailleurs pas. Il faudra donc que nous continuions notre travail ce sujet. Pour ce qui est des perspectives financiéres, je redis ici ce que j'ai dit au Conseil européen, il faudra que nous adoptions avant le grand rendez-vous des Européens avec le suffrage universel, c'est-a-dire avant mai de l'année prochaine, ne serait-ce que les lignes Si nous ne le faisons pas, si nous répétons les m mes erreurs qui ont présidé la mise en place de la période financi re actuelle, nous manquerons notre devoir. Des dizaines de milliers d'étudiants européens ne pourront pas participer au programme Erasmus+, alors que nous proposons, dans les perspectives financi éres pluriannuelles, de doubler le budget affecté au programme Erasmus, pour le porter 35 milliards d'euros. Nous perdrons, par mois de retard, 5 000 emplois en mati re de recherche, donc 5 000 chercheurs européens n'auront plus les appuis financiers dont ils ont besoin. Je réit re mon appel aux états membres et au Parlement européen, afin qu'ils accél rent leurs travaux, non pas pour verser dans l'échange d'arguments faciles, mais pour résoudre la question substantialqui nous fait face. Le timing est donc, mes yeux, plus important qu'on ne le pense. Si nous n'arrivons pas bon port au moment indiqué, nous perdrons 100 000 projets en mati re d'énergie, de santé et d'inclusion sociale. Qui veut en prendre la responsabilité? Si les etats membres n'arrivent pas se mettre d'accord, la Commission qui succédera la mienne sera critiquée pour ne pas avoir su donner suite tous les projets qui sont les n'tres. Je me déplacerai aux états-Unis, avec l'élan que vous me connaissez, pour discuter avec le président des états-Unis, des questions de commerce. Le président du Conseil européen a fait en sorte qu'il y en résulte un accord, qui reste, sur l'essentiel des questions liées nos accords commerciaux. J'expliquerai au président américain, comme nous l'avons fait, le président du Conseil européen et moi-mé, lorsque nous nous sommes vus dans le cadre du G7 au Canada, qu'en fait nous pensons que le déficit est de l'autre cété de la barri. Si vous additionnez les échanges de marchandises, les échanges en mati re de services et les bénéfices réalisés par les multinationales américaines en Europe, le déficit se trouve de l'autre cété de l'Atlantique, donc il ne faut pas se laisser faire, il faut objectiver le débat et nous verrons, En ce qui concerne le Brexit, nous sommes en attente depuis plusieurs mois du livre blanc de Downing Street et nous verrons, l'analysis, ce qu'il en sera. Je veux toutefois dire ici, au sujet de l'accord du Conseil européen, que nous n'accepterons pas que la question irlandaise soit isolée au point d'étre la seule question non encore résolue la fin des négociations. All of us, we are Irish. (Applause)

name: Presidente. –
text: It is precisely in confirmation of our desire, with regard to Africa, to look to this continent

name: Manfred Weber
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the President-in-Office Jean-Claude Juncker has asked the question: glass half full or glass half empty? I would say that we had an empty glass at the last Council results. In this respect, we are already glad that something is inside. Looking at the Council's results, we have been very critical the last few times. This time it can already be said that progress has been made – and I would like to thank you for that on behalf of my group – in the area of migration policy, for example. The 10 000 Frontex officials, the clear commitment to providing the necessary money to the centres in both Africa and Europe, the reflection, Africa and Turkey, are clear progress. That is why it is positive, and we welcome these results. It has always been clear to us, as the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, that there are two sides to the coin: a committed and determined border protection and, on the other hand, a resettlement programme, where we extend our hand to the world's most vulnerable and invite and welcome them to Europe. We believe that the two sides belong together. I can say this in a party political way: if it is allowed for The Prime Minister, Mr Tsipras, to implement the Turkey agreement in Greece – which means, in concrete terms, that refugees will be repatriated directly from Lesbos to Turkey without scrutiny – if this is possible in a left-wing country, then we can also argue in the Mediterranean that we apply the same concept in the fight against the smuggling gangs there. I would, of course, like to single out the monetary question as a second point: not as much as we would have liked, but progress, a clear commitment to further development, to the European Monetary Fund, and, above all, the most important thing, the crown jewel: the backstop, which is intended to safeguard our financial markets. The focus on investment and personal responsibility – the buzzword of deposit insurance – is a real accent. The devil is in the detail here. In other words, by December we will see whether any real progress will be made on the matter. And we have to take a step further in this regard, because there are also PPE-DE Heads of Government, liberal Heads of Government, who are very sceptical about some of these developments. So we will also have to work there in our parties so that we can convince us so that we can move forward. Mr President-in-Office of the Council, I would just like to add one more thing, and that is that, in all these developments, it would be wrong for us to leave out the Democratic Chamber of Europe. If we make a European Monetary Fund, if we go towards an investment budget, then there must be a place where this is democratically legitimised and can also be controlled in the future, and that is the European Parliament. I would therefore ask that this be taken into account. Thirdly, Brexit. A lot has been said. I would just like to remind and underline the two points for my group. The first point is that I believe that the people of Europe must know in March 2019 what it means to leave the European Union. If we only activate the transitional period and nothing changes, then I believe that this will cause damage, political damage. It must be clear that something will change when you leave the European Union. Secondly, it must be clear that we need to formulate what 'long-term partnership' actually means. I cannot stand before my constituents next May and tell them that britain is leaving, we have agreed a transitional period, where nothing changes at all, and I cannot give any answer at all as to what the exit actually means for the City of London, for economic contacts, for the euro, or perhaps for the issues of police cooperation. If all these questions are open when we leave, then no citizen in Europe can explain it. That is why we need clear announcements in these two areas. Namely, in March 2019, "there must be" or "not doing" a difference, there can be no cherry-picking, and there must be long-term clarity as to what exit actually means. I still have my concerns on both points as to whether this will be feasible. That is why I would like to say on my group that there will be no automatic agreement on an exit treaty. The two points will have to be clarified in the autumn. And last but not least: foreign policy. I would like to thank mr President-in-Office of the Council for sending out a clear signal on Russia. The fact that we are extending the sanctions on Russia is a clear signal. Given that America and Russia will meet in Helsinki, it is important that we establish a clear position. Violence and war cannot be a means of politics. That is why we stand by the sanctions and hope that Russia will return to a partnership path.

name: Udo Bullmann
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I would like to welcome President Tusk to this House. It is good to have you here, Mr Tusk. I do not exactly know about the glasses in the Council meeting – half full or half empty – I don’t care too much about the glasses but I am worried about the results.  If I ask myself why European citizens very often become more and more irritated about our institutions, one answer could be that we are permanently selling victories where no progress, or no sufficient progress, was achieved. This, I would like to say, is also one of the results of the last European Council. European and monetary union: progress. The big crisis in 2008 to 2009 – that is 10 years, my friends, 10 years we have been waiting for strengthening of our institutions. Are we waiting for the next crisis to hit European citizens? Or why is that necessary? Why cannot we speed up?  On migration: we lose lives each and every week in the Mediterranean. Each life is one life too many to lose. It is an incredible scandal that we do not get our act together and I do not question, President Tusk, your personal willingness to do something about it, but we, the leaders of three Groups in this House, the Liberals, the Greens and we, the Social Democrats, have written a letter to you: please put the Dublin reform at the top of the agenda because this is the cornerstone for everything. Until today, we did not see any political response.  I am not satisfied with the result of this Council. I think what Europe needs is progressive leadership and I could not detect progressive leadership. I could see that some members of the Council, some heads of state or government tried to add additional value to the conversation. Pedro Sánchez was jumping in and saying we have a new policy in Spain. I welcome this. Cyprus was doing something – they are ready for bilaterals – but this is not enough, we need structural solutions. We need a complete Dublin reform.  If I ask myself what the building block of the resolution, the final statement, was then, yes, I can detect a building block. The building block is that everybody has something where he can claim victory – but nothing is going to happen, and this is not enough for Europe and this is not enough for the European citizens and for the big challenges we have to face. Ich frage mich: Sie sind viel besser als andere in der Lage, die Blockaden zu analysieren, die es im Visegrád-Block gibt, wenn es zur Frage der Migration, zur Frage der Flüchtlinge kommt. Aber wann ist denn der Zeitpunkt, wo wir einladen, wo Sie einladen zur großen Debatte, zur großen europäischen Unterhaltung darüber, was wir eigentlich brauchen, um aus den Sackgassen herauszukommen? Wann kommt diese große Debatte? Wie viele Menschen sollen noch sterben, bis diese große Debatte kommt, wo wir dann fragen: Ja, was sind eure Interessen? Natürlich haben die Visegrád-Staaten Interessen. Sie wollen in Sicherheit leben – das ist Verteidigung und Sicherheit. Das wissen wir. Sie wollen Energiesicherheit haben, sie wollen auch morgen Kohäsionspolitik haben. Das sind alles relevante Themen. Aber wann kommen wir denn dazu, sie einfach mal mit den anderen Fragen zu kombinieren, wo wir dringend auf Solidarität warten: bei der Migration, bei den Flüchtlingen?! Warum gibt es kein Paket, Herr Präsident Tusk?! Warum nicht?! Ich interessiere mich nicht für halb leere Gläser oder für halb volle Gläser. Es ist ein Skandal, dass wir in Europa nicht vorankommen, und das ist es, worauf die Menschen warten, und deswegen können wir nicht zufrieden sein, und deswegen müssen wir in den nächsten Wochen und Monaten drängen. Meine Fraktion steht zur Verfügung, das europäische Projekt wieder stark zu machen. Aber das, was geliefert worden ist, wird nicht reichen.

name: Raffaele Fitto
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in the last few days, at the end of the European Council, when I read the first statements by the participants, I expressed my satisfaction. I read the statement by the President-in-Office of the Council of my country, who was enthusiastic.  Then, continuing to read the agencies, I read Orban's, who was thrilled. And then I read Macron's, and he was excited. There I realized that something was wrong, that things could not have gone well; so much so that, the moment I read the document, I realized that nothing changed: because that is the truth. The glass half full or half empty, Mr Juncker, is unfortunately half full only for avoiding a resounding rupture but not for having achieved results. And I am addressing not so much the President of the Commission as the President-in-Office of the Council, because the real big problem lies there, the real problem from which we cannot get out is the Council's inability to find a solution. I have followed and fully share the position, action and role that President Tajani, on behalf of this Parliament, has taken with regard to the initiatives that have been taken, on the need to be able to intervene on the migration front by giving clear and precise answers. But at a time when bailouts under international law remain as they were, reception centres are exclusively on a voluntary basis, redistribution is a topic that cannot be talked about, it is clear that the 2020 target is a goal that is not good, because in 2020, between now and 2020, although migratory flows are also decreasing at this stage , however, in some countries there is a risk of an unacceptable situation in all respects, fuelling an anti-European climate towards these institutions that is no longer manageable. That is the truth. So the institutions have a duty to deal with this situation and the European Council, if the statements and considerations that have been made this morning are true, should give answers. In conclusion, I would like to add that I listened very carefully to Chancellor Kurz this morning; I have listened to a very positive speech for your country, because the statements about the relationship with Germany, about the possible decisions to be transposed to the border in the relationship and in the confrontation with Germany are clear: the domestic policy choices are very clear. The positions announced, on the other hand, on the general agreement on immigration are very, far too general, because we do not have the framework for a precise objective, in which we do not have the courage and the strength, from the point of view of managing this situation, to be able to say clearly that we are leaving national egoism in order to clearly manage a broader vision of this intervention. This is the framework before us, and that is why the position on the Work of the Council and the document it has adopted is absolutely negative.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I have to tell you that I agree with Mr Fitto. It doesn’t happen all the time, but I agree 100% with the assessment he has made. You were not there, Mr Tusk, but while we were preparing for the European Council in this House here three weeks ago, I proposed to the President to examine whether it was not necessary for our Parliament to go to court, because there is a clear failure to act by the Council, especially on the Dublin file. I don’t say this in a wild way; it is based on facts.  If you look at the Council conclusions, what are they saying? Have you liberated additional money, 2019-2020, to start with the Border and Coast Guard? Will you do that? Additional money to the 2019-2020 money? Otherwise, we cannot accelerate the Border and Coast Guard from 2027 to 2020. Have you agreed on a new Dublin asylum system? Where is the position of the Council? We have had our position since November, and we are still waiting for the position of the Council. There is not even a word on this. We are going to work further on this – that is the only thing you can read from the conclusions. The same on these reception centres. What we have in the conclusion is that we are going to ‘examine’ it. In European language, that means it is going to take a while. Reception centres of disembarkment platforms – you are going to examine them while you all have different points of view. Some are in favour of in Europe; others say no, out of Europe; some are saying that it has to be closed, while others are saying they should be open centres. You have the experience in France where there is a centre like that in Chartres, which is working very well. These people who come to the centre in Chartres can ask for asylum, and when this asylum is agreed on they will be transferred to France. That is happening now. Why do you examine it? Why do you not decide on it?  The same on legal migration, legal economic migration. I think there is no possible solution unless we also have an agreement on legal economic migration in this package. Where is the decision of the Council? I don’t think that the deal in Germany between the CDU and the CSU now will solve the problem. On the contrary, what you risk is the reinstatement of national border controls, killing Schengen. That is what is already happening with Austria, because Austria is now considering – they have announced it in government circles today – closing the Brenner Pass because of this internal German deal, so that is what is happening today. And then you come here and say ‘no, no, no...’.  I can tell you that the problem is a political problem; it is not migration. It is exactly the same, and Mr Bullmann is 100% right when he says that that isn’t going forward either in the eurozone reform. You have a problem in the Council. I do not know what to do. You have to block them during the holidays for three or four days. You come out one day and you say ‘here we have a text’. In the past it was different. I remember once, together with Jean-Claude Juncker, at a summit in Nice – do you remember that? – we needed to reform the Treaty, and it took four days and four nights before we got an agreement, at 4.00 in the morning. But we got an agreement. And here, after one day you come out and say ‘we have a text; it is very general; we are going to examine this, maybe we are going to do that’. That is not the way. Put them together. Maybe, this holiday, put them all together on your disembarkment platform somewhere in the Mediterranean, these 27 Member States and heads of government, and make a deal. Push for it, lock them in a room; that is the only way they will understand, otherwise we will continue and continue. And the eurozone reform is exactly the same. We say we have made progress. Progress? You name the progress. I am sorry, Jean-Claude, but I am not in agreement with you on the so-called ‘backstop’. It is a fake backstop. It is a credit line, a credit line that will be given to this resolution by the ESM. I asked you, Mr Tusk, if you engaged this credit line, if the ESM engaged this credit line, will there be an approval of the Deutsche Bundestag – yes or no? In my opinion, yes. And if it is yes, it is not a backstop; it is a fake backstop. That is the reality. A backstop is automatic. A backstop is not something that has been approved in I don’t know how many parliaments or how many governments of a Member States. Don’t take it personally; my attack is not on you, it is on what you represent: the European Council. You have said a few times with a lot of courage these past few weeks, after everything that happened with Trump, that we are on our own – and I think that is right. We are on our own, but the problem is that we are in fact not capable of acting on our own – and that problem you have to solve, Mr Tusk. (Applause)

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to say to President Tusk that I can only share the disappointment that we have still not got anywhere on the whole eurozone reform matters. We have not got anywhere on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and so many important issues.  The eurozone reform has not just been around since yesterday; we have had this crisis since before 2010. We know what to do, and it’s not going ahead because the heads of State and government are just not doing their work and are not getting ahead. Instead, at the Council the only talk was about migration, migration, migration – as if it’s the only problem that we have. I care very much about migration, but I have to say that there are other things we have to talk about.  President Tusk, when talking about migration and refugees, you did not talk about the hundreds of lives that have been lost just in the last few days, while the rescue boats are stuck in the ports because some Member States want to bring the people who actually rescue people to court. This is really an active engagement against rescue at sea. This is against any sort of international law, but it is also against any sort of humanity not to let others, who want to do the work, rescue people. This is not something you talked about. I wonder if anyone still remembers Lampedusa 2013 and how we all went and said that we were so sorry that hundreds of people had drowned. But now, again, hundreds of people are drowning and we are turning a blind eye. I do not think this is direction Europe should be going in. You also didn’t talk about the Common European Asylum System that this Parliament has been preparing, where we have managed to get political compromises together across the groups. So I really wonder why we managed to do it and you don’t manage to do it, whereas the same parties are present here and in the Council. This is what you did not talk about.  Instead, you talked about creating this disembarkation platform: camps somewhere in the Sahara. You might say that people can ask for asylum, but that’s the thing: the one word about resettlement mentioned in the conclusions is ‘voluntary’. You will not find a Member State which is going to admit those people who might get asylum there. You will just put the refugees somewhere in the camps in the Sahara and that’s the end of it. If this is being implemented, it’s basically an end to the right to ask for asylum here in the European Union, and this is not where we should go. The right to ask for asylum was invented in Europe. The aim of the Geneva Convention, just after the Second World War and as a result of the incredibly horrible experience, was to never again let anyone suffer and not find protection. That was the aim of the Geneva Convention, and I do not think we should give up on that so easily. So we have managed to find a compromise in Parliament and, even if you want to close off the borders completely, it will never work. You can never completely close off a border, but what actually you can do, with the heads of State and government, is extinguish any light of humanitarianism and any light of the human rights that the European Union has always stood for. I do not think we should not go that way. We should stand up for human rights, especially the rights of people who are not living here, and especially the rights of people who are not us, because that’s when you show how much you care about human rights.  (Applause)

name: Curzio Maltese
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would say that the European Council achieved a result and that is to produce a rare climate of sharing between various political groups of the same feeling, as it is today, of absolute disappointment. The Council has done nothing but approve of what is happening, pretending not to know that the worst is happening. The peoples of Europe have witnessed this theatre playing into the hands of the good and the bad, where, on the one hand, there was openly xenophobic rhetoric from certain governments, such as my own, the Italian Government, and, on the other, less crude but equally ignoble and, in any case, very hypocritical rhetoric, from governments such as the one French which, having dumped the issue of migration on the shoulders of the countries of southern Europe, today want to give these countries a lesson in morals at no cost. So I am not talking about what has been decided, because nothing has been decided, but about what has not even been discussed. President Tusk says that Europe has no intention of leaving Africa: Africa has already abandoned it! I would like to know where and when we have talked about the real causes of mass migration and about which the citizens of Europe know nothing.  Who is talking here about the war in South Sudan, about the 300 000 dead and the millions displaced, about the civil wars in Somalia, Eritrea, Chad, Mali, the Central African Republic, which are a big deal for European arms dealers? Who is talking about the tens, soon hundreds of millions of Africans fleeing desertification, climate change, land and water theft by multinationals? Establishment parties and anti-establishment parties are pretending to divide: in reality they are complicit in this silence. It is better for some to hide their complicity in recent years in the hyper-liberal exploitation of Africa and its further reduction into a state of slavery, and it is better for others to earn easy votes on disinformation, hatred and fear. The important thing is that the peoples of Europe should know the facts and not consider them as solutions, what? The witch-hunt against NGOs, which are wrong to be where the European Union should be and is not there and there is less and less. Or would it be a solution to continue to finance real lagers in Turkey and Libya? These are not solutions: they are offended by the intelligence of European citizens.

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, well, it is not difficult to get the mood of this room this afternoon. The answer to the question is very simple: the glass is half empty. It is sombre in here, and that is because you know in your hearts that something fundamentally changed at the European Council last week. It could be summed up in a word: Italy. A founder member of the European Union uncritical for decades of the process of European integration and now as a result of the last general election, an Italian Prime Minister threatening to veto the entire proceedings unless he was given something on migration. But how to satisfy the Italians and to save the ever more beleaguered Ms Merkel. That was the question. And traditionally, you would have looked for a European answer but there wasn’t one, so you came up with a very weak formula talking about regional distribution centres on a voluntary basis. The deal which everybody said would hold had fallen to pieces within the space of a few hours. I have to say what you saw was the rebirth of the nation-state, and that is the direction, that is what Brexit is, that is what Trump. That is what the Italian elections are all about, and I wonder whether the Verhofstadts of this world recognise this massive shift. And it isn’t just a one-off. it is a trend. People want to do things at a national level. Where I do sympathise with everything the speakers have said is in their criticism of the British Government, who two years on have a summit this Friday to decide exactly what our Brexit policy is. So, no, we have not exactly made life easy for you but then nor have you for us by continually saying that Mr Varadkar in Dublin can veto the entire deal. I would suggest Mr Tusk wasn’t necessarily particularly helpful either. But one area in which you do agree, I but I wonder for how long, is you talked about increasing military cooperation Mr Tusk, being discussed at that Council meeting last week and this when earlier today we heard from Mr Weber from the CDU that he wants foreign policy to be decided without veto. Just a quick look ahead to next week. Mr Trump will be at that NATO Summit next week. You appear to be hell-bent on pushing for your European army; hell-bent for a foreign policy without veto and hell-bent to be on a direct collision course with President Trump and with NATO. You can’t have a European army and NATO existing side by side and maybe your next big challenge is European citizens will need to work out who they feel best protected by: a European army or America and NATO. I think I know what the decision of the people would be. Next week, we may well find out.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, now it is no longer the Commission that decides on migration, it is the nations that are taking over. Mr Macron and Mrs Merkel find themselves isolated, because their policy of welcoming illegal immigrants is now very clearly rejected by the people. Gone is the Paris-Berlin-Brussels axis. From now on, it is the leaders of Rome, Vienna and Budapest who are giving the la. This is the conclusion that can be drawn from the last European summit. The compromise that was reached with great struggle on the night of Thursday to Friday remains a compromise. But he makes it clear that, from now on, I quote: "all ships operating in the Mediterranean must comply with applicable laws and not obstruct the operations of the Libyan coastguard". This is the great step forward in Matteo Salvini's determined action against NGOs, which are often complicit in mafias and smugglers. It also calls for the end of compulsory quotas and stresses the need to strengthen external borders, which is a requirement of the Austrian Presidency. This is a defeat for the Brussels Commissioners and for the Macron-Merkel couple. However, to date there have not been any truly effective measures at European level, only courageous national responses. Therefore, before a hypothetical strengthening of the external borders, which we call for, it is indeed the national internal borders that must be regained control and control.

name: Diane James (NI).
text: – (start of speech off mike) [...] a touch of honesty and reality. The United Kingdom’s Times newspaper reported the Council meeting as follows: that it would break the European Union – I say that it will. That it has brought untold misery and exploitation – it has. The blame lies directly at the feet of the European Union, Ms Merkel and the EU Council – it does lie there.  The latest attempt to solve the problem with the migration crisis is a complete façade and is undeliverable. The European Union Council meeting was yet another failure to resolve a negative and unacceptable situation of their making. Plans for multi-billion-euro holding centres in Africa – a commitment given without any agreement from the African state leaders. More money to go into the coffers of Turkey with nothing in return, except to keep a problem at bay.  Please, will you wake up to the fact that your approach to migration has failed. Please take down the sign ‘Willkommen’.

name: Janusz Lewandowski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab There were no easy points at the last Council summit. I will choose two points where it is easier to have divisions and contradictions than to agree.  The first, of course, is migration. Given the differences of opinion signalled before the summit, agreeing on a common position is a relative success, especially in this complicated geopolitical climate around Europe, because it means wanting to seek a common European response in this regard. Some things are completely uncontroversial: sealing the external borders (but of course it is not about words, but about solid budgetary instrumentation), cooperation with transit countries and countries of origin, or seeking a solution to the immigration problem where it was originally born, which is also an uncontroversial issue, provided that the money follows, hence this trust fund for Africa, so important for President Tajani. A novelty is reception centers. However, the main message that has spread widely in some countries is, of course, the abandonment of the forced relocation of refugees. I believe that relocation would not work in europe's current political climate, where it could only fuel xenophobic or anti-European movements. Many issues remain to be resolved, including the reform of the Dublin system or the so-called secondary flows.  However, I am moving to the second point, where it is also easier to have divisions and tensions than to agree, i.e. the budget. There was no strong declaration of haste on the Part of the Council, namely the will to complete and agree on the budget after 2021, but before the European elections. Moreover, I believe that the proposal put forward by Commissioner Oettinger does not quite help us to find a common solution, because there is too much difference, especially in cohesion policy, between countries that lose – they have losses of 24-25% – and those that gain. It will not be easy to find quick consent.

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the recent European Council proved that something is wrong in the European Union because we have in front of us a clear choice. On the one hand is the option of a Europe that exploits citizens’ fears and advises a return to national borders, or of foot-dragging on important reforms, such as that of the eurozone for which we have been waiting for 10 years. On the other hand is the option of finally putting on the table at the European Council the proposals which we know about and know should be adopted. The choice can no longer be delayed because if we delay until December, then forget it! We are just paving the way for the decline of European integration. It is easy to foresee that. The European Council has come to a point where it needs to decide on another way: to use qualified majority voting, please, whenever this is possible, and it is possible on many of the blocked proposals.
