I would say to the Council: you have clear positions, majority positions from the European Parliament, giving you backing. Use this. Put on the table clear proposals for a clear definition from governments. We are in need of this. There are four big proposals to be put on the table. The first is to organise a European border capable of protecting people in Europe and also of giving protection to those asking for refuge. A credible proposal for a partnership with Africa also needs to be put on the table because everybody knows that without this, there is no real solution. A proposal for agreement on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), needs to be put on the table, providing cohesion and proper conditions for implementation of the European social pillar. And finally, on eurozone reform, yes, we have, so far, the only monetary zone in the world without fiscal capacity or deposit guarantee. The European Stability Mechanism needs to attain the capability framework and have the conditions for taking decisions. If these proposals are not put on the table, Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, you will lose your own personal chance. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Madam Colleague, you are calling on the Council to act and to have the asylum directive voted on by qualified majority. I would like to draw your attention to the fact that the asylum directive interferes with the rights of Member States to decide on the reception of asylum seekers, and it is also a question of security. Do you think this is really necessary? That one day you will not want the Member States to have more autonomy in this matter, a greater right to decide?

name: Maria João Rodrigues (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – I really believe that, when it comes to European asylum, something in respect of which European values need to be asserted, the Treaty of Lisbon is clear. We can decide by qualified majority voting, and your argument that security concerns should come into play is not relevant because, of course, we need to be careful about this, but that’s exactly why we need to build a European border. That is completely compatible with providing a European asylum system.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR).
text: – Madam President, I am glad that President Tusk and President Juncker did not only talk about refugees but also about the other challenge, or should I say catastrophe, that is Brexit.  We have heard here numerous times that the situation does not seem to be going smoothly. I had the opportunity to talk to the Austrian Chancellor, Mr Kurz, at lunchtime, and I asked him the same thing I have asked you already – that he should consider during his Presidency, which is the last Presidency of this Parliament – and, by the way, the Presidency where the deal would have to be done, or not – I asked him to offer Britain a new deal which enables at least the Remainers in that country to stop this terrible situation where two trains are running on the same track towards each other.  The other thing I asked him for is should, indeed, there be chaos in London, maybe in October or November, that he tries to offer a Britain an extension beyond March 2019. Should he do this, I would appreciate, President Tusk and President Juncker, that you support him.

name: Sven Giegold (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Pretty much exactly six years ago, we were here in plenary discussing – at that time – the four-president plan. We still thought that we urgently needed reforms of the euro area so that the next time the structural crises hit Europe, the euro would be safe. Time and again this reform has been postponed, plans have been put forward, and Mr Tusk himself has said it: he has promised that if the reforms do not finally come in June of this year, he will tell us who bears the political responsibility for it. We were lucky because the global economic environment has been relatively stable for the last six years. But let's just look at America: Mr. Trump, the global economic risks, they're still there. So I wonder: where are the reforms we need to keep the euro stable? The Commission's proposals are on the table – from tax cooperation to a finance minister who establishes democratic control over the Eurogroup in Europe, the common deposit guarantee, the common budget of the euro area, etc. There are more far-reaching proposals here from others in Parliament. So when does the Council assume its responsibilities and implement these proposals?  Mr Tusk, please keep your word! I am hearing that you are busy with other things.  President Tusk, please keep your promise and tell us today who's responsible for the fact that we didn't get the full eurozone reform package, and please defend outspokenly your proposals, because we need them in order to make the euro waterproof.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, allow me to express solidarity with the fair fight of interpreters.  The Council's decisions highlight the inhumane nature of the EU's response to migration. Erect a Fortress Europe, with more selective, beautiful and exploitative answers. They propagate the defense to alleged threats that, in the non-existent, aim to justify security and militaristic policies. They criminalize those who seek a safe place and advance measures that surround, inside and outside, the freedoms of peoples, feeding xenophobic and racist feelings. They are part of the most reactionary views in the response to a humanitarian crisis to which they close their eyes.  The repetition of the EU-Turkey agreement, the creation of the chilling landing platforms, authentic EU-sponsored concentration camps, result in an unavoidable violation of international law, from ransom to non-repulsion or asylum application. The death sentence of thousands of people in the Mediterranean has your signature, leaving hostages of human trafficking networks to escape them. Such decisions do not dissociate, rather reflect and deepen the EU's militaristic escalation or the policies that fuel exploitation, social exclusion, poverty, cuts in social functions and policies, health or education, or debt garrote. Country-specific recommendations, adopted under the European Semester, or euro area rules are reflected in economic and social divergences, conditionalities and impositions on fiscal and economic policies, which undermine national sovereignty and are contrary to the interests of Portugal and the Portuguese people and other countries.

name: Laura Ferrara (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, at the last meeting of the European Council, which gave a great deal of space to the issue of migration, tensions emerged between all the Member States on an issue that is extremely important for the future of the European Union itself. On the one hand we have the Group of Eastern European Countries, which is following the well-known policy of walls with regard to reception and, on the other hand, we have seen the attempt by the Franco-German axis to present a pre-packaged proposal, during the pre-summit on 24 June and, therefore, to impose on Italy a destiny on which Italy obviously did not agree. This, in fact, was the novelty of this European Council, italy itself, which rebelled and showed that it did not want to be considered a puppet and, above all, rebelled against the fact that it wanted to be considered as the only place where all the migrants rescued as a result of search and rescue operations and then take all the burdens deriving from the failed Dublin Regulation. For the first time in the European Council, therefore, thanks to the action of this government, it is stated that the landing of those who are rescued as a result of search and rescue operations which, as I have always said, are morally necessary even before a legal point of view, must be based on shared and complementary actions between the Member States. The foundations have also been laid for a system of legal avenues for access to the European Union, which I believe to be fundamental. It stressed the need for a reform of the Dublin Regulation which would balance responsibility and solidarity and which would also take account of landings. The urgent need for a partnership with Africa was also reiterated. So it is clear that the game is still open: there is still a lot of work to be done, especially with regard to the common European asylum system, which concerns not only Dublin but also the rules of procedure. It is on this game, and therefore still doing a lot of work, that it will be shown that there is still a European project based on cooperation and solidarity.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report and for his excellent work. Mrs Merkel said that migration can become the fate of the European Union when she spoke about the summit, and the lady is indeed right in this case. Mr Juncker was just talking about the post-war question, perhaps as a small promise. Well, this summit does indeed have some of that. This is because this summit is indeed a paradigm shift, and that is because there are no longer majorities and unity on a mercurial migration policy, on an illegal euro policy, suddenly in this European Union. The new, the young, the fresh Europe, that we saw here this morning with Sebastian Kurz embodied. The new Europe, that is the Europe of the Orbans, the Kurz', the Salvinis and also Seehofers, who has now won off Merkel in Germany as well. Many in this Parliament do not want to see that. Mr Weber spoke again today about resettlement programmes. Mr Weber from the CSU, of all people, is falling behind Mr Seehofer in the case of relocation programmes from Africa to Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, the vast majority of you were wrong. You were wrong when you put the administration and the planned economy above the market economy. You were wrong when you wanted to trade the homeland for hedonism, and you were wrong when you claimed morality for your policies alone. What Europe needs now is unity, justice and freedom, but unity just under the realistic policy that Orban has begun, which Kurz has continued and which has now carried Seehofer all the way to Germany. We need a return to the primacy of law, not only in migration policy, but also in economic and monetary policy, and we need freedom for the citizens, because we are making policy for the citizens and not for your ideologies, ladies and gentlemen.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Madam President, last week’s Summit was wrongly billed as make or break for Brexit talks on the Northern Ireland border. Calmer heads have prevailed, but time is short. The backstop solution for Northern Ireland, as set out in the Protocol, is wholly unacceptable. Northern Ireland sells more goods into the Great Britain market than in all other markets combined. Equally, around 75% of all goods and services brought into Northern Ireland are from Great Britain.  A solution that sees these goods and services as being from a third country and therefore subject to customs checks is a totally unwanted interference within the UK’s internal market and its constitutional order. We will never accept such interference in the constitutional and economic well—being of our part of the United Kingdom. The European Union institutions have set as their priority the need to uphold the Belfast Agreement. This Agreement gave rights, in equal measure, to both communities in Northern Ireland. By seeking to take away that automatic access to the UK’s own internal market, the EU is removing those rights and undermining the agreement.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the Spanish Socialist Government was preparing for the media reception of the Aquarius flotilla with six hundred people on board. The Civil Guard rescued more than a thousand people from the sea, twice as many, without mayors or televisions being to receive them. The Open Arms is currently heading to the port of Barcelona with sixty migrants on board. And television cameras and politicians are also waiting for you upon arrival. In fact, several MEPs travel on the boat. Very media. But in the meantime, since the start of the year the Civil Guard has rescued more than seven thousand and five hundred people at sea, and no MEP was accompanying them on the legs, of course. And only on the Spanish coast have more than three hundred human beings drowned at sea and obviously no mayor was waiting for them in the port. On the one hand, we turned the worst humanitarian drama of our time into a television and political spectacle and, on the other hand, closed our eyes to the thousands and thousands of drowned. Ours, seen together, is called cynicism. We have leftover speeches and selfishness and we lack responsibility and heart. It is cynical to call an immigrant crisis a crisis that is of poverty, ignorance, religious persecution, climate change, disease, forgetfulness, femicide, but not people. Europe's problem is solved in Africa. To think that it can be easily fixed with bribes, humanitarian flotillas or pats on the back is not to see the truth or not want to see it. We can close ports, we can build detention centers all over the continent or, on the contrary, eliminate external borders so that everyone can enter. In the medium term, everything's going to be useless. If we do not help Africa change Africa, despair will continue to push millions of women, men and children to sea. If I were African, I'd be an immigrant. And it would be with my children, and so would all of you. (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr. González Pons, you speak of cynicism. I am talking about a lack of shame, because when we need to talk about the need for a European policy on immigration here, there are some who prefer to spend their time criticising a government which has been an example of solidarity within the European Union.  Do you know why the policy of quotas for the distribution of refugees in the European Union has failed? Because irresponsible governments, like Mr Rajoy's, have not fulfilled their obligations. When we had to receive more than 36,000 refugees in Spain, Mr Rajoy's government did not meet even 20% of that commitment.  That is the crisis in European policy on immigration and asylum. That's it. So don't talk about cynicism and recognize what your government's policy has been.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE)
text: "blue card" response. – It is a pity that my speech was in Spanish, because you have understood nothing. I have not said that the Socialist Government is cynical, it has applied it to you. I recommend that you listen to the video in your own language, in Valladolid's, and understand what I said. It is cynical that in the European Union, on the one hand, a media spectacle is organized when a ship is rescued and, on the other hand, look elsewhere when millions of people drown at sea. I said that, on the whole, is cynical. You have understood what you wanted to understand because I do not know if I have explained myself well in Spanish or if you understand Spanish well.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D).
text: – Dear President! No wonder people are scared. Dangerous populism and the rhetoric of spreading fear are winning among European leaders, which is not based on facts. Less than 95% of newcomers have been on European soil this year alone, and so it has fallen by the transition.  We have been left without the necessary concrete European solutions, that is, without the important Dublin Regulation, on which we have worked hard in the European Parliament for two years, and instead of The Europeans, bilateral agreements, problems and challenges have been addressed to third countries. These external platforms, dear President, will not work for disembarkation. Firstly, because there is no will and desire for them in the countries, and their consent is urgently needed by the Union. And secondly, because the scheme is voluntary and because we are creating a Dublin problem again: who will be responsible for the applications for examination, on the basis of what key will refugees be resettled in the countries of the Union? Quotas? Haven't we learned anything? And colleagues, without European solutions, we will seriously jeopardise Schengen, as is already happening to us. What Kind of Europe do we want to live in? In Europe with an army at its borders, which austria staged last week on the border with Slovenia, where it had military police operations, only 13 refugees have returned to my country this year alone.  Those who spread fear are the greatest fears for Europe and must be stopped until it is too late.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Since yesterday, we have known that, after three years of extremely negligent action, the German Government wants to control who comes to Germany again. After the immense damage that has been done because all those who passed by have been let in, this decision is compelling and logical. Austria's response comes immediately: Austrian borders are being controlled, and Italy is also getting serious about border controls. This means that the Schengen system will be repealed: if some people are to be denied entry, everyone must be controlled. We are losing one of the greatest advantages of the European Union because for a long time the European Union has not ensured that valid treaties – specifically the Schengen Treaty – and rules are respected. I would remind you, for example.B of the infringement procedure against Greece in 2010, which is still in a drawer to this day. It is to be hoped that the European Union has understood that the protection of the external border is an absolute priority.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Liisa Jaakonsaari (S&D)
text: blue card question. – Up to now, this debate has been of interest, but around 90% have all said no to some of the measures that are being put forward. I do not believe that this big 'no' and the big borderline will ultimately come up with any solutions. I would therefore like to ask you what you would accept in addition to the 'closed borders' policy? Do you agree with the amendment of the Dublin Regulation? Do you accept the partnership with Africa? Do you accept the reception of refugees in different countries? What do you approve of?

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. What I can accept is that the European Union protects the external border. If necessary, this border must be hermetically closed. It must not be the case that even one person enters illegally. That is to be accepted. That is the only thing that will work. And Dublin IV is dead. It is pure nonsense what is written in it. Dublin IV is dead.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Mr Tusk, this Council has been a disaster. Reform of the euro area has been completely blocked and immigration and asylum has been ceded to the demagoguery of the far right, an increasingly influential far right in the Council – not matter because popular Europeans have decided to open the door to some governments.  And what are the conclusions? Well, you just start to walk towards the death of the right of asylum with landing platforms in the southern Mediterranean – which are clearly illegal – or even with the mention of new centres. But what good is it to make new centres if there is no host policy, if Dublin is not reformed? New centers so that then these people go where? It's a real mess. That's the question you don't answer.  And then – you mentioned it yourself – the message you give NGOs in the conclusions by saying that they do their favor of letting Libyan coastguards do their job, when it is the Libyan coastguard who systematically violate human rights. For you to say that and that in the conclusions the dead in the Mediterranean do not deserve a single line is a real shame, Mr Tusk.  This Council was a real aberration.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, we have witnessed with outrage and shame a new chapter of the moral degradation of the European Union. A European Council that markets with human beings to save Mrs Merkel's government. A European Council for the greater glory of xenophobic politics headed by fascist Salvini. Criminal policies that are directly responsible for turning the Mediterranean Sea into a mass grave for those fleeing wars or misery. This agreement does not provide for legal or secure avenues and deepens the outsourcing of borders, opening up the possibility of installing real concentration camps such as our CIES, places of impunity and violation of human rights in third countries. It also delves into collaboration with pirate forces, such as the Libyan border guard, while dismantling rescue schemes or intending to criminalize NGOs that are complying with international law, the law of the sea or minimal human decency. They are not only worth humanitarian gestures, because if we are not attending the end of any decent project, buried between political selfishness and tolerance for fascism and racism.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: – Dear President, today I am just repeating what I said here three years ago. The quota policy has been despised, but it will only encourage migration to Europe more, because it sends a signal: 'You are welcome here, you will be taken care of'.  However, African states should send a completely different message to their governments: stable peace in the region and proper control of their borders.  So it took about three years for European leaders to understand that such an asylum policy leads to europe's creeping suicide. In the end, we managed to wake up from the sleep of the lethargic and only after several states made drastic but just and inevitable decisions. The political agreement reached is unlikely to help restore democracy and return from chaos to harmony if the ultimatums of the European Union vis-à-vis the smaller Member States continue to apply and European leaders ignore the will of the peoples.  People are tired of waiting. They require concrete solutions and reforms for the European Union.

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF).
text: Mr President, I would like to turn to Guy Verhofstadt, my former Prime Minister, who here with heavy arm movements towards the Council, as he always does, gave me the impression that he wanted to invite all illegal immigrants from Europe to Flanders. I will do it in the language he always uses here: "wake up, open your eyes, Mr. Verhofstadt". What has happened and what has been concluded by your Council, of this European Council, is that your Europe, your European Union, your centralised European Union is in tats. Along with Schengen, together with Dublin. That era is slowly but surely over.  There is one reality hidden behind all those Orwellian terms about disembarkation platforms and the like, one reality that is moving forward and that is that a new European Union is on the way with populists, as you always call it derogatory. People who listen to the people and who bring to here and to the Council the governments and parties who, on the basis of listening to what the people want, will pour out a much stricter immigration policy on Europe than you have known so far.   (The speaker responds to a "blue card" question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: "blue card" question. – Mr Annemans, I have the impression that here in Europe you still think Guy Verhofstadt is Prime Minister. To be clear, he did not sit at the Council table this weekend. You will continue here in the European Parliament with this hate speech, your calls for fear of the people, which your party has done in Belgium for many years. You're going to go through with this quietly. I have one specific question for you. Why are you against these disembarkation platforms? Why do you want to leave power in the hands of the people smugglers? Why do you continue to support small children drowning on those seas every week?

name: Gerolf Annemans (ENF)
text: "blue card" answer. Mrs Vautmans, it is very cute that you are defending Mr Verhofstadt, but I have heard him here today only pleading for more immigrants to come to Europe. If he had been in the Council, he would have met with them for four days until an agreement. No, I can't accept it. It is not because parties in our group are in power in Italy and Austria that they are isolated. We are not isolated. There are governments and political groups in other countries that are going to do things differently than Mr. Verhofstadt and the whole cabal here together.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab What we are seeing is the well-deserved result of many years of action by the European Socialists, who have built here a system of social benefits that attracts the most problematic immigrants to this continent. When you put free food on the table, then you have to keep an eye on the door so that some suspicious company does not enter. When people enter the market, everyone rejoices – every customer is welcome, because you have to pay your bill, but when you give away various things for free, you pull people, with whom then there are problems. The European Union does not currently border on any country in which war is taking place, except Ukraine possibly, so there is also no reason for it to accept war migrants. There is no reason for us to rescue people in the Mediterranean who are making a crazy decision. If someone wants to do such cruises at their own risk, they must not require others to rescue them. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Renaud Muselier (PPE)
text: "blue card" question. How can we say that people are allowed to die in the Mediterranean on the pretext that they are being cared for in Europe? What should we do? Stop public care, stop care for our fellow citizens? And what do we do? We take the decision to let all Africans die, who think only of one thing, to seek a little life and democracy. But what is this reasoning? This reasoning is the systematic abandonment of social policy in our European countries that is already protecting us. Let's start with that.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. "That's right. This means that we are abandoning social policy because social policy encourages people to take risky action. It is stupid actions and stupid statements – such as the Lord's at the moment – that encourage people to go to the Mediterranean and risk their lives because they know that the Lord will save them. They hope and often it ends badly, because everyone can not be saved. So if someone takes a risk and wants to cross the Atlantic, then of course they have that right, but they can't require others to always rush to their aid. Sometimes they can, but don't have to.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, Commissioner, the first point, which I think is essential, is to introduce some calm and some tranquility into this debate. This year the number of migrants and refugees is not alarming and therefore we should allow us to make a decision and a set of resolutions calmly and thought out for the medium term.  There is one fact that is indemsible: demographics are the only exact social science and the numbers speak for themselves. There will be no controls and there will be no barriers that can stop this movement and therefore we must have control over the process and, to do so, we have to focus on medium-term solutions. One is to strengthen the coast guard and borders in a very, very, very robust way, and the other is a Marshall Plan for Africa. Without a Marshall Plan for Africa, there will be no solution to this problem.  Europe once benefited from a Marshall Plan from the United States. Now is our time to retribution for this aid that the Americans once gave and put Africa in a development situation that will attenuate this movement.  Only then can we go far, but for that, Mr President-in-Office, there cannot be a budget 1.0, with a budget of 1.0 there will be no solution to any problem, let alone the problem of migration. (The speaker agrees to answer a question asked under the Blue Card procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Ana Gomes (S&D)
text: It asks according to the procedure "blue card". – Mr Rangel, you can explain to some of the Members in this House that at a time when there was no Schengen and that there were supposedly hard borders, more than a million citizens, their citizens and my citizens, had no difficulty in crossing these pure and hard borders, in search of a better life.  That is exactly what Africans are doing and we have responsibilities and we cannot change let people die. We're not fascists. We learn from history.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Mrs Gomes, there are many points where I disagree, but here is one point I would like to say. Just on Thursday the Prime Minister of Norway told me personally that she was minister of Immigration and Integration and that the situation in Europe today is much better than it was before.  So what we have to do is just prevent, make careful control, have a good protection of borders, also investing in Africa and, at the same time, leaving there are entries that are, say, gradual entries in our space and, if we do this, without discrimination, and even understanding that some economic migrants are in desperate situation and therefore that they are practically refugees , I believe we will have a balanced solution for the next time.

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: – Madam President, for in this age of post-truths and lies, we will tell five truths.  Mr President of the European Council, Mr Tusk: First, we are not being invaded by an avalanche of migrants and refugees. Other Members have already said this: we are in the lowest figures in recent years.  Second, Europe urgently needs migrants because we age, because we need them to pay our pensions and sustain our welfare state. And we all know it - you know it, we know it, the entrepreneurs know it, the governments know that.  Thirdly, the European Union needs to give a common answer, and you have a common answer on the table for months that you are not giving.  Fourthly, the Council's conclusions are disappointing. Despite the efforts of some governments, such as the Spanish Government, which has put on the table a humane, Europeanist and decent treatment of migrants, the Council's conclusions are nevertheless hugely disappointing.  And the worst truth of all is that there are some who are willing to change lives by vote because, even if we are in the lowest numbers of immigrants of the last five years, June this year has been the deadliest of all in the Mediterranean.  We are not giving a proper answer; we are not managing to slow flows, because flows are born of despair; and we are fueling the most xenophobic and racist debate in the European Union.  Listen to governments that are willing to make a human policy, like the Spanish government, no matter how much Mr González Pons says.

name: Laurenţiu Rebega (ECR).
text: – President Tusk, the last European Council ended with optimistic statements from all delegations and from all sides. It's a rare thing to say hello to! On the other hand, the fact that, after the Council, there were tensions at the level of Germany's leadership suggests that general solutions may be contrary to local interests. I want to point out two problems. As far as refugees are concerned, as I have always argued, the solution is that of massive European investment in the countries of origin. Wars and migrations start with a lack of resources. On the other hand, even if I support the hard line against illegal migrants, I believe that the idea of setting up "sorting" camps or centres in third countries is deeply immoral. I categorically reject such a solution! The second problem relates to the finding that this Council should have made consistent progress in the European Union reform dossier. The refugees were an emergency, all right! But in this way, we are in the paradigm "The Union is not reforming because it has serious problems". Do you not think that the Union has serious problems precisely because it is not reforming?

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the mere fact that the debate has been transformed from Council conclusions to a debate on immigration, I think, says it all. Dear Mr Avramopoulos, Mr Tusk, Mr Juncker – regardless of whether he is now absent from the Chamber – in my view you have no responsibility. You're relieved. But what's to blame if you don't have a responsibility? It is because the states, some states, consider that this is in their interest, what they are doing, isolation, enclosing, national borders.  How can this change and what is your responsibility? Bring fundamental proposals for change to the European Union, such as to make states believe that they have an interest contrary to what they think they have now, that they have an interest in opening up. Do that and, if they don't accept it, say so and denounce them publicly. Tomorrow you'll leave this position. At the very least, you have the image that you have e-already ed this perception of visionary change within the European Union. If I were an immigrant, if it were you, Mr Tusk, Mr. Avraboule, Mr Juncker, if you were an immigrant and read the conclusions, what would you do? I, I think, would go drown, I wouldn't have a choice. I regret to say it so extreme, extremist perhaps, but we are not giving a solution. (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Bernard Monot (EFDD).
text: Madam President, Mr Tusk, the last European Council, which was supposed to be crucial, is in fact an empty shell. This once again demonstrates the inefficiency of the European Union's decision-making process.  On the scourge of migration, no European solution has been reached, contrary to what Mrs Merkel and Mr Macron claim. Given the seriousness of the risk of migration to Europe, the political conclusions adopted are laborious, derisory and ineffective. As for the famous transit centres and landing platforms, migrants will avoid them. Almost all of the migrants are in fact economic illegal immigrants who are not real refugees. The only effective solution is the nation with its borders and customs officers.  On the reform of the economic governance of the euro area, its failure is obvious. European citizens can only welcome the german-inspired federalism of prison federalism served by Mr Macron.  It is now the states such as Italy, Austria and Hungary that are reorienting European policies. The big winner of this summit is indeed the President of the Italian Council, Mr Conte, who has demonstrated his courage and determination to uphold the will of the Italians.

name: Angelo Ciocca (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it says 5 million here and it is not a number: 5 million are people, they are women, mothers, fathers, children! 5 million poor Italians who cannot pay bills or who do not have a home or who do not have a job or who do not even have the opportunity to cure themselves. And this Europe, to these needs, to these problems, does not provide answers, but rather worsens their situation. All the peoples of Europe, now, not just the Italian people, are shouting loudly at this Europe: change, change, change! But there are still some 'Euroimbeciles' who wonder why, to these people's clinging of hope. because people are asking for change, because people are calling for a Europe that finds solutions and not a Europe that creates problems and that feeds problems; a Europe that in a crazy way in recent years has overwhelmed the 5 million poor Italians with a crazy and criminal invasion of reception. But we are now saying to Mr Juncker: the parcel is over! The Italians trust not this Europe but the League and Matteo Salvini!

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Madam President, Mr Tusk, Commissioner, today I chose not to wear a tie, because the Greek Prime Minister, Mr Tsipras, wore it to celebrate the agreement he made on greek debt, which did not reduce a single euro, and the country's supposed exit from the memorandums. He financially bound Greece on unprofitable terms for many more decades to the loan sharks. He also handed over the name of Macedonia to the Macedonians, contrary to the will of the Greek people. I assure you that the Greek people will not allow the agreement of the Prespas to be implemented.  At the last European Council, all the leaders of the countries of the European Union agreed that they disagree. Merkel, in order to maintain the coherence of her government in the face of the intense reactions caused by criminal attitudes to migration, proposed the promotion of illegal immigrants in the countries of first entry. And the Greek government, faltering with zero support for the people and with little political time now at its disposal, willingly agreed to ensure the outside good testimony, thinking that this would curb its ever-decreasing percentages. Of course, like the Prespa agreement, it will also remain on the cards to Merkel's disappointment. The Greek people will not let you destroy Greece and turn it into a warehouse for illegal immigrants so that you can serve your petty political interests.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I did not want to talk about migration, but I must. At a time when, due to several measures, the number of migrants arriving in the EU is a small fraction of the numbers of just a few years ago, we are facing a severe political crisis associated with migration, and this is despite the fact that I guess everyone knows that there is nothing like a national solution for migration.  Let me call on Council Members to work on a common functional and effective solution and not allow this crisis to get out of control. At the end of the day, I guess the Summit was more a success than a disaster, but only by a very small margin.  Other topics of the Summit, like promotion of security and defence, or economic issues, including trade, illustrate how substantial added value could be a function of the European Union for our citizens, the global economy and the world. I believe that we should not forget about it and we should not put it at risk.

name: Birgit Sippel (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The European Council announces fake news. reception centres in third countries – no country has yet agreed to this. And if so, what about the ban on rejections? And would vulnerable people come to Europe from there? Or is it just a matter of not taking in people fleeing war or torture? Reception centres in Europe – they already exist, and again there are no binding statements on redistribution. More staff for Frontex - but for what? Better control or foreclosure? National governments must finally agree on a comprehensive reform of the European asylum system. We need common rules on labour migration and agreements with countries of origin of this labour migration, so that the economy and democracy are further strengthened, they protect their citizens from false promises from smugglers and take back rejected asylum seekers. The Heads of State or Government must finally stop using fake news to unsettle people first and then deceive them with sham solutions. Finally, implement the decisions of the Commission and Parliament! Protect our citizens by controlling arms and drug smuggling, protecting them from the import of dangerous and counterfeit products, and protect the rights of our citizens, for example, by implementing ePrivacy! Finally do your job!

name: Sander Loones (ECR).
text: Mr President, what have we all heard here in the European Parliament? Mr. Verhofstadt says there is no migration crisis. Mr. Lamberts of Ecolo says migration, that doesn't wake people up, that's not a top priority. I think they missed the results of the elections, the results in Italy, in Austria, in Germany, in the Netherlands and in France.  The atmosphere in this Parliament is still there: we will solve the crisis by spreading more migrants. If we say: no, we must first work on strengthening our external borders, then the answer is: yes, we are going to do that with a European coastal and border guard. But to do what? That is the essential question: to do what?  We also want a strong coastguard, but one that can break people smugglers. A coast guard that's going to rescue and bring people back, so we can stop illegal migration. They just want a coastguard that will simply bring more boats to the European Union with no maximum limit. That will only increase the crisis, ladies and gentlemen, and that will not reduce the crisis. As long as the European Parliament does not face up to this reality, we will always be chasing the facts.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by congratulating The The fall of the EU will probably be the lack of action to stop the influx of economic migrants pouring into our Member States. At the same time, I am in favour of the word voluntary nature now appearing at the highest EUROPEAN level. The redistribution of migrants has been discussed and tried to be carried out for a long time, but then by force.  Now countries will be able to decide for themselves and, of course, most countries will not accept migrants. However, it took far too long to establish this and the result is that we have a large group of migrants who now need help to return to their home countries. The fact that we are now discussing setting up camps in third countries where economic migrants and real refugees are distinguished is a step in the right direction.  As I have pointed out earlier in this House, Europe must use a solution similar to that adopted by Australia. Through these measures, we ensure law and order within Europe, we ensure prosperity, our citizens will receive and, moreover, we will save thousands of lives in the Mediterranean. In addition, in the long run when order lines are restored, countries such as Sweden can spend part of the huge budget that is currently being spent on illegal economic migrants rather than help people in need on the ground in their home countries or in neighbouring areas.  But time is running out and before the decision is made, the flow of migrants will continue and the problems will grow within the EU.   (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Danilo Oscar Lancini (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I finally see the light at the end of the tunnel of uncontrolled immigration. There must be a concrete response, based on actions and not on promises. The conclusions of the European Council of 28 June include many 'ifs' and many 'buts'. There is a need for certainty: it emerges from the text presented that this Europe today recognises and defends the borders of the Member States, as we have always been calling for. It must be clear to everyone that stopping this trafficking in human beings means hitting traffickers and that parasitic system that lives on the shoulders of these poor wretches. In this regard, I would like to quote a great Italian political scientist, Gianfranco Miglio, who said: 'The degree of political civilization of a country depends on how the quantity and presence of parasites can be limited'. Parasites are in society as they are on animals: those of you who have a dog or cat know that parasites grow and the animal dies; and a society dies. There are historical examples of societies that have disappeared due to excess parasitism. Blocking illegal traffickers means stopping parasites, known in a socio-economic sense, not racism, it means saving Europe... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Madam President, the reactionary decisions of the Summit are sufficient for the cynical statement by the head of Frontex: the Member States, he says, of the European Union are not obliged to rescue migrant refugees, i.e. the victims of the imperialist interventions of the European Union, the Member States and their allies. In just three days, hundreds of dead and missing. And those who get away with it face the torment of waiting for which of the governments will first bring them back with the disgrace of Dublin, with the intensity of deportations, with a crackdown on borders. Otherwise, prisoners in Moria-type centres, in inhumane conditions bearing the stamp of the European Union and the SYRIZA-ANEL government. Now also in third countries, while European monopolies penetrate these countries. Maximum fraud is the stolen dipole "progressives" on the one hand and "xenophobic" on the other. The European Union's reactionary policy is common, in which all governments converge with their contradictions. The peoples with their struggle to give a decisive response to the unpopular decisions of capital, government and imperialist associations.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE).
text: – Madam President, there is a tendency here to say that if we don’t solve the problems that we are facing, the Union has failed. I think that is totally the wrong approach, for it is a way of underestimating the problems and challenges which we are facing and which, in many cases, are not of the kind that you can solve by a political decision today or tomorrow. We need to deal with them, and the only way to deal with them in a proper way is to stand together. That goes for the migration issue. It wouldn’t be easier if Member States were on their own. That would not be feasible at all. But together we can do it, if only step by step. And it is also true when we look at the more fundamental threats which we are facing from aggressive Russia or state capitalistic China, or which stem from the fact that we have a president in the United States who is unreliable.  We need to stand strong – strong in security, strong in cooperation – and not see every political conflict as some sort of dividing line. The right thing to do is to make us as strong together as possible and to see the threats to our democracy and our open society.

name: Patrizia Toia (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the summit was a great success of national self-interest: it won an idea of a Europe of barbed wire, not of the citizens or of those who are still drowning in the Mediterranean. The result: no obligation to show solidarity, only voluntarism and control of internal movements, with peace of mind schengen and Italian interests, to the detriment of Italy! Dublin is being left to the fate of consensus and this would be the great result of the novelty of the Italian Government: I say this to my colleagues of 5 Stars and the League, you are satisfied with much, very little. The conclusions state that illegal border crossings have decreased by 95%: so this is the certification that we are not experiencing a migration emergency but our own political emergency! More than the migration crisis, we need to talk about Europe's political crisis. But that's the paradox! My country, Italy, which is the one that now needs everyone most not to be left alone, is allied with the enemies of solidarity; it lends itself to the game of those who do not even want a refugee and, in order to give Europe a shot, it goes against Italian interests in order to defend those of Hungarians or those of other countries. A beautiful masterpiece of self-harm!

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI).
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support Progress has been made on migrant issues at the EU summit: the natural acceptance and management of migration has been removed from the centre of thinking. Preventing migration has come to the fore. To this end, the tasks have been decided: the EU's external borders should function as a real, genuine border, and regional centres inspected for the processing of asylum applications are needed, partly outside the Union. The effectiveness of returns needs to be increased and, last but not least, one of the most important decisions is the abandoning of the mandatory quota for the reception of migrants.  This also means that the amendment to the Dublin Regulation drawn up by the LIBE Committee, which includes these mandatory quotas, effectively failed before it was formally put on the council's table in the legislative process. Thank you very much!

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ-Βρυωνίδη (PPE).
text: Madam President, over the years we have been talking about the need for a common European asylum policy, a common European immigration policy and binding policies in all Member States. We all know, however, that volunteering has proven to be a failure, as are certain countries that have refused to implement decisions that we have taken. They support their interests without a European mentality. The summit did not provide satisfactory answers, it did not provide sustainable solutions to this top issue. Postponing the final reform of the Dublin Regulation for December creates insecurity, while undoubtedly not supporting the fundamental principle of solidarity.  The migration problem continues to burden the host countries, such as Greece, because flows from Turkey continue and even increase in 2018, as the Commission has confirmed. Ladies and gentlemen, the time for the European elections is approaching and we must all reply to our fellow citizens how proportional reception of refugees will work in all Member States, in accordance with the balanced and fair proposal of the European Parliament. There is no other way to decongest my country, Greece, so that it can manage this very important issue effectively, but also with respect for human rights.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Dear Chairman, migration has again emerged as the dominant topic, not because of the high influx of people as in 2015, but as a reflection of new political opportunities in Italy and the coalition crisis in Germany. Unfortunately, something remained the same and no reform of the Dublin Agreement and the common asylum system was agreed. While solidarity does not work in practice, there is again talk of the success of the conclusions that controlled centres will only be established on a voluntary basis. This severely limits solutions to the migrant crisis, and only serves to defuse political tensions in some member states. Of particular concern are the announcements of sending German border police to schengen borders, which would be an additional contribution to the collapse of Schengen. Croatia, as the member with the longest external border of the European Union, must not be left out of such partial arrangements. In conclusion, congratulations to Macedonia and Albania. Both countries deserved to open negotiations without further delay. But at a time when enlargement does not have sufficient political support as part of a comprehensive solution, such breakthroughs nevertheless represent progress.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you have missed an historic opportunity; you have only agreed on the outsourcing of borders, which violates rights elsewhere and opens up more dangerous routes. And also with regard to the attack on NGOs: intimate them not to hinder the Libyan Coast Guard and in the meantime people die at sea in the hundreds. And you governments, in your complicit indifference, as you close the doors and ports, are responsible for these deaths. There really is no sign of what is needed: no European solution, no agreement on Dublin, on which you want unanimity, and no compulsory relocation but only voluntary solidarity, which has never worked and which allows those who refuse to play their part to continue to do so. And within hours of the deal you were already arguing over interpretation: it's an undignified show, you're not worthy of your role! That is how nationalism wins by feeding on your inertia, but it loses the Union. However, the battle is not over: you have not listened to two-thirds of Parliament calling for ambitious reform in Dublin; you have not listened to the mobilization of thousands of people in 170 squares; But we will continue to call strongly for European solidarity until you understand that without us we are playing the Union and the future. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bernard Monot (EFDD)
text: 'blue card' question. "Dear Colleague, in your pro-immigrationist rant, you speak on your behalf and on behalf of the European Parliament, except that the majority of European citizens today no longer want immigration because they suffer in terms of their purchasing power and their jobs. What are you going to say to them in 2019?

name: Elly Schlein (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I am speaking on behalf of the European Parliament, Mr McKenna, because the European Parliament voted by a large majority for a reform in Dublin which ensures that each government does its part on reception. We are not facing an invasion: you are lying to the citizens of Europe. The numbers, with sharing solutions among all Member States such as those that this Parliament has called for by a large majority, can absolutely be addressed with sustainable solutions that can also bring important benefits to our local communities. You are lying to the citizens of Europe!

name: Knut Fleckenstein (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The Council has also taken a decision on enlargement and, In my opinion, a good decision. The fact that negotiations with Macedonia and Albania are to start in June next year was the right decision. Albania has presented a number of steps with its judicial reform, which must also be appreciated, and Macedonia has shown that it is on the right track by trying to reach an agreement with Greece on the name issue, and also with the treaty with the Bulgarians. I am very grateful to the Council and to you, President Tusk, also – especially personally for your commitment to this region. The majority of this House clearly stands for this policy, the Commission does, and 25 out of 28 Member States would have been right to go one step faster. Nevertheless, it was a good result, and the people of the Western Balkans deserved it.

name: Roberto Gualtieri (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Tusk, I appreciate your optimism, but it is clear that the conclusions of the euro area summit are inadequate in relation to the inescapable task of reforming and strengthening economic and monetary union. As you yourself acknowledged, there is only one decision: the ES MES will provide the backstop to the resolution fund and even on the concrete terms of this positive choice there are still no unambiguous indications! For the rest, we have yet another postponement and, indeed, we note that the principle of a euro area budget, on which there is already a legislative proposal from the Commission, cannot even be appointed by the Heads of State or Government and we are relying on a twisted game of cryptic references to all the elements of a letter to the President of the Eurogroup, who in turn asked for guidance from the European Council on this point. Our position on the substance is well known. Here we simply say: respect for the European Treaties; we are working on the Commission's legislative proposals under the ordinary legislative procedure and respecting this Parliament, which cannot be said to be 'take or leave' on a general approach by the Council.

name: Pervenche Berès (S&D).
text: Madam President, Mr Tusk, you said that having a budgetary support scheme for the resolution fund was a great step forward. Recognise with President Juncker that we cannot talk about progress on a point on which there has been a political agreement in principle for so long. However, this European Council should have said under what conditions this safety net will work. In the event of a bank resolution, no one can imagine that national parliaments should be consulted. So we will have to change the governance of the European Stability Mechanism, and on that you are totally silent. You are also silent on this object which ends up being unidentified, namely this budget of the euro area, this function of stability which everyone recognises is essential to deal with the next possible crises of the euro area. However, the European Council has postponed this matter, which is a serious mistake.

name: Seb Dance (S&D).
text: – Mr President, normally we celebrate when together there is a common thread in European thinking, but what has come out from this Council is a common thread that should worry us all: a total lack of leadership, a complete dearth of responsibility when it comes to the big issues. On migration, what do we think locking people up who are seeking a better life is going to do when we don’t tackle the root causes – the reasons why people feel the need to move from their homelands to seek a better life? We never get this right, and we listen to the people opposite who describe those people, those families, those children, as parasites. And we follow them. We follow their dialogue – they are the ones that are leading this, and we should be ashamed of ourselves.  If you want an example of dearth of leadership, look at the United Kingdom: a country that is now chasing a fantasy, and whose politicians are not owning up to the truth. This is the time for leadership: our citizens are crying out for it, and as long as we hold up these fantasies, we will get nowhere.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I want to thank President Tusk for the conclusions of this summit and I think they have one mistake, they are late. In the meantime, we have lost a long time discussing and enforcing mandatory quotas that do not work and which have caused great harm in some countries to those who are pro-European but want a sensible asylum policy.  The summit confirmed that the absolute priority is to protect the external borders and strengthen the coast guard. All vessels operating in the Mediterranean must comply with the applicable laws and shall not impede libyan coast guard operations. I think that is a clear message to humanitarian organisations, which sometimes help the smuggling business under the guise of humanity. And we don't want that. I therefore very much welcome this realistic approach adopted by the Council, which is in the interests of preserving European unity.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, President Tusk, Commissioner, the Council conclusions of June 2018 open the way for a Presidency which is announced under the slogan 'The Europe it protects', but not to protect Europeans from flesh and blood but to protect Member States from an alleged avalanche of immigrant foreigners and asylum seekers in a policy of fear that exploits fear , hatred and anger, which fuels the conservative far-right spiral, exactly the same spiral blocked by the Dublin Regulation, which imposes a securitarian rather than humanitarian bias on the policy of the area of freedom, security and justice and which outsources the management of external borders, and that it denies solidarity and shared responsibility for migration flows , which is exactly the mandate of the Treaty of Lisbon, that is, of common European law and international humanitarian law. Exactly the opposite of what needs to be done at a time when the flow of immigrants has declined dramatically and yet the exploitation of fear of immigrants is growing as an unacceptable and immoral new form of speculation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the European Council meeting on refugees is a monument to failure. Instead of actually deciding changes in Dublin III, you finally kept Dublin III running, which means that Greece is turning into a warehouse of souls. Instead of continuing the relocations, you are now turning them into a voluntary basis. So no one's going to do any relocation.  Instead of finding European solutions, we have been led to national solutions, at the initiative of Mrs Merkel and Mr Tsipras, who now agrees to return to Greece thousands of refugees who have passed through our country. So instead of solving the issue, you've complicated it. Greece cannot afford other appeals and illegal immigrants. The only solution is the application of Article 72 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union by Greece to suspend Schengen, suspend Dublin III, to stop Greece being a magnet for refugees and illegal immigrants.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Europe cannot absorb all the refugees who seek it, whether from the Middle East or from Africa, but it can do more, much more, to resolve the conflicts and wars that generate these refugees. Europe, as someone has already said, cannot absorb all of Africa's misery, but it can do more, much more, to combat poverty on this continent, not least because we have very special historical responsibilities.  Europe has dominated Africa for over 500 years. Has Europe designed Africa's internal borders and is this the result? Is this the result of European dominance in Africa?  There is therefore much to do. The solution is not to build walls, as some claim, nor to say, as some do, "Welcome, come more", to refugees and migrants seeking Europe. The solution lies in the assumption of Europe's historical responsibilities in this problem.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI).
text: Mr. President, Mr Tusk, I will speak in my mother tongue, Macedonian, that is to say in Greek; , not taking into account the will of the Greek people, you pseudo-democrats.  They falsely called the pain of the Greeks a "treaty of friendship". They falsely called "cooperation" the prohibition of expression and democratic decision-making. They falsely called it a "good neighbourhood" serving the interests of America and the European Union. Greek history is not a product for conciliation, extradition, falconing or tarnishing for the political survival of left-wing "Malist people". When reason is displaced by interests, then we must recall the obvious. All Greeks, Macedonians and non-Macedonians, are on a strong alert against counterfeiting and attempted sell-offs.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Dear Mr President Tusk! I am approaching that of the majority of Members, colleagues and colleagues who give a positive assessment of the council's conclusions, mainly because of the volunteering that the solidarity mechanism has received, in order to increase the possibility of setting up regional centres, including transit centres, as soon as possible, because you are closer to a comprehensive approach for effective border control, including the objective of destroying the business model of smugglers, and that we will already get 10 000 officials at the external border in 2020. In the area of defence, too, it is a step forward, it is about measures to increase investment in defence, but also to coordinate investment policies in the arms industry.  The negative in all of this is that the conclusions are too little concrete, too little operational.

name: Sylvie Guillaume (S&D).
text: Mr President, on migration issues, the Council has not reached a european solution, much less a European solution. Everything that has been said is based on volunteerism, bilateralism and outsourcing. It is easy to reach an agreement when none of the proposed measures are binding, except that it does not work.  For example, there is agreement to implement closed centres within the Union, but no country is willing to host them. There is agreement on the establishment of de-boarding platforms in third countries, without even warning them. As a result, no one wants them and nothing is moving forward. I mean, I do. We endorse the outsourcing of our migration policy by delegating our responsibilities to territories that sometimes treat migrants as slaves.  Yet solutions exist. They are not miraculous, but they would save lives and break the economic model of smugglers. These are legal routes of migration and the reform of the Dublin III Regulation. However, it seems that the Member States have decided otherwise and have chosen populism and hysteria on the subject, instead of efficiency and rationality.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by As we hear, the last summit on refugees was a compromise, indeed a success. There will be no forced relocations. However, after returning to Germany, Chancellor Merkel stated that fourteen European Union countries had voluntarily agreed to relocate refugees to their territories. Three of the countries it listed immediately denied this information. Could the President of the European Council say what the outcome of the summit really was? Has there actually been an agreement between Germany and these countries, or is european public opinion being deceived to save the government coalition in Germany?  If such an agreement is concluded, is it not compatible with the Dublin III Regulation? I therefore ask for information as to whether the Council or the Commission has implemented proceedings against countries which have infringed the Dublin III Regulation?

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by expressing my thanks to all of you for your contribution to this very important debate, but let me tell you that the next time, if we have a similar debate, it would be good to see, seated next to President Tusk, 27 leaders having an open discussion directly with you. I am sure they would come out from this room wiser and more responsible.  We all talked about the glass. The glass is half full, yes, but the bottle is there, full of European ideas, initiatives and solutions. Instead of looking at the glass, look at the bottle and its contents. Finally, a bottle is there to be shared. This is definitely a question of political will. Only if the will is there can we reach solutions. We need European vision to revive it, and realism.  Yes, I agree with all of you that we need leadership – strong leadership – to reach future—proof answers. We cannot operate in crisis mode on migration anymore. Many of your interventions indeed reflect the fears, the concerns, questions and convictions of our citizens too. Here is what I see as the essence of the European Council last week.  European leaders confirmed their commitment to a comprehensive approach to migration and for me the most difficult task was Mr Tusk’s; to bring together 27 leaders. It remains to be supported now with concrete proposals and actions. They reaffirmed that no country should be managing this alone, and that we can only move forward with the joint and European approach both inside and outside Europe, and naturally at our external borders.  This is precisely the approach which has been adopted by the Commission since the very beginning, and it is this approach, and no other, that has already produced results. And of course, thanks to your support, to the support of the European Parliament. Indeed, we have managed to significantly reduce irregular arrivals into the European Union. We are not where we were three years ago, definitely. Based on these positive results, we now need to further address the structural changes where they really are.  We cannot forget the big picture and we can never lose our humanity. Over the past few days, many shipwrecks have occurred close to the Libyan coast and hundreds of people have lost their lives. I understand that you are outraged by these events. I am outraged too and that motivates me to keep going and not deviate from our values and principles. We can never turn a blind eye to the situation on the other side of the Mediterranean. The outcome of the European Council builds on what we have achieved so far, and gives us the operational and practical guidance to continue.  We are already working on their implementation because the tragic events in the Mediterranean show once again that there is no time to lose. We do not start from scratch and we do not leave anyone alone. The EU—Turkey Statement has been key to fighting smuggling in the eastern Mediterranean and reducing the irregular arrivals to Europe. We remain committed to upholding it, also by delivering the second tranche of the EUR 3 billion for the protection of refugees hosted by Turkey.  More than 600 000 lives have been saved so far, thanks also to the support of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency. More than 1 300 have been evacuated from Libya to Niger. More than 15 000 have been returned voluntarily from Niger or Libya to their country of origin. The Libyan coast guard are rescuing an increasing number of migrants.  Thousands of migrants in Libya are receiving access to medical help and other services thanks to International Organization for Migration (IOM) and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), which, as you know, we support financially. On top of this, another EUR 500 million will be transferred to the EU Trust Fund for Africa to ensure that our many actions to address the root causes of illegal immigration will continue.  We count on Member States also to pitch in with significant financial contributions. It is clear that we have to further engage with countries in Africa. To further strengthen our external borders, we will soon present a proposal to beef up the European Border and Coast Guard Agency even more and transform it into a genuine EU border police, but an effective and firm migration policy is not and cannot be just about borders. As the President said, reform of the common European asylum system is equally essential. It is necessary, not only to ensure solidarity among Member States, but also to effectively reduce secondary movements within the European Union. We are so close that I frankly see no defensible reason for delays. The five pieces of legislation on asylum qualifications and reception conditions, on Eurodac, on resettlement and on our asylum agency should be adopted before the end of this month, and then I plead once again with Member States to move towards finding an agreement on Dublin and asylum procedures before the end of the year. It will be one of the most important legacies that we, all the European Union institutions and the European Parliament, can leave behind. The facts and reality tell us we are no longer in a migration crisis. The crisis we are confronted with is purely political. I call on everyone not to protract this political crisis any longer and to get down to business. I am looking forward to working closely with you, as I have always been doing during the last three and a half years and, of course, with the upcoming Austrian Presidency to swiftly make progress on all these aspects. The informal Justice and Home Affairs Council that will take place next week in Innsbruck will be the first opportunity. Allow me to say some words in Greek, responding to Mr Hadjigeorgiou.  Κύριε Χατζηγεωργίου, συμμερίζομαι την ανησυχία σας. Πιστέψτε με, είναι και δική μας. Η πρόκληση της μετανάστευσης στην ουσία δοκιμάζει την ίδια τη συνοχή μας και η απάντησή μας σε αυτή θα καθορίσει το κοινό μας μέλλον. Πολλοί πίστευαν ότι θα ήταν η οικονομική κρίση, η οποία θα έθετε σε αμφισβήτηση το μέλλον της Ευρώπης. Τελικά, είναι η διαχείριση της μεταναστευτικής κρίσης γιατί απευθείας και στην καρδιά αγγίζει τις αρχές και τις αξίες πάνω στις οποίες έχει χτιστεί το ευρωπαϊκό οικοδόμημα. Εμείς, η Ευρωπαϊκή Επιτροπή, από την αρχή έχουμε αναλάβει τις ευθύνες που μας αναλογούν και έχουμε καταθέσει μια ολοκληρωμένη πρόταση για την ευρωπαϊκή μεταναστευτική πολιτική. Θυμηθείτε πού ήμασταν πριν από τρία χρόνια και πού είμαστε τώρα. Ας συνεχίσουμε πάνω στις ίδιες γραμμές. Και οφείλω να τονίσω, για μία ακόμα φορά, ότι το Ευρωπαϊκό Κοινοβούλιο έχει στηρίξει αυτή την πολιτική και εργάζεται προς την κατεύθυνση της ολοκλήρωσής της. Οι κοινές αυτές προσπάθειες, όμως, δεν επαρκούν. Δεν εναπόκειται πλέον τόσο στα κράτη μέλη. Εγώ συνήθως αναφέρομαι στις κυβερνήσεις των κρατών μελών, θυμίζοντας ότι οι κυβερνήσεις έρχονται και απέρχονται, ενώ τα κράτη θα είναι εκεί. Και πρέπει πάντα να θυμούνται οι σημερινές κυβερνήσεις ότι ήταν ιστορική η απόφαση των προηγούμενων ηγεσιών να περάσουν το κατώφλι της ευρωπαϊκής οικογένειας. Εναπόκειται, λοιπόν, στις κυβερνήσεις των κρατών μελών να αναλάβουν τις δικές τους ευθύνες· να ξεκαθαρίσουν πώς αντιλαμβάνονται τον ρόλο τους και τη θέση τους μέσα στην ευρωπαϊκή οικογένεια. Η κοινή μας ευθύνη είναι μεγάλη και θα έλεγα ότι κάτω από τη σημερινή συγκυρία είναι και ιστορική. Και από την απάντησή μας στην πρόκληση της μετανάστευσης θα κριθούμε από τις μελλοντικές γενεές, γιατί αυτή θα καθορίσει τελικά την συνοχή και την ενότητά μας. The migration challenge is putting in question our principles and values, as I said before. It is, however, only by upholding them that we can move ahead stronger and united. We will all be judged by the way we respond to it.  These values are the way for responsible and effective decisions to move ahead. We need leadership and vision, but also frank and brave discussions amongst us. This Commission and this Parliament are showing the way by agreeing on a comprehensive migration policy. I expect that the governments of the Member States will also take their responsibilities.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, allow me to make just one comment on migration. I am absolutely sure that the people of Europe expect us to show determination in our actions to rebuild a sense of security and order. People want this not because they have become xenophobic and want to live in a sort of European splendid isolation with walls against the rest of the world; they want to have a political authority able to enforce the law to protect our territory and our borders. In fact, this is the first and the most important obligation of every government.  Many in Europe and around the world claim that the European Union – or, more broadly, our traditional democracies – are unable to efficiently protect the external border. This is a favourite argument of some new political movements, not only in Europe, offering simple radical and attractive answers to the most complicated questions. They want to convince people that only strong men, anti-European, and with a tendency towards authoritarianism, are capable of stopping illegal migration, and we have to prove that they are wrong. We have to fulfil our political obligation. Jeśli chodzi o polskie pytanie, ewentualne dwustronne porozumienia między Niemcami a innymi państwami europejskimi nie były w ogóle przedmiotem obrad Rady Europejskiej.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – In this age of post-truths and lies, we must speak with truths. First, we are not being invaded by an avalanche of immigrants and refugees. In fact, we're in the lowest figures in recent years. Second, Europe urgently needs migrants because we age, because we need them to pay our pensions and sustain our welfare state. Thirdly, the EU needs to give a common answer, and you have Parliament's proposal on the table for months. Fourthly, the Council's conclusions are disappointing, despite the efforts of some governments, such as the Spanish Government, which has put on the table a humane, Europeanist and decent treatment of migrants. And the worst truth of all is that there are some who are willing to change lives by vote because, even if we are in the lowest numbers of immigrants of the last five years, June this year has been the deadliest of all in the Mediterranean. We're not giving a proper answer. We are not managing to slow flows, because flows are born of despair; and we are fueling the most xenophobic and racist debate in the EU.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. – In the last month, some 400 people have died in the Mediterranean, trying to reach Europe On the other hand, on 1 July, 32 people have entered Italy irregularly. No people in Greece. The figures are accurate and provided by the United Nations and demonstrate a trend that is not new (the Council itself acknowledges a 95% decrease in illegal entries). We all know that control of our external borders is not the real problem: this is the result of the Summit. A European approach is lacking, there is a lack of solidarity between the Member States and the Council has regressed: we have regressed to ethically dubious and merely voluntary "solutions". The one that joins the surreal and unconsequenceed announcement of the CDU/CSU business. Instead of a fair distinction between refugees and migrants, we put everything in the same bag and, regrettably, in the same "camps". Member States continue to think of election by election. A la carte solidarity is the real problem that plagues Europe. My question is simple: When will we make funds and Schengen conditional on participation in the common effort of a European asylum area?

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – Yet again, ‘solidarity’ remains a term, most likely to speak about but not practice. I am proud that Malta, the smallest EU country, showed leadership in the Lifeline case and brought together Europe’s most compassionate Members to show solidarity. It is unacceptable, however, that not all EU members want to share responsibility. Moreover, it is ironic that the EU expects ‘rapid and secure’ processing of applications from only a handful of Member States operating on a voluntary basis. When the EU as a whole does not provide an adequate framework for Member States and bona fide NGOs to operate in, it simply means that responsibilities are being ignored. This is not the time for Member States to fight one another but for them to come together, be bold and establish clear rules of engagement.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The European Council highlights the deep crisis in which the EU finds itself. Its conclusions not only do not open perspectives to overcome it, but also contain in themselves – by decisions of militaristic deepening, neoliberal and federalist – new elements of crisis.  "Country-specific recommendations" have been adopted in the framework of the European Semester, pressures are renewed to reduce primary public spending, in particular in the health sector, alongside the increase in expenditure associated with debt payment. The debate on the deepening of EMU – guided by the conclusions of the Franco-German summit – makes it clear that, in the name of a supposed "improvement" of the euro, it seeks to strengthen the procession of constraints and impositions that limit national sovereignty and thus the possibility of the affirmation of sovereign development projects based on social progress.
