It reinforces the militaristic and imperialist character of the EU, NATO's "European pillar", in line with the interests of its main powers – with emphasis on France and Germany. The concept of "fortress Europe" is consolidated, based on an even more selective, inhuman and exploitative vision of migration, supported by measures of a security, militaristic and criminalist nature, which disrespect the rights of migrants and refugees and foster xenophobic and racist sentiments. These conclusions "institutionalize" this view.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – In this age of post-truths and lies, we must speak with truths. First, we are not being invaded by an avalanche of immigrants and refugees. In fact, we're in the lowest figures in recent years. Second, Europe urgently needs migrants because we age, because we need them to pay our pensions and sustain our welfare state. We're not giving a proper answer. We are not managing to slow flows, because flows are born of despair; and we are fueling the most xenophobic and racist debate in the EU.

text: in writing. – In this age of post-truths and lies, we must speak with truths. First, we are not being invaded by an avalanche of immigrants and refugees. In fact, we're in the lowest figures in recent years. Second, Europe urgently needs migrants because we age, because we need them to pay our pensions and sustain our welfare state. Thirdly, the EU needs to give a common answer, and you have Parliament's proposal on the table for months. Fourthly, the Council's conclusions are disappointing, despite the efforts of some governments, such as the Spanish Government, which has put on the table a humane, Europeanist and decent treatment of migrants. And the worst truth of all is that there are some who are willing to change lives by vote because, even if we are in the lowest numbers of immigrants of the last five years, June this year has been the deadliest of all in the Mediterranean. We're not giving a proper answer. We are not managing to slow flows, because flows are born of despair; and we are fueling the most xenophobic and racist debate in the EU.

name: Eva Maydell (PPE)
text: in writing. – Discussing the Council conclusions on migration, we need to acknowledge the facts and the context of the debate: today the number of migrants arriving in the EU is much lower than a few years ago. This is partly due to common European efforts, but mostly to the efforts of EU countries at the external borders. We need to recognise that and use those results as valuable time to prepare a sound common European policy on migration.  The Council conclusions show determination to walk together in the right direction. European citizens expect that from us – 73% of them want to see more EU intervention on migration. With the conclusions, we have the confirmation that the operational tools and resources will be created for that purpose. We need to take care that our actions on migration do not fall victim to populism and continue to be in line with our core values of solidarity. This is the right approach – protecting our external borders and enforcing existing legislation while working closely with the countries of origin outside of the EU and those hosting migrants. The proposals, which came during the meeting of the leaders, were also ideas which the Bulgarian Presidency has backed in the past six months and which I am confident the Austrian Presidency will make progress on.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – At last week's European Council, it was clear that the refugee crisis that peaked in 2015 had now dried up completely. In 2015, 1 million 46 000 illegal immigrants arrived in the European Union, in 2016 the same figure was only 374 000, then in 2017 161 000 people and in the first five months of 2018 a total of 41 000 illegal immigrants arrived in the European Union. This means that as many people are now coming to the Union as they arrived in the years before the crisis.  The refugee crisis has now subsided thanks to a common European solution. Nevertheless, unfortunately, there are still some governments, such as the League, which is a member of the Hungarian, Polish or Italian governing coalitions, which continues to spread its propaganda about the millions of Muslims occupying and populating Europe, unduly inficing fear among Europeans. So the refugee crisis is over, but the political tantrum continues.  Our primary task as we politicians and parties of European values approach the 2019 Elections to the European Parliament is to show the real facts and continue to promote the implementation of European solutions to the refugee crisis.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. – Asylum and migration were once again the main topics of the last European Council. National prime ministers have passionately debated what should be done about refugees and migrants, how to further tighten up asylum policy. They are doing so at a time when the number of refugees has fallen significantly compared to previous years.  Exactly the prime minister who said there is no migration crisis, there is a political crisis. And that is indeed the case. The fact that far-right, populist politicians mislead people in order to gain power and retain power creates fear and hatred – in Italy as well as in Hungary. While not saying a word about inclusion, integration, cooperation. It is a mistake to think that these debates are still about immigration and asylum. Debates have long been about the future of Europe. Orban, Salvini and the others are not interested in refugees, but in how they can transform Europe and the European Union according to their own will. And that is precisely why we cannot and cannot compromise with them.  We must acknowledge that Europe is divided today. But that is why we need to present a clear alternative. We want an open and inclusive Europe that protects liberal democracy, not a Europe based on an alliance of populists. To achieve this, we need political courage and innovation, not cheap compromises.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Writing. We have been waiting far too long for a workable outcome from the EU Council! The blockade of some hardliners must finally be resolved so that we can sit down at the negotiating table. We need a common and sensible solution from the EU Council. Instead of resorting to the decision of the European Parliament, however, the Council is producing little thoughtful demands – which even violate EU and international law! Our proposals, that is to say the proposals of the European Parliament on the reform of the Dublin Regulation, have been on the table since last year. We cannot stress it often enough: we must combat the reasons for fleeing, conclude a pact for the future with Africa, provide legal entry and a pan-European, sensible and, above all, humane solution!

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. – Ahead of the European Council, many Member States' leaders announced their unchanging positions in the resolution of the migration crisis in advance, which was one of the main points of the Council meeting. It was Merkel, Macron, but also the V4 states. On the other hand, we have European citizens who are split between the dilemma of providing humanitarian aid and the natural fear of uncontrolled migratory flows. The summit took place a year before the EP elections, a year before the new Commission was set up and less than a year before Brexit. Therefore, if we do not want to have more exits and more extremists and opponents of a common Europe in the new EP, the leaders of the Member States had to take off their pink glasses and come to an agreement to deal with the migration crisis. They all agreed on the protection of external borders and an effective return policy. I consider this to be of the utmost importance in order to protect Schengen, which is one of the greatest achievements of a common Europe. Another important point at the summit was cooperation with Africa. If we do not help Africa immediately, as a result of poverty, famine, climate change, but also wars and terrorism, millions are at risk of becoming the current hundreds of thousands of migrants, and this would have devastating consequences for Europe. The creation of an EUTF for Africa is a good step, but the EU must take further measures to eradicate poverty in Africa.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: Writing. – I welcome reaching an agreement on migration and maintaining an internal political consensus in the German governing coalition. The success of cooperation between Member States is also shown by the fact that the number of illegal border crossings has decreased by 95% since 2015. We must now focus on stabilising the situation in the immediate vicinity of the European Union.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D)
text: Writing. The Council's results are not genuine. The European Parliament has already made several sensible and balanced proposals to coordinate asylum reform at European level, but the Council is not interested in a solution and is blocking any progress. The Member States must abandon their blockade and clear the way for a pragmatic and human rights-compliant solution. The first decisions are already wobbling again, because each country interprets them as it sees fit. Once again, we see that some Member States are not interested in a European solution, but are only using the issue of refugees for cheap mood-mongering. The victims are people fleeing war and persecution and have died in the Mediterranean in the last few days alone. But the NGOs that save people from drowning in distress from the Mediterranean are now also being targeted. It is cynical to make these people and the work of many NGOs scapegoats now. They are saving the lives that have been put at risk by years of inaction on the part of the Member States. Helping people is not a crime.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. – The migration stems from peoples between regions and continents. Genetic diversity, the fruitful crossing of traditions and cultures, the interpenetration of customs and beliefs are the watermark of the evolution of humanity. The issue of migration in the European Union (EU) has been used by populist forces to implode the humanist and solidarity foundations of the partnership. The perception of the volume and impact of these flows are voluntarily exaggerated and the positive consequences ignored.  The "agreement" reached at the European Council is defensive and insufficient. A different view is needed. Turn the threat into an opportunity for change. A balanced distribution of migrants across different EU countries requires convergent levels of prosperity and opportunities across the Union. Not reducing the focus on convergence policies, in particular the cohesion fund and the common agricultural policy, will make a strong contribution to easier management of migration flows.  Investment in improving the structural conditions of European economies will facilitate the integration of migrants, creating more and better opportunities for resident populations and creating conditions for harnessing the potential that can be drawn from a positive demographic shock.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on: – the report by Mrs Merja Kyllönen, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2006/22/EC as regards enforcement requirements and laying down specific rules on Directive 96/71/EC and Directive 2014/67/EU on the posting of drivers in the road transport sector (COM(2017)0278 - C8-0170/2017 - 2017/0121(COD)) (A8-0206/2018), – the report by Mr Wim van de Camp, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 as regards the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 As regards minimum requirements for daily and weekly driving time, thresholds for daily and weekly rest breaks and periods, and Regulation (EU) No 561/2006. 165/2014, concerning tachograph detection (COM(2017)0277 - C8-0167/2017 - 2017/0122(COD)) (A8-0205/2018), and – the report by Mr Ismail Ertug, on behalf of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, on a proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 laying down detailed rules for the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1782/2003 as regards the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1782/2 This Regulation should therefore be amended accordingly. 1072/2009 with a view to adapting them to developments in the sector (COM(2017)0281 - C8-0169/2017 - 2017/0123(COD)) (A8-0204/2018)

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I am a very pragmatic Finnish MEP who always wants to know and understand how the legislation that we create can work on a daily basis. I have worked for almost 12 years with transport legislation, so I dare to say that I have also got to know what works in this area and what does not. The report is the result of long and intense negotiations in the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN).  The result is a balanced and fair report with enforceable and smart rules and careful consideration of the cross-border nature of international road transport. We did check the other opportunities: we counted salaries, working hours, prices of loads with specialists, and came to the conclusion that without huge bureaucratic burden, it is impossible to add the Posting of Workers Regulation to international transport and transit in a fair game. So there is a real reason why the lex specialis needs to exist. Whatever we decide tomorrow, it will shape the way in which international road transport will be performed within the EU. We either make sensible workable legislation, or create chaos if we choose that. We need to do it with understanding what we are doing, so please consider this. The posting rules are legally and practically inapplicable to drivers who work on a daily, or even hourly, basis in different Member States. Why would we knowingly make legislation that does not work? The TRAN report is the result of intense discussions with relevant stakeholders from both the employees’ and the employers’ sides. The TRAN report respects the highly mobile character of international transport, but imposes posting on cabotage and combined transport from day one to prevent unfair competition on the domestic markets. This is a significant improvement to the situation today. Only international transport and transit is excluded, and there are several good reasons for why they are excluded. But you all need to understand that this doesn’t mean that drivers from countries with lower living standards working in international transport operations are out of social and economic protection. We already have existing legislation such as Rome I: you just need to insert the enforcement in your own Member States. You also need to understand that the general posting of workers was never intended for mobile professions such as drivers, pilots, air crew, train drivers, seafarers and inland waterway workers in international transport.  The absolute majority of transport organisations and companies support TRAN’s, opinion as they all know that it can really work. The TRAN report restricts red tape and safeguards SMEs’ interests, leads to better enforcement and social protection, and respects the very special nature of a highly mobile workforce. We want to end up making legislation that will make it obligatory to apply up to 20 different national legislations a month with up to 50 different minimum wages, depending on the seniority of the driver, the truck, on the goods transported, and so on. This is what applying the posting rules to the drivers of international transport does. It is impossible to apply it in practice, and the transport companies and drivers themselves know it. We would create risk, pushing all the drivers into bogus self-employment, so let’s not do that.

name: Wim van de Camp
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, when you talk about EU transport policy, you are talking about the model of the internal market. As the European Parliament, we want the free movement of goods and people without too much administrative inconvenience. But we also want a social policy and a social policy that at least supports and helps drivers. But as Mrs Kyllönen said, we have a mobile market and the mobile market requires more flexibility.  I would like to reiterate once again that the EPP Group believes that the package proposed by the Transport Committee, in which we have combined the three dossiers (i.e. secondment, cabotage and driving and rest periods) into a balanced balance, that this is a balanced package.  But Chairman, we are not blind. We have, of course, seen the June vote as a defeat and we must move. The EMPL Committee also has a clear understanding of what is going on and what needs to be done here. In my dossier on driving and rest periods, we have adopted a number of amendments from EMPL, which I hope will be able to balance things more and lead to a positive vote tomorrow. I have reduced the reference period from four weeks to two weeks because we want the rest of the drivers to be decent and balanced.  And then, Mr. President, the parking lots. I must honestly tell you that I notice that many people do not understand what is said in my report about those parking spaces. We respect the European Court's ruling: there is normally no rest along motorways in poor parking spaces. You may only spend the rest, including the weekend rest, in good parking spaces that are equipped with all safety and sanitary measures. So it remains an exception to sleep in the parking lots and not the rule. It might be good in these times of fake news to repeat that again. I would particularly like to appeal to my colleagues in the S&D Group, who have supported an earlier compromise on this point and on which I myself have supported and who now seem to be dropping out.  Mr President, a special element is the distinction between freight traffic and passenger transport. People are not containers and containers are not persons. On a number of points, we have made a distinction so that these two flows can function together properly, but also socially. Finally, Mr President, if we cannot reach an agreement tomorrow, the liberalisation of the market will continue unchanged. We are already seeing the necessary transport companies from Ukraine, Belarus and Turkey moving into the European market without any form of social protection, without any form of internal market regulation. And we shouldn't want that.

name: Ismail Ertug
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for the work she has done. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs of the other dossiers and all the shadow rapporteurs, because they know exactly what we have done in recent weeks and months and how difficult it has been to actually reach the compromises in the end. I think that we in this House have to take a decision on how the transport sector will be organised in the next decade. And I also believe that the fate of three million female drivers and mainly drivers is at stake. The question from the outset has been, and still is, that we want a level playing field and, at the same time, should not allow social dumping to become a business model. With one of the cross-cutting achievements of this House, I would like to mention that we will have an earlier introduction of the so-called intelligent tachograph, in our view, from 2022. And we have also managed to agree across dossiers that national electronic registers will be introduced, which will be grouped together at European level by the ERRU. Because one thing is clear, I believe: that the best rules will not help if we cannot implement and control them. As I said, I would like to thank Mrs Merja Kyllönen in a special way on the posting dossier. I believe that the Posting of Workers Directive must benefit all workers, and I do not believe that we should set a precedent here with the area of mobility. Because what's next? Maybe the craft or the care? We must not do that. Therefore, let us take this with us! And when we talk about a compromise, it is precisely this so-called Danish model that is on the tray. And that, I would think, we could all decide with a clear conscience, because it prevents social dumping, is more controllable, there are fewer bureaucratic hurdles and helps companies that do their jobs honestly and pay their people properly. On driving and rest periods, my group and I largely support the Proposal of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. There is no point in extending driving times indefinitely, which has also been prevented by the rapporteur in many areas. We can also say positively that drivers should go home every three weeks. The big problem on European motorways today is that we have models that provide three months of work away from home and allow for a month's holiday at home. In the 21st century, this cannot be the European Union's response to the citizens. That is why I believe that this is the way we should go. The inclusion of so-called light commercial vehicles is also right, because we are increasingly seeing a shift away from the large lorries towards the so-called sprinter classes, which are doing their bit without speedometers, without driving and rest periods, without any control on European motorways. That is why, if I may conclude by mentioning cabotage, we have controlled cabotage, and we have also restricted them where they have led to wild growth. There will continue to be a regulation that will ultimately prevent letterbox companies, and we have also enforced new eligibility criteria for light commercial vehicles. Finally, we must show a clear edge to all the companies whose business model is based on generating benefits through social dumping. Finally, I would like once again to thank my predecessor, our colleague Jens Nilsson, who unfortunately passed away recently.

name: Martina Dlabajová
text: Rapporteur for the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, I have long regretted that the debate on the mobility package has turned into a clear ideological struggle and, unfortunately, even more so in the EMPL Committee than elsewhere. But few realized that it wasn't just drivers and carriers in the game. Populist solutions threaten the FUNDAMENTAL PRINCIPLES of the EU, our common market and our common future. Fraud in the international road transport market will not be prevented by applying the same rules that have been tailored to, say, the construction industry. Not only is this im feasible in practice, but it will also cause enormous damage to the internal market and put transport services at risk. The biggest problems in transport, which relate to cabotage, driver-nomadas, letter-box companies and enforceability of the rules, were caught by the Committee on Transport. There, unlike the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, a solution has been found that ensures sufficient balance. I therefore call on everyone not to support politicking and non-compliance with pre-negotiated agreements.  Will you support a qualified balanced tran proposal or will you support the building of additional barriers? It's up to you.

name: Georges Bach
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. As rapporteur in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I was of the majority who felt that further flexibility was not necessary. In other words, further deregulation and liberalisation of driving and rest periods are not appropriate. We have flexible times, we have enough derogations, and that is why we could leave it at that. That is why I am glad that we, as the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, have the opportunity to come forward with the proposals again. I would also like to thank the coordinator of the TRAN Committee for finding various compromises. With as far as posting is made, I believe that drivers are, of course, part of the functioning internal market and that it is essential that they are recognised as posted workers. In other words, why should they be deprived of the same pay for the same work in the same place? And why should we legalise social dumping in this sector of all places?

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for organising today’s debate about three very important parts of the so-called Mobility Package 1. Let me stress that the social and market aspects of road transport are two sides of the same coin. That is why these legislative proposals have been put forward jointly, and it is why they should continue to be discussed and adopted together. If one of them fails, the interlinked social and market problems will not be solved. In other words, it is truly a ‘package’ approach. First, allow me to say few words on the posting of workers in road transport. Thank you, Ms Kyllönen, for your constant efforts to find solutions on this very sensitive and difficult topic. The sector needs rules on posting which are clear, fair and well adapted to the highly mobile nature of transport activities. In short, we really need this lex specialis. I am glad to see that the report is comprehensive on the enforcement measures of posting. I welcome your ideas on the further use of digital solutions to make compliance and controls easier. As you do, we support a tight list of requirements to ensure legal certainty. I equally welcome your amendments aimed at reinforcing the principle of co-liability for infringements of the posting rules throughout the operational chain. It is more difficult to find a balanced solution on when these posting rules should apply. For the Commission, there is no doubt that cabotage operations should be subject to posting rules from the very first day, and the proposed clarification that transit does not constitute posting is also very welcome. When it comes to the application of posting rules to international service, I want to make it clear that the Commission supports neither full exclusion nor full inclusion. As the Commission sees it, we need to distinguish between international operations that are very occasional and those where drivers spend substantial amounts of time in the host country. Let me now comment briefly on the amendments on driving and rest-time rules and on tachographs – thanking Mr de Camp who had to work on a huge number of amendments. I am glad that Parliament and the Commission seem to share the same ambition of making the social legislation fit to address the needs of workers and companies in the road transport sector. It is crucial to provide for adequate resting conditions for drivers and to ensure they can return home regularly – in the interest not only of better working conditions but also of road safety. In this context, suitable parking and resting infrastructure is essential. Therefore the Commission sees some merits in the rapporteur’s proposal on dedicated parking areas where drivers could spend rest time in a comfortable, safe and secure environment. The work of drivers, operators and enforcers will certainly be facilitated by swifter introduction of smart tachographs. Enforcement authorities would also benefit greatly from real-time access to relevant databases such as the European Register of Road Transport Undertakings (ERRU), and I therefore welcome the amendments introducing those necessary measures. However, there are three issues on which I would call for caution. First, in relation to rest-time rules applicable to passenger transport: allowing bus drivers to delay their daily rest or to take it in shorter parts could jeopardise passenger safety. In addition, such derogations would make controls more complex. Road safety should always remain as first priority. Second, in contrast to the situation with regular weekly rest, spending reduced weekly rests in a vehicle has not been identified as a problem during our public consultation and impact assessments. So we do not see a need to change the existing rules here. Third, on the extension of the scope of the social rules to include light commercial vehicles below 3.5 tonnes, the Commission has proposed the inclusion of such small vehicles within the scope of the rules on access to the profession. It is important to remain proportionate in our approach. Finally, turning to Mr Ertug’s report on access to the profession and access to the market, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his work on many issues addressed in his report. I believe there is a broad consensus, in particular, on stepping up the fight against letterbox companies, with reinforced criteria to determine where hauliers must be legally established; on regulating light commercial vehicles involved in international transport so that those vehicles are not used to circumvent our legislation; and also on accelerating digitalisation, using electronic tools which should become standard in this sector. We generally welcome the solutions proposed on these issues but there are two aspects on which we have some concerns. First, on cabotage, the Commission proposal aims at fighting illegal cabotage and improving the enforcibility of EU rules without changing the existing level of market access. Some amendments, however, are very restrictive and could discourage cabotage – with a negative impact on the efficiency of logistics networks and the environment. They would also make the rules much more complex and difficult to enforce. Second, on the establishment criteria, we fully support obliging hauliers to manage their activity from their Member State of establishment but we disagree with obliging them to conduct loading and unloading with a certain frequency in that same Member State. Such a new obligation could have a negative impact, particularly by increasing empty runs. To conclude, I would like to underline the point that, for this mobility package, time is of the essence – and I mean it! The sector is urgently awaiting clear, enforceable and fair EU rules. It cannot function smoothly in a patchwork of uncoordinated and inefficient national rules, so the status quo is therefore not an option. We are talking about the development of a single market. Let’s not go backwards. I know this sense of urgency is largely shared within this House, and the timetable is intended to have the new rules adopted before your elections. It is, however, possible to find a way forward and I feel that, if we stay at the table and talk and negotiate, we have a chance to move on and to give European citizens and businesses what they need in order to stay competitive and fair, to contribute to climate-change action and, of course, to continue developing their operations.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné
text: drafts member of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, as draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I recognise that the text of the Committee on Transport and Tourism has struck a balance between the different realities existing in the European Union. It is not the same to cross the entire European Union from Spain, Portugal or Poland than to operate from France, Belgium or Germany, where the distances that carriers have to travel are much shorter.  The Directive on the movement of workers applies to cabotage from day one, so the remuneration received will be the same as that of the local worker, so it is not true that the workers are unprotected.  In addition, the obligation to return to the Member State of establishment together with greater and better controls will help to combat long-term cabotage and so-called 'mailbox undertakings', which are the real problem.  Of course it is important to defend workers – that is what we work for – but what we cannot do is use it as a pretext for protectionist purposes. Otherwise, we would go against the single market, the freedom to provide services, free trade and, ultimately, against the values defended by the European Union.

name: Andor Deli
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, we should not be debating as if we had a blank slate, or as if we were at the start of the process. Tomorrow we shall have the final votes. Indeed, we in the Committee on Transport and Tourism have worked very hard and managed to achieve a very good compromise package, which will prevent fragmentation of the transport market and give protection to companies, workers and, last but not least, consumers – and by that I mean the citizens of Europe. We also received a lot of letters in support of the TRAN Committee position from all parts of Europe, from Romania to Denmark and also from Germany, which clearly proves that the TRAN position is valid and balanced. I would call on all colleagues to support the TRAN position tomorrow during the vote. The transport sector is a highly mobile sector. It cannot fit into the regular posting of workers’ regime. We must not play with the  transport companies, as that might be fatal for the competitiveness of the European industry and would jeopardise jobs and core fundamental freedoms of the European internal market. Also, politically speaking, the TRAN Committee position could help to move western and eastern, and northern and southern, parts of Europe closer together, and that is clearly essential at this moment in time. Otherwise I am afraid that we might make the divide even worse.

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, let me first be very glad that we have this discussion and a plenary vote tomorrow. It’s about democracy; it’s not about one committee versus another committee. Second, let me outline why that is so important: it is important for the work of the internal market, but more so for the protection of our people working in that sector. That brings me to the driving and rest time: I think it’s extremely important that we have the two—week reference – and I thank the rapporteur for going along with our Group on that. But also make sure that their weekend rest is outside of the cabin, Mr van de Camp – that is extremely important. Second, on the posting, Ms Kyllönen, we cannot follow your line and leave five million EU workers out of the posting. I think people in this sector are equal people who deserve protection as well.  And last, let me thank Ismail Ertug, who found a very good compromise on the cabotage, and I also thank our former rapporteur, Mr Jens Nilsson, who did a wonderful job on that as well.

name: Kosma Złotowski
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Honourable Commissioner, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. In fact, I could say everything that Mr Delii said, and I will not repeat himself again, because I would now like to draw attention to another aspect of this matter. Social dumping has been used twice here. This is an allegation against eastern European workers that they are using social dumping. What is dumping? Dumping occurs when someone sells goods below the price of its manufacture. With us, in the east of Europe, work is even cheaper, because all other products are cheaper, life is cheaper. Why can't we compete also pay? This is the first question. And the second question. Jean-Claude Juncker said at the beginning of his term of office "the same job, the same wage", but let us reverse that and say 'the same wage for the same work with the same employer', and then let the cashier in Auchan, Paris, earn the same as the one in Bydgoszcz or vice versa. That is, you can take advantage of the pay gap the other way around, and not in that direction? This is a two-way street and I ask the Commissioner to take this into account.

name: Pavel Telička
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I will not speak as shadow to one of the files. I will speak primarily as a coordinator – as someone that was present in the majority of the debates, in a number of the agreements, a number of the deals. This is not the time to put in danger social rights. This is not the time to put at risk businesses, including small businesses. This is not the time to put at risk the internal market, and therefore growth and jobs, but many of the amendments are doing exactly that. I think that we should take that into account. We should provide support to the Committee on Transport (TRAN) arrangements, because this did form a complex solution.  Ms Van Brempt, you have referred to your colleague Mr Ismail Ertug. He will tell you that if it were not for me, we would have never had the agreement on cabotage. But at the same time, we have made it clear that this is linked to posting, so that we don’t establish obstacles to the functioning of the internal market. How do we want to calculate – I mean, in terms of hours – the salary if a truck crosses the border of three countries in five or seven hours? Impossible.  So let’s give it a chance. We’ve got a good deal. We’ve got a compromise. Let’s support it. That’s the only way if we don’t want to endanger social rights, businesses and the internal market.

name: Karima Delli
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, for some time now we have been falling under the fake news, you know, this false information spread on the internet. Some here even relay them. What do they tell us about the social reform of road transport? They tell us, "We are going to protect the employees. How? It's simple: by lengthening their working time and splitting their rest time." Is that what you call "protecting employees"? First fake news. They say better. They want to protect employees by curtailing the few social rights won at European level, such as the detachment of workers. Second fake news. Then they tell us, ''We are going to protect the working conditions of employees'. Do you know how? By making them sleep in their cabins, which is contrary to the opinion of the Court of Justice.  Ladies and gentlemen, if you care so much about rest in the workplace, set an example. Every night you have spent in Brussels or Strasbourg, sleep in your office because we, as MEPs, have benches at our disposal.  The truth is that some would like, above all, to make truck drivers second-class employees. Worse, modern slaves in a European open bar market, without rules or laws. It is not only a danger to millions of road transport workers in Europe, it is dangerous for all of us and all of us, because a tired driver is a public danger on the road that puts lives at risk. Finally, I warn you, ladies and gentlemen, that your approach is politically dangerous, because the response of peoples to the social jungle is anger.  So tomorrow we will have to choose between a Europe that divides or a Europe that protects. Now the ball is in your court.

name: Marie-Pierre Vieu
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, first of all, I would like to welcome the campaign of the trucking unions, which have been alerting us for months about their working conditions, about the hardship, about the operation because 32 degrees on the Weimar motorway in cabins without air conditioning is not social, it is exploitation. This vote is important because it is a question of choosing the model we want for road transport. Either we strengthen the choice of social dumping which is that of the logic of the texts proposed to us and this results in the exclusion of the large majority of truck drivers from the status of seconded workers, to the lengthening of working time, to more precariousness, or we make the choice of progress and then it is to fight against abuses, it is to secure the paths in the face of predatory competition, it is to decide to move towards an ambitious model for European road transport. We want respect for the principle of 'equal work, equal pay', with secondment on the first day, ban on cabin rest and strengthening road controls. I call on everyone to take responsibility and defend the amendments of the Employment Committee as well as those tabled by my group concerning secondment, working time and cabotage.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this mobility package really worries me. I have received a deluge of emails from charities and constituents expressing their concern about the Commission’s proposed definition of travel for non—commercial purposes. The proposed definition would mean that charities such as the Red Cross, Scope and Mencap would be seriously affected. This would mean vulnerable EU citizens left out of society. I am only relieved that this elected House has proposed an adequate amendment to change the unelected Commission proposal.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the mobility package is indicative of the nature of the Brussels institutions, which are hypocritical, blinded by the ideology of the single market and subject above all to the benefit, to the detriment of the workers of the Union. The proud Europeanist elites, sure of the triumph of their consumerist Babel, did not want to wait for the economic and social convergence between countries with advanced economies and those dragging the ball of 45 years of socialism. The result is a struggle between workers in the East and those in the West. Unemployed in the west, slaves in the east: this is the choice imposed by the Union. Yes, slaves, because at 400 euros a month, who here would do the work of these drivers crisscrossing Europe for the benefit of large financial transport groups? Hypocrites, because when the European Commission claims to protect drivers, it degrades their working conditions, even to the detriment of road safety, because when the Commission claims to fight against the abuses of cabotage in Western Europe, akin to entrepreneurial piracy, it proposes to liberalise it over five days. As for the already largely inadequate application of the status of seconded workers, your wish is that it concerns as few workers as possible, as little as possible and, to top it off, with the support of a rapporteur who claims to be radical leftist. Libertarian liberalism tinged with good feelings is poison. Diametrically opposed to these positions, which had been further aggravated by the Transport Committee, our ENL Group proposed amendments to stop the exploitation of drivers in Eastern Europe. We refuse to kill our transport companies and put our drivers out of work by social dumping, not only permitted but encouraged by European rules. And we will support, without partisanship, all the amendments that go in this direction. I believe that the fear of the tidal wave announced in the European elections next May, of those you call populists, will at least have the merit of forcing the elected representatives of the system to defend, for once, the interests of small businesses and... (the President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (NI).
text: Mr President, liberalisation and the Single European Transport Area are a focal point of the single market and the dominance of the respective monopolies in the sector. Dominance and fundraising based on the brutal exploitation of millions of salaried drivers who work literally at risk of life in unacceptable conditions of intensification, under the threat of dismissal, with endless hours at the wheel, long absences from their families, with wages crumbs and without collective agreements, taking civil and criminal responsibility for accidents where they are essentially pushed under pressure from employers for timely delivery or overweight loads. The European Parliament's wish list does not address the situation, but opens windows with exceptions to safety rules, with stamp controls, flexibility in working and rest hours, with loss of labour rights, posting in favour of employers. For all drivers, work equivalent to seven hours, five days, consideration of waiting times and other work as workable, regular satisfactory rest periods at the place of residence, collective agreements with satisfactory wages, with exclusively public transport.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for I think that tomorrow in the vote we will really answer the question of what Kind of Europe we want. Do we want to support the single market? Do we want to promote competitiveness? Do we want to promote the free movement of goods and services? But are we in favour of promoting protectionism, bureaucracy and competitiveness, because, ladies and part of you, when you talk about protecting drivers' rights, you really want to eliminate competitiveness, because you are not on the way to the fact that other companies are better – let us be honest in this House. The proposals that have come out of the Committee on Transport are balanced – they take into account all the comments. We are eliminating abuses and, please, transport companies, transport organisations, not only from Eastern Europe, but also from Western Europe, from all countries they say: accept the proposals and compromise of the Committee on Transport, otherwise we will be burdened with unnecessary bureaucracy. Small and medium-sized enterprises will not cope with this bureaucracy. Consumers will have to pay higher prices for goods and services. Ladies and about! Let us be accountable to consumers, to the electorate, and let us create a law that is transparent, that can be revised, controlled, and let us not come up with rules that will cause many small and medium-sized enterprises to collapse.

name: Agnes Jongerius (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it was in this Chamber that Jean-Claude Juncker announced three and a half years ago that he was committed to a triple A social Europe and many people were in favour. In a social Europe, there are no first- and second-class employees. We therefore do not want drivers in Europe to be declared second-class workers. It is clear in these proposals that transit transport is excluded from the posting rules and we are prepared to discuss the Danish model. So there is room for compromise.  This is not the case when it comes to driving and rest periods, because lorry drivers and bus drivers are also entitled to adequate rest. Being on the road for weeks and having hardly any break is debilitating, it's bad for health and it's bad for safety for everyone on the road. It is for this reason that we have put the EMPL proposals back on the table and I call on you to vote for them.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR).
text: – Mr President, we know that the committees have proportional representation from our political families. That is why the Committee on Transport and Tourism, when we discussed it, we did it very substantially with a mandate of all the political groups. We took into account that there are rich and poor countries, and we took into account the high market areas in Europe and the low market areas in Europe, and we also know that some Member States are tens of – and some are several thousand – kilometres from the high market areas. We did everything with a good understanding on a political level. For example, Merja Kyllönen is on the Left side and I am on the Right side, we have both been Ministers of Transport, and we took a reasonable compromise on all those issues. That is why I ask you to trust the TRAN Committee – we did compromise very well on all three dossiers; nobody is completely 100% happy, but it is a good balance. Please trust us as a committee, because the way the TRAN Committee is working was developed over several years, and it is very cooperative, not seeing what kind of political views we have. At the same time, we would like to keep it as a package, and please don’t separate those issues. Otherwise, we will have a cocktail of protectionism, a fragmentation of the single market in the haulage business, and have argumentation of so-called drivers’ social rights, which is often actually not true. So, please be serious at the vote tomorrow.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, this report and the transport package as a whole are essential to end the fragmentation affecting this sector. We need to clarify and harmonize the application of the rules, end social dumping, improve the working conditions of professionals, contribute to road safety and prepare the sector for changes that come from decarbonisation and intensive application of technology to more efficiently combine modes of transport. From the Directive on the mobility of workers, we have provided these objectives with the exclusion of international transport from the scope and the obligation for cabotage drivers to work from day one under the regulated conditions for the sector in the country in which they perform the service. We've de facto banned mailbox companies. We also want non-compliance with the rules to have an impact on the reputation of companies and their possibilities for market access. We appreciate progress in standardizing procedures, automation and reducing administrative burdens, but we still believe that road transport needs a European agency.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, the European Union is founded on fundamental principles; equal treatment is one of them. In the vote tomorrow, we can show workers from North to South, and from East to West, that this means something to us. They will look to this plenary and ask themselves: will the European Union defend our rights? Not in an abstract way, not when we talk about the pillar of social rights somewhere in Gothenburg, signing a declaration or having a good photo opportunity, but really in a way that will affect their everyday lives and working conditions.  To me it is clear: drivers are not second-class workers in this Union. When it comes to posting, they deserve exactly the same rights as any other workers in the EU. Tomorrow we have the chance to stand up for those rights for hard-working people, for fair pay, and for their working conditions; and we should stand up also for the fundamental principle of the European Union that is equal treatment. In order to build a European internal market, so to speak a European labour market that safeguards freedom of movement and the provision of services as well as fair working conditions and fair competition, we have to find workable solutions based on principles. Equal treatment has to be one of them. Let us show that to workers tomorrow in the vote.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the reality of the road transport sector reflects a reality of brutal exploitation of workers: very high levels of precariousness and very low wages, which denounce illegal practices of payment to the kilometre, tonnage or travel, and heavy working hours to meet the needs of large economic groups.  The right to posting is limited and personal and family isolation is required, in long periods of service, which some proposals aggravate. The fair need for rest is neglected and the high levels of stress and physical and psychological exhaustion to which workers are subjected are ignored. The proposals under discussion are essentially aimed at deepening the mechanisms for exploiting workers, maximising profit and concentrating capital for the benefit of large companies and multinationals in the sector or sectors that depend on road transport, in particular for imports and exports.  On behalf of the single market, they promote the levelling of living and working conditions in Europe by increasing inequalities, exclusion and poverty, options to which, regrettably, the Portuguese Government has joined.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I have told you before: these proposals should not have existed. I believe that any attack on the Court of Justice of the European Union would abolish them without any problem, because these proposals go against fundamental elements of the European Union: the free movement of capital, services, labour. I heard here about social dumping. I believe that your proposal makes protectionism for certain categories. I've heard of second-rate, first-rate drivers. Yes, there will be protected drivers from certain states – first-rate – and "market-protected" drivers from other states – second-rate drivers. There will be price increases, because the beneficiaries will suffer, because those who will no longer have competition, the transport companies, will raise prices. So there will be bureaucracy. A driver will be paid seven to eight salaries if he goes from Portugal to Lithuania and I am very curious if the driver from Germany, when he passes through Romania, will be paid with the salary from Romania. The only reason I support the compromises in TRAN, which are, however, good, is to eliminate the abuses made at this time by some national administrations. So: let's vote on the compromises in the TRAN Commission!

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Mr President, we had achieved and achieved a compromise precisely between the workers of the periphery and the workers of the centre, that is to say that we know that on the road the real problem is not only wages, but prices. And the prices, of course, we do not put them on the periphery: it is the chargers, it is the distributors, the supermarkets, that are in the center, that impose the prices.  To that, for the time being, Commissioner, we do not have a great answer and some of our proposals – and I thank Mrs Kyll-nen for taking it into account – has been rejected.  The commitment we have rightly sought, by all means, to be a compromise between the needs of each other, in favour of the exclusion of transit and bilateral international transport with the return precisely in order to be able to load. But, for the first time – and we all agreed – we accepted the implementation of the Directive on the movement of workers to cabotage from day one, knowing that some of the Member States were going to have a huge cost.  We have also fought for the non-criminalization of drivers, i.e. reducing roadside controls and, on the other hand, doing them in businesses and by the authorities.  We are in favour of the European agency and, of course, for the platform of mutual trust so that there is no discrimination in workers abroad either.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the free movement of goods is one of the fundamental freedoms of the European Union, and europe simply needs international road transport to fulfil it. We must move forward with its liberalisation and modernisation of the rules. It is therefore a great pity that the rapporteurs were not given a mandate at the last plenary.  The compromise approved by the Committee on Transport and Tourism was balanced and, above all, respected the fact that the sector is specific and needs and requires special rules, special legislation. In other words, the general rules on posting of workers should not fully apply to transit and international road transport.

name: Gesine Meissner (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. What is the aim of this package, what is the aim of this package? The aim is to create currently suitable conditions for the transport of goods by truck in Europe. This also applies in part to buses, but I will come to that later. As a reminder, one of the basic rules in the EU is the free movement for people, goods and services – and that is also what this is all about – to fair European rules. Now it is the case: it is also about the shortage occupation of truck driver or driver. We need these people in the future, and they should, of course, be given fair conditions. That is what we want to ensure. By the way, most employers treat their people quite well, but there are black sheep, and we have to deal with that. I am talking specifically about driving and rest periods. For this, we have proposed many good things, such as sleeping in the cabin in certified parking lots, including light commercial vehicles and much more. However, we also need a few exceptions, and I would like to come to this in particular: tachograph ingescroen, for example, for craftsmen only within a radius of 150 km, asphalt must be applied when it is ready, which applies to road construction. Finally, bus drivers are not truck drivers. They need different rules if they are already being dealt with in the same law. Passenger transport is something other than the transport of goods.

name: Keith Taylor (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I believe that Parliament is being sold a pup when it is told that we need new regulations on drivers’ hours and rest periods to give more flexibility. I’m concerned that flexibility is all one way: in favour of the operators and against the drivers’ welfare and road safety, given that driver fatigue plays a major role in traffic accidents and these regulations are possibly extending the reference period for calculating working time. Allowing rest in cabs will mean more stressful time for drivers in and around their vehicles, and more time between weekly rests.  These changes will also allow coach drivers to work continuously for 12 days, which is one of the reasons why I argued successfully for account to be taken of drivers’ – all drivers’ – duty time. In our meeting with drivers from across Europe we heard about the additional tasks that they are expected to do, like route planning, cleaning etc. Now is the time, fellow colleagues, to show who matters most: the professional drivers and the travelling public or the operators. We’ve got a number of amendments with recorded votes, and I ask for your support and for the amendments from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.

name: Rina Ronja Kari (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President! Several weeks in the lorry cab without a proper rest outside the lorry, and a poor wage, which can hardly be lived on, these are some of the most important issues when we deal with the Commission's proposal for a road package. And the answer must be clear: No, it's not working! No, there is no need for worse rules! On the other hand, there is a need for better rights and better rules for drivers. That is also why the trade union movement has tried to call us out. Ladies and gentlemen, we must listen to them. Social dumping on the roads is very much the result of the EU's internal market and unfair competition – and this must be stopped! In the Committee on Employment, we invited drivers and trade unions in. We had a real dialogue with them about what problems they are experiencing out on the roads. That is why the Committee on Employment has tabled such important amendments. We take their problems seriously. Ladies and gentlemen, listen to them! Listen to the drivers! Listen to the unions! Vote yes to amendments!

name: Dieter-Lebrecht Koch (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to thank you most warmly – for recognising the need to deal with these politically sensitive reports in plenary, rather than allowing a controversial committee vote to become the basis for the negotiating mandate. Finally, and only after the rejection of the mandate, the concerns of many of us were taken seriously. There are now real compromise proposals that will improve the TRAN result. This willingness has been completely lacking before. But better late than never. If you also do not want lorry drivers to drive across Europe for low wages and without social security, if you, like me, want social dumping and nomadism to be a thing of the past, if you also want fair and transparent rules of the game not only in football, but above all in the real world, then let us together support these compromises. Above all, they enable small and medium-sized enterprises, honest transport companies, to exist today and tomorrow, under fair conditions of competition, without creating unnecessary administrative burdens. In other words, please vote in favour of a 48-hour restriction of cabotage per Member State with a cooling-off period, the inclusion of international transport in the Posting of Workers Directive after a specific period of time, more efficient controls, the specific situation of the coach industry and the extension of the existing exemptions to driving and rest periods.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. Truck drivers deserve decent working conditions. Truck drivers must not and should not be second-class employees. I have had countless conversations with truck drivers myself in recent weeks, I have been on the road with them, and what do you see? Driving times of 15 hours at a time, with amphetamines piled up to persevere are many of them. Months of sleeping in the truck, and then they are often fed with hourly wages of around three euros. Is that fair, is that fair? No!  sIn a progressive, in a social Europe, I do not expect that. We must not allow this to happen. That is why the Posting of Workers Directive should also apply to lorry drivers from day one, as we voted in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. No loopholes, please. I would like to address those Members of the European People's Party in particular: exceptions of ten days are also inhumane, not decent.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Richard Sulík (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mrs Regner, I would like to thank mrs Regner for her excellent work and for her excellent work. They spoke of travel times of 15 hours at a time, buoyed by amphetamines. But that is already forbidden today! No driver from Eastern Europe is allowed to drive longer than is allowed in Germany or France for 15 hours. What are you talking about, please?

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I cordially invite you to take part in checks in Austria, and I must tell you that one thing is what is prescribed and the other is how it is actually practised. We must not be too naive, we must also design this whole package in such a way that it is implemented realistically, and these violations are unfortunately the rule and not the exception.

name: President. –
text: Indeed, the reality is always more complex.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – Mr President, dear, what you are doing with these proposals is not the protection of workers' social rights, it is not the introduction of any social justice, this is an attempt to steal business. The proposals made are outrageous, illogical and aim for one thing only – to bankrupt entrepreneurs in Eastern Europe, because there are no truck drivers in Western Europe. And that's the reason for these lobbying changes, to try to steal this business. You want to sleep in hotels, hotels will not. You want to sleep in secure parking lots, there are no secure parking lots and insurance does not apply. You want people to come home at three weeks, where are you going to tell someone where to be in three weeks? When we told you that, you said you wanted the trucks to come home in three weeks. Why, dear, do trucks mourn their truck friends to want to go home? You say you're green. What happens when these thousands of trucks move around Europe, burning tons of naphtha, polluting the environment and closing roads. Is that the green? No, that's hypocrisy. These amendments must be voted against because they divide the European Union. You say you want a strong Union, and you divide it in two! Shame.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, one minute to discuss three directives: I think this is an original solution for the problem of interpreters. We should persevere in this direction. With regard to the problem of working time, I think we have a choice, as has been explained, between working conditions and road safety on the one hand, and the market on the other. In fact, everyone agrees on the subject. We will not choose the market against the workers. I would point out, in relation to what I have just heard, that if his conditions and emoluments were so strong, there would be no recruitment crisis and if we have difficulty finding drivers, it is probably because the conditions are harsh and the wages are meagre. I think there is a synergy and compromises on working time and cabotage, but I will still make a point about detachment: if the outright exclusion of detachment is a compromise position, what was the radical position? In these conditions, I am still a little amazed that the tip of the rainbow is presented as the rainbow itself. A little reason would be needed.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Let us say once again what the rules on posting to international transport mean. This is one great legal chaos. This is the introduction of an obligation to apply only one month to up to 20 different national legislation or up to 50 different salaries. Take the example of the route of one driver who passes through 5 Member States during the week and does so 3 times a month. His salary will depend on the number of hours spent in the country, region, land. This means that if he suddenly becomes stuck in Luxembourg, his salary will have to be raised accordingly. And if he has to stay there? How many additional administrative staff will have to calculate salaries in small and medium-sized enterprises on an ongoing basis? What about contracts for a specific amount for a service? What about the prices of imported products? If we want international transport to be delegated, why lex specialis?  To those who think that taking transport by delegation from day two, three or four will make a difference, I say: no, nothing will change. One day equals 6 hours. Can you imagine a transport company in Europe that spends only 12, 18 or 24 hours a month in EU countries due to posting restrictions? Do we want companies outside the European Union to work on other days? They certainly don't want this company from Western Europe as well. For weeks we have been getting calls from a huge number of organizations representing companies from Western Europe: France, Germany, Denmark, the Netherlands, Finland, Portugal, Spain, Ireland, Belgium or the United Kingdom, or from Central and Eastern Europe. They all call for international transport to be excluded from the rules on posting. Let us listen to their voices, let us support the TRAN report.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I am convinced that defending workers' rights means guaranteeing them not only adequate economic conditions but above all satisfactory working and personal living conditions. The work carried out by the TRAN Committee was based precisely on this principle: we have tried to take a step forward in relation to the current situation, which I consider undignified for drivers, who have been forced to rest on the roads for months and in precarious conditions. I also believe, as the EMPL Committee has also said, that it is important to emphasise the substantial difference between the transport of goods and passenger transport: the latter should enjoy greater flexibility, precisely because of its characteristics, especially in the tourism sector. I am convinced that the legislation needs to be changed: the idea of maintaining the status quo cannot be seen as a victory for those who claim to care about the interests of workers. (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Marek Jurek (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. – Do you not consider that respect for the dignity of workers requires, first of all, taking into account their interests, listening to their reasons, taking into account the social context? After all, the differences in competitiveness between our countries, which always have different aspects, are simply part of the reality of Europe as it is. How can this be ignored?

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: answer to a "blue card" question. I did not talk about competitiveness between Member States. I have spoken precisely about workers' rights, and I do not think that workers' rights are sufficiently guaranteed today, nor, I have to say, safety. She said earlier that, by going with the drivers, she realised that there were rules that were not being complied with. So, if we think that this situation is enough for us today, we are unfortunately making a serious mistake and I think that the immediate application of the tachograph can also be useful in overcoming this situation which, I believe, today, not only as a group but as Members, we must consider outdated.

name: Matthijs van Miltenburg (ALDE).
text: Mr President, the mobility package unfortunately reveals new fault lines in Europe, fault lines between Eastern and Western Europe, between countries on the periphery and centrally located countries. But Mr President, is it not precisely the role of this European Parliament to bridge these fault lines? A united Parliament can send a strong signal to a divided Council. Of course, the compromise as worked out in the Transport Committee has imperfections. But the beauty of the compromise is the balance between the internal market and social working conditions for all European drivers. International hauliers and drivers get the appetites of the internal market, but not the administrative burden. We also end the unwanted nomadic existence of drivers and start with a smart tachograph.  Mr President, the title of the mobility package is 'Europe on the move'. Let us move forward by supporting the mandate of the Transport Commission and negotiating. Let's move on.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for outlining the urgency surrounding this EU mobility package. We have three files here from the Committee on Transport and they need to be taken and looked at as a whole package. We can’t pick pieces from one or the other.  As has been said, international transport, by its nature, is international and a highly mobile workers’ posting is not suitable to workers, as has been outlined by many colleagues here working in the transport sector. I think we should, all of us, look at the reasons why and the work that went into it in the Committee in getting to the point of these compromises. They were not easily attained.  We have a debate here between east and west, and peripheral and central Europe. But the single market should allow all Members access to that market, regardless of their geographical placement or regardless of the level of wages that they pay in their country. I’d ask everybody here to look at the compromises that have been won in the Committee on Transport by a significant majority there and vote to support those tomorrow.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D).
text: Mr President! Tomorrow we will take a decision which is of great importance to drivers throughout Europe. In relation to driving/rest periods, we have two options: we can improve working conditions for drivers, or we can choose to make working conditions on the country roads even worse than they are today. For me, the choice is easy, and there are two reasons for this: firstly, we should not put up with drivers living a nomadic existence where they live in their lorry and camp in car parks around Europe in miserable conditions. Of course, when drivers spend the weekend, they don't have to sleep in the truck, they have to go home to the family if they want to. Secondly, we should not accept that drivers are being pressured into working 20 consecutive days with only two days off. We must fight against social dumping and unfair competition. That is why I would recommend to you all that you vote in favour of the amendments tabled by the Committee on Employment. We owe it to the drivers!

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: Mr President, what is this matter about? In essence – Commissioner, you know as well as we do – it is about two things. It is about road safety and it is about tackling social dumping. These two things, of course, go hand in hand.  It is a good thing that we are introducing and accelerating this mandatory smart tachograph on international transport and that we are also doing the same for the vans in order to close the loopholes. On the other hand, it is our duty to put a stop to these social abuses in the transport sector , as Mr Christensen said. Truck drivers also have rights and deserve our full respect for the work they do. They have the right to spend a weekend at home or in a decent hotel instead of in some rough parking lot.  Today, this regulation is already the case in Belgium, including In Germany and other Member States. We really do not want that arrangement to be undermined. A cabin of two meters to two is not the ideal place to spend a weekend. These measures are essential from a social point of view and also from the point of view of road safety.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I have listened here – I must admit – some fairy tales. For example, an employee does not sleep in the office, but at home. Only that the employee does not guard the truck and cargo, and the driver must watch. Go to Calais – in your country, in France – and see if the driver can just go to the hotel. Second point. Someone said that he earns several dozen euros a year. In Poland, drivers earn between 1,400 and 2,000 euros per month. Third point. I understand that it is so nice to say "the same wage for the same work". Well, Commissioner, then, and the same rates. Why in Germany does a German company get 2 euros, a Polish company – 1.60 euros? Please, the same rates per tonlimeter in Germany or France, and we will say 'same job, same pay'. We should support mrs Kyllönen's report and compromises, which has done an excellent job. I thank her for this and congratulate her.

name: Ivica Tolić (PPE).
text: - Dear Chairman, first and foremost I would like to acknowledge the shadow rapporteurs and rapporteurs who worked on the mobility package. I support the compromises reached and I rate them very good taking into account the complexity of the topic.  It is very important that the labour market is properly regulated and that all the rules to be protected in posted workers, including the minimum wage, are recognised, but if the Posted Workers Directive covered transport operations other than cabotage itself, this would call into question the legal certainty of persons wishing to carry out their registered activity. Although the European Union is a community, it is normal for each country to want to protect its territory and preserve the competitiveness of its businesses, however it is not acceptable for this to result in a restriction of the entrepreneurial freedoms of other members. As far as cabotage is concerned, I believe that the current proposal achieves the main purpose, i.e. avoid empty driving while protecting against market distortions of the host country. I invite everyone to accept this mobility package.

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Mr President, the central issue of this mobility package is clear: to combat the continuing deterioration of the disastrous working conditions of millions of truck drivers.  Will we allow truck drivers to spend more than two weeks in their cabs without a normal weekly rest? Will we allow bus drivers to drive 12 consecutive days without a weekly rest? Will we agree to legalise the rest of drivers in their cabins against the very advice of the European Court of Justice? Ask yourself the questions, colleagues. Would you be willing to sleep in your offices after a trying day's work? Would you allow your employees to spend their weekend off in the office?  Truck drivers are angry, and they are right to be angry. They are angry because, seated in their comfortable seats, some MEPs, who have no idea of the hard working time of the truck driver, dare to ask them to take their rest in the cabin and drive two weeks without any normal weekly rest of 45 hours. They are right to come here and fight for their rights. It is the future of their profession that is at stake. Such proposals must be fought hard and we, socialists and democrats, will do everything possible to ensure that measures that improve the rights of all workers are adopted.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Our aim in tomorrow's vote should be to find a balanced compromise that, on the one hand, protects European drivers in road transport and, on the other, continues to make the free movement of goods within the European Union possible. Nor should we be guided by national interests or even protectionist ideas. Excessive restrictions on international transport would make logistics processes slower and more expensive, involve a high level of red tape for companies and ultimately hinder the free movement of goods. There are a number of amendments seeking this compromise, and I hope that they will also be supported tomorrow. However, I would also like to say explicitly that bus transport is bus transport, and lorry transport is lorry transport. I think it is good that we are now trying to separate things. And we should also be careful that where we mean international transport, we also address it and do not suddenly meet the craftsmen. I hope that these exceptions will be supported.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D).
text: – Colleagues, the mobility package raises legitimate questions about the impact on the European transport market. As a legislator, however, it is our responsibility to create legislation that protects the interests of the entire Community bloc, not just the Western states. I believe that the mandate given in the TRAN Commission is not perfect, but it is a legitimate and balanced one, which responds to the realities of the European transport market. The inclusion of international transport, a hypermobile sector, under the Posting of Workers Directive will create administrative and economic burdens that would lead to the bankruptcy of several companies in the east. Hundreds of thousands of jobs will be lost. With regard to cabotage, I believe that reducing its time will lead to market distortion to the advantage of western companies, which is unacceptable. It is essential to respect rest times, but I do not believe that we should impose the location where drivers rest or the obligation to return the truck, which is not a human resource, at three weeks at home. However, I support a European agency for road transport.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
