text: – Mr President, Commissioner, it is no longer even about transport. It is about the fact that, with its vote tomorrow, this Parliament will show where the European Union is headed. Towards fundamental values for which it was created, such as the single market, such as the free movement of persons and goods or otherwise, towards the planting of protectionism and the restriction of free initiative. If we choose the second path and do not follow the agreement reached in the Transport Committee, the message for all people will be clear. Today is international transport, tomorrow can be everything else, Schengen, Eurozone. There is a single market, but only for some Member States, as we decide here. I will not participate in this and will not give my voice to the creation of a new iron curtain. Let's reach out to an entire industry just because the companies in it are registered too much in the East, too far north or on the periphery of the European Union. I call on all colleagues not to make this mistake and to support the exclusion of international drivers from the Posted Workers Directive tomorrow and support what we have achieved in the Committee on Transport.

name: Marita Ulvskog (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Commissioner, I would like to thank the Rapporteur for his We are at a crossroads, should road transport in Europe be exempt from the fair conditions for workers that we operate in other areas? Can drivers of heavy traffic tolerate more than everyone else? Of course not.  We cannot have a Europe where the race downwards with depressed prices, unworthy working environments and dumped wages should be the norm. At the same time, we must, of course, guarantee the safety of both drivers and everyone along the roads. That they are not put before individual companies that want to use people to drive for weeks on end, living in their trucks, without reasonable rest: we cannot have that.  And so would my friend and fellow MEP Jens Nilsson, who died a short time ago, have put it if he had been here: we cannot have that.

name: Anne Sander (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, the European Union has been built on the basis of ongoing cooperation between states, between citizens and between economic actors. But what do we see today? While our unity has never been more necessary to deal with the growing global instability, the divisions within Europe have never been greater. Road transport is a good feature of this situation. For France, more than 30,000 companies, nearly 400,000 jobs, find themselves in unfair competition with foreign carriers, which are themselves European. With these texts on the mobility package, we started from a vision of more liberalisation at a time when we are expected to implement fairer rules. That is why we will oppose any text that does not improve a situation or that would strengthen unfair competition, or that does not allow drivers to work in more decent and equitable conditions.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to make three points in my one minute, so I am going to speak quickly. Firstly, on the procedural question: the cabotage issue was dealt with conclusively in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs (EMPL) and in the Committee on Transport and Tourism (TRAN). There is a real consensus on cabotage. I appeal to Members of this House: do not vandalise what was a good piece of agreement and negotiation as vindication for other elements of this package which you might not agree with. Where we do agree, leave it alone and let the agreement be. Secondly, on the substantive issues: just to note, these are really serious issues – low pay, dangerous lacks of rest time, people working weeks and months away from home. Let us take in good faith that we all here want to solve those issues, and what we differ on perhaps is how to do that and the speed at which we do it because of where we come from.   As I seem to have longer than I thought, I could perhaps make my third point, which is just to say that we have not [...] (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – It is unacceptable in what circumstances drivers work, not always, but very often, so we need clear rules to protect them. However, it is also clear that the transport sector cannot have exactly the same rules as other sectors because of its specificity.  However, we must also be careful with this, of course. Too strict rules would have the exact opposite effect. These drivers could be out of work.  I am particularly concerned that, under the guise of protecting drivers, they would have a sophisticated effect on reducing competition. The fact is that it will be a big mouthful for transport companies from Eastern Europe.  So we have my determined "yes" greater protection of employees and just as determined "no" protectionism. I believe that this compromise that we have on the table, which they have reached in committee, is good and addresses all these concerns.

name: Emilian Pavel (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I want to say that the rapporteurs in the TRAN Committee have done a very good job, and I want to join here my colleague, who said not to vandalise cabotage. I say: let us not vandalise this package from TRAN, which nevertheless covers the priorities of both parties (if we have to talk about two sides)! There is an attempt here to mislead some colleagues by the fact that the TRAN model or the trans compromise would be one that allows these illegal practices, which were being talked about. Completely wrong, dear colleagues. They also say there are low-wage companies that don't protect employees. These companies are exactly from western Europe and practice these methods through subsidiaries in our peripheral countries. Those we need to attack and we need to protect those in SMEs, who are trying to comply with current legislation. Remember, colleagues: we are all in Europe and we do not need additional borders, we need fewer borders.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I very much appreciate the TRAN compromise proposal and call for its support. I consider it to be very balanced, both in terms of the social protection of drivers and also in terms of maintaining the freedom to provide services. This compromise improves the social protection of drivers in many respects, for example, after weekly working hours drivers are entitled to rest outside the cab and will only be able to spend it exceptionally in the cab if the car park is adequately equipped. It's not just about comfort, it's also about road safety. The transparency and enforceability of these new rules should be ensured by speeding up the mandatory use of smart tachographs from 2022. Ladies and gentlemen, the ante-sectoral protection of the posting of workers directive is a fundamental change to prevent the emergence of new administrative barriers. And if we really want to build the freedom to provide services and workers, then we should support this compromise.

name: Richard Sulík (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mrs Regner said earlier that drivers also have to drive for 15 hours. She later admitted that this is already forbidden under today's laws, but in reality it is still happening. But the only point is that the police in the Western countries are not in a position to enforce this driving ban, which already exists today. That is why the arguments are hypocritical that we need new rules, new laws, new directives if we cannot comply with the existing ones. This is not about protecting drivers or protecting workers coming from Eastern Europe to Western Europe. This is about protecting our own markets, and I find that completely incorrect and very hypocritical. If THE Members really want to protect people, they would demand that an industrial worker in Slovakia earn as much at Volkswagen as an industrial worker in Germany who works at Volkswagen. But they don't want that.

name: Jérôme Lavrilleux (PPE).
text: Mr President, I will not surprise my EPP colleagues by pointing out that my inspiration is the Social Paper, the social position of the EPP group, and that is why I will rather follow the results of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and not those of the Committee on Transport and Tourism. I think that Europe must move towards a better—social and not less-so-social—as is unfortunately too often the case. And I think that as a grandson and great-grandson of what was called, at the time, a trucker, I would be in breach of my duty of remembrance to him if I took a different position from the one I am about to take. So I urge, but I know that all my colleagues in the French delegation in the EPP will have the same position, to support the texts from the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and not those from the Committee on Transport and Tourism.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the mobility package shows a Europe with no future, divided and deaf to the demands for fairness and help from thousands of entrepreneurs and workers in the freight sector. The TRAN Committee voted against extending the principle of 'equal pay for the same work' in road cabotage activities to international transport as well, which therefore remains fully subject to the salaries of the country in which the driver is employed, favouring social dumping and unfair competition from companies. The rules on drivers' rest periods, returning home or to another place of their choice, at least once every three weeks, cannot be considered sufficiently stringent. The mobility package, by reducing rest periods, effectively increases the driving times of long-distance lorry and bus drivers and worsens the conditions of transnational posting. The dramatic impact that the package could have on real-life road safety is therefore glaring.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I will repeat again that what we have in hand, with part of the mobility package, is the working conditions of one of the most precarious sectors of the European Union. And we can make them better or worse. This is exactly what we're going to vote for tomorrow. Those who work in this sector do so by charging lower wages every day, away from the principle of "Equal work, equal pay". And what to talk about the rest of your conditions! These workers sleep in the cabins, just two square meters, located above the truck engines that have been circulating for hours. Have you tried to rest in places like this, at absolutely unbearable temperatures? The fatigue suffered by these workers implies a problem of occupational health, but also of road safety. Think about the power and wingspan of a three-axis trailer. All this, safety and working conditions, is not corrected with greater flexibility in driving and rest times. Listen to the workers and their unions. It may seem incredible, but they are experts in the field.

name: Daniela Aiuto (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament has an historic opportunity tomorrow to determine the fate of European road transport. The stakes are, of course, very high: we are talking about the unacceptable conditions in which European hauliers are forced to work, spending their entire lives in a lorry, away from home. Thousands of people forced to eat, sleep and actually live on a vehicle on a continuous journey around Europe, without having the opportunity to plan their own personal lives outside their work. A real modern slavery. I wonder how it is possible for this House to be even divided and not to stand in unison in defence of the profession and against social dumping, as well as against the continuing unfair competition that is forcing more and more companies to close down. Tomorrow this House will have a unique opportunity to restore the dignity of road transport work. Failing that, the memory of this failure will remain etched in the memory of this legislature.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, even though there are few of us here, I want to say this: I am not satisfied with the compromises we have reached at TRAN, but it is the solution that we can now have to go with the whole package. What does it mean to go with one report? It means a disaster and believe me. Let's stop being populists! We all think about workers, but let's think about the long term! What does it mean to bankrupt companies in many states? What does it mean to bankrupt sMEs? Lack of jobs. And what happens to those drivers? They're going to be hired by mailboxes and they're going to be paid as badly as they are now, right? So let's stop being the moralistic wolf! I propose that tomorrow we vote on this package or, if not, we reject it in bulk and start again, Commissioner. We cannot fragment the market, we cannot fail to have competition and competition, we cannot disregard subsidiarity. Wages are subsidiarity. Dumping makes western companies when they hire from the east and sit there and pay on the wages of the east.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank everyone for this very fruitful and very dynamic debate. We have taken very good note of your comments and I would like to react to a few of them.  First, I hope I have already made it very clear that the Commission does not support the exclusion of international services from posting rules entirely. However, these rules have to be applied taking into account the highly mobile nature of the sector and need to be implemented in a proportional manner.  Any extreme proposal would be contrary to the objectives of the EU laws and principles. This is why the Commission proposed introducing a three-day threshold for cumulative presence of drivers in a month. It would allow proper protection of drivers while avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens.  Application of posting crews to international service from the first hour would, on the contrary, create red tape without real benefits for drivers. It would simply be unenforceable. Please keep in mind that thresholds already exist in the Posting Directive for other sectors which are less mobile.  Next, yes, you are right, drivers are not second-class and that is why a balanced approach to the issues on the table is essential – a balanced approach. Neither of the proposals leads to exploitation. On the contrary, they lead to fairness and enforcement that rewards those that want to play the game within the law.  Please keep in mind that we have been focusing our debate today only on the three remaining issues but there are many measures on which there is a broad consensus within this House, but also among Member States and between social partners. Like you, we have been consulting – unions, hauliers, operators, Member States and other associations. We should not forget the large number of improvements for the functioning of the transport market, for drivers’ working conditions, for better enforcement as well as for simplification through four levels of digitalisation.  I respect the very diversified views and different points of view from different stakeholders in this House. But now it is time to come together and find a way forward that will lead to the conclusion of this file. And we can only do that if we really sincerely engage and understand that we cannot stay fixed on our own position and not move.  Whatever the deal is, it must make the rules proportionate, enforceable and transparent. This will help to restore trust and to ensure the smooth functioning of the internal road transport market. What is at stake here is the fairness and the competitiveness of a vital sector of our economy, but also the credibility of our institutions. I hope we have learned from past experience. Inaction can only fuel populism and be destructive. So please bring all your wisdom to the negotiating table, so that we can find a reasonable agreement before the next European elections.  I am very much looking forward to your positive vote tomorrow and a possibility to engage as soon as possible in a trilogue and deliver on these files.

name: Merja Kyllönen
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you for this fruitful discussion. It has been eye opening. I am quite sad that this ‘same salary for the same job’ does not happen in this House, either. Not the same salary for staff, trainees and APAs; not the same salary and equal rest time for translators; not the same taxpaying for each Member State by MEPs, so maybe before the next election this will change. Tomorrow, with TRAN’s solution, we can stop the practice of nomadic drivers in a way that ensures that the driver knows his or her salary beforehand. We can ensure effective enforcement of the posting rules in a way that promotes socially responsible behaviour by all actors in the whole delivery chain. The proper functioning of the internal market needs smart and enforceable common rules. The companies who operate on those markets need to know that they can follow the rules. The workers need the companies to have a job, starting from the driver, transport company, consigner, distributor, consignee, producer and, in the end, even the consumer. We need to know the effects on the whole chain, and actually the legislation which we have built in the Committee on Transport and Tourism is a position which we have checked in this whole chain. We are not just politicians running for the next election, but also responsible legislators, so don’t forget that when you are pushing the button tomorrow. Vote for the TRAN Committee report. It is a balanced solution.

name: Ismail Ertug
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I think everything has been said. It is not necessary to discuss once again all the details and all the contents, but I can tell you that tomorrow is important because we have to solve this issue of nomadic drivers; these kinds of Wild West operations must be solved. Second, no protectionism within the European Union. Third, the level playing field must be ensured and guaranteed. Fourth, we have to prevent this social dumping. All three dossiers, all of them, each of them, will provide this in a good way, but it depends on the details. I think the details are very spread within this Parliament; there are positions from east to west and from north to south, but in the end I think it goes in the right direction when we support the drivers through a good, proper life for the drivers and giving them and guaranteeing them a good social life also.  For the companies too. We have to secure and we have to guarantee that even the companies, the SMEs, must have the chance to live, must have the chance to earn some money, and not just the big hauliers and the big logistics companies. They should not earn all the money, which is the case at the moment. The pressure on the sector is very high and I will try tomorrow with my Group to facilitate that a bit more, but I cannot guarantee that this will be, in the end, the situation or the position which could be the best for all colleagues here in the Parliament. I have to thank the Commission and my colleagues as rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs. Let us vote and see what will come out tomorrow.

name: Președintele. –
text: The debate has been closed. The vote will take place on Wednesday, 4 July 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – On such complex and complex issues as international transport, it is extremely difficult to reach a compromise that not only balances the rights and obligations of each party, but also took into account the differences in working conditions, laws and customs of all Member States. Therefore, when creating this right, common sense must prevail, not the particular interests of only one party. I am of the opinion that such a sensible compromise has been reached in the Committee on Transport. I strongly support the exclusion of the international transport sector from the scope of the Posting of Workers Directive because of the unique, highly mobile nature of these operations. Otherwise, the administrative burden would be enormous, disproportionate to the theoretical advantages allegedly to be applied by the driver. Only good enforcement of existing rules and possible new lex specialis can ensure that transport companies can continue to provide their services in the common market and that drivers' rights to adequate pay, working and rest conditions are enforced.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – The principle of 'equal pay for equal work' should not be allowed to be used as a campaign ploy by Western protectionist politicians to displace more competitive workers temporarily working abroad. Hungarian companies in the haulage sector with a competitive, modernised fleet of vehicles may also face extra costs and additional administrative burdens due to the tightening of driving time, breaks and rest periods requirements. If the driver is not allowed to spend his rest time in the truck cab, but has to stay in a paid accommodation, not only can the demand for comfortable trucks for drivers be dampened, but the logistics industry as a whole can also be prepared for additional costs due to rising accommodation costs and changing operating economy. This is expected to mean further cost increases for other businesses, as well as price increases for customers across Europe.  Meanwhile, according to a credible professional database, there are only 13 guarded and accommodation rest areas in germany's economic and industrial centre that would be suitable for resting under the new rules and for the safekeeping of vehicles, while nearly 13 million high-performance lorries run on EU roads.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. – A smooth and accessible internal market is the foundation of the European economy. As far as transport is concerned, too, efforts must be made towards a single internal market and the freest possible mobility. The mobility package before us aims to reform the EU's rules on road freight transport, for stationed drivers and drivers for rest breaks.  It is important to tackle illegal practices and improve the effectiveness of the implementation of the rules. I regret that many Member States are now trying to build artificial barriers to free movement and a single internal market. It's the wrong way. The transport of goods must be streamlined, the administrative burden reduced and practices clarified. The social rights of drivers must be ensured through better supervision and enhanced cooperation between Member States. Responsibility cannot be passed on to the driver, but belongs to the transport company.  Unfortunately, it has to be said that these directives have taken far too little account of the changes to transport brought about by digitalisation and automation. Automation will have a significant impact on the work of drivers, for example, and rigid regulation of working and rest periods in its current form can create quite a few obstacles to the rational organisation of work and logistics planning in the future. Further work should take a much more innovative approach. It would be important to focus on promoting digital transport ordering systems. The digitalisation of subscription systems promotes access to services throughout the internal market, increases operational transparency and facilitates supervision.  Transport produces a fifth of emissions and traffic volumes are projected to increase significantly in the future. At the same time as emissions have been cut in other sectors, they have only increased in the transport sector. The environmental friendliness and efficiency of the entire transport chain must be substantially increased. Empty or half-empty transports must be avoided in the transport of goods.

name: Președintele. –
text: The next item is the debate on the Statement by the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the migration crisis and the humanitarian situation in Venezuela and at the borders of Venezuela (2018/2770(RSP)).

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice—President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, first of all, let me thank Parliament for its continued monitoring of the situation in Venezuela. The recent visit of the European Parliament delegation to Colombia’s and Brazil’s regions bordering Venezuela raised the visibility of the situation of many thousands of Venezuelans fleeing their country. I saw that situation with my own eyes when I visited Colombia, in particular Cúcuta on the border between Colombia and Venezuela, three months ago. Frankly, what I saw in Cúcuta was dramatic, and heart-breaking because it could so easily have been avoided. But the crisis does not stop there. The number of Venezuelans fleeing to countries in the region is growing rapidly. They are fleeing to Brazil and Colombia, where almost a million Venezuelans have fled over the past two years, and also to Peru, which has received around 400 000 Venezuelans. Venezuelans are also fleeing to Ecuador and the Caribbean countries, including the EU Overseas Countries and Territories. According to the UN High Commission for Refugees (UNHCR), since 2014 more than 2 million Venezuelans have left their country. More than 60% of them are currently in an irregular situation. All countries in the region are showing great solidarity in a challenging situation. We will stand by them to support their hospitality and to help them provide healthcare, education, housing and security for Venezuelan refugees. Unfortunately, there is still no solution in sight to the crisis in Venezuela – this is the hard reality on the ground – a crisis which is first and foremost a political crisis but one which also has serious economic and social consequences. The destabilising effects on the region cannot be ignored. Several international bodies, including the UNHCR, have already made appeals for supplementary assistance. As a consequence, the European Union – all of us – stepped up our support to Venezuelans and their host communities, in order to alleviate their most pressing needs, starting with food and health services. We mobilised our humanitarian and cooperation instruments for an amount of EUR 35 million. Over half of it is being spent to address food security, water, sanitation and hygiene within Venezuela, but there is also support for the socio-economic inclusion of migrants in neighbouring countries and, at the same time, for host communities. EUR 5 million will be allocated to humanitarian aid for health assistance, food, water and protection for the most vulnerable people, mostly inside Venezuela because the situation in Venezuela remains really dramatic. Another EUR 5 million will aim to reduce social tensions and violence and to protect people displaced by the crisis. An additional EUR 7 million can be used for other humanitarian requirements, but we intend to use part of this amount for cooperation on migration issues in other countries in the region. We Europeans feel strongly for the people of Venezuela. We feel their pain and their aspiration to put their country back on track. We are continuing to aim at a peaceful, constitutional and democratic solution to the crisis, ensuring that the rule of law and human rights are upheld. We also expect that Venezuelans will be guaranteed better living conditions so that they do not need to leave their homes. The Council of the European Union called on 28 May for fresh democratic presidential elections – elections that should be free and fair and should respect constitutional rules. Unfortunately, new additional and targeted restrictive measures were adopted last week. Our objective as the European Union is that Venezuelan citizens should have the right to express their political will through a democratic, transparent process, so they can take the future of their country into their own hands. This is the most important democratic right. We believe that regional engagement has an important role to play to facilitate and accompany a negotiated solution to the crisis. I discussed the need for such regional solutions with President Santos in Bogotá during my visit in March. As you also know, High Representative Federica Mogherini personally met with the Foreign Minister, the President of the National Assembly and representatives of the main opposition parties. We will continue, together with our partners, to monitor any development and we will calibrate future actions in the light of the evolution of the situation. This crisis is man-made, there is nothing inevitable about it. A political solution is possible, and so is a better future for all people of Venezuela. It is time for all sides, and particularly the Government of Venezuela, to engage seriously in moving towards a shared solution. This is the only way.

name: Agustín Díaz de Mera García Consuegra
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, the humanitarian crisis is devastating in Cúcuta. Colombia's solidarity response deserves recognition from the Union and the help of the international community. They can't do it alone.  Colombians would never create refugee camps for their Venezuelan brothers. It is a massive displacement of desperate population with four characteristics: return, destination, pendular and transit ⸺on mixed flows⸺.  They have created a registration, a border mobility card and a special permanence permit; are useful administrative emergency instruments for ordering aid.  2 200 kilometers of border and only seven border posts, but cross more than 250 axes. There are still guerrillas and many criminal gangs: extortion and abuse.  More than two million people have left Venezuela: 820,000 are in Colombia. They can't do it alone. Colombians can't do it alone. Everyone claims the humanitarian situation is going to get worse. The Union, Commissioner, has to increase its aid by releasing emergency funds.  We're calling for a humanitarian corridor. We call for an end to human rights violations and the restoration of press freedoms, expression and assembly. We call for free elections again and urgently. And we also want them to derive from them a democratic government that addresses the crisis and undertakes national reconciliation.

name: Francisco Assis
text: on behalf of the S&D Group- Madam President, Commissioner, ladies colleagues, I was in Brazil last week. As you know, one delegation went to Colombia and another to Brazil.  The situation in Brazil does not have the size of the situation in Colombia, the number of refugees or migrants is substantially smaller, but it is still a particularly serious situation, for a very simple reason: the Brazilian state bordering Venezuela is the state of Roraima, is one of the poorest states in Brazil and is a state that is separated from the rest of Brazilian territory by the Amazon ian system. People arriving in Roraima have many difficulties in moving to other regions, to other states of Brazil, or even to other countries, the case of Argentina and Chile, to which some of the Venezuelans wanted to address. Two things I've noticed. First, the deep despair of those people who left their country for the simple reason that fundamental goods, food, medicines and access to medical treatment are scarce, and it was in a state of deep despair that those people decided to leave Venezuela and leave for Brazil, always wanting to return, as soon as possible , to your country of origin. Secondly, the good response of the Brazilian authorities, which, in excellent coordination with the five United Nations agencies operating on the ground, has given an excellent response to the emergency and is now concerned with ensuring what they call the "internalization" of Venezuelans in Brazil, that is, their transfer to other states. I believe that the European Union must continue to be aware of this situation. Today I am talking more about the humanitarian dimension, less, perhaps, of the political issue, although on the political issue I absolutely agree with what has just been said here and which is contained in our recommendation and has been repeatedly taken on by us, but from a humanitarian point of view we must be vigilant and we must provide the greatest possible support to those countries which, at the moment, , are taking in Venezuelan refugees and migrants in terrible conditions.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Thank you very much, Congressman, you are a great knower of this area, our subject is very important, but I ask my fellow Members to take the time.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, the recent report of the UN Human Rights Office described the rule of law as being virtually absent in Venezuela; this is truly shocking. Accounts that the government forces are now responsible for extrajudicial killings, seemingly with impunity, must surely represent a new low, even for the Maduro regime. As inflation reaches 40 000 percent, the economy continues to tumble, with basic food and medical supplies in desperately short supply. Such problems are contributing to a worsening refugee crisis that is seeing ordinary Venezuelans flee to neighbouring countries like Colombia, Peru and Brazil.  I now welcome the Council decision last month to add another 11 names to the sanctions list, bringing the total to 18. This must be widened to include all those directly connected to the Maduro brutal regime in power in the near future. Beyond sanctions, however, it is difficult to see what more could be done to put pressure for fresh peaceful and democratic elections, given President Maduro’s willingness to embrace his new-found status as a global pariah.  We must also be prepared to receive citizens of EU descent coming from Venezuela, as many of them are dual nationals of countries like Portugal, Italy and Spain. So there may well be an influx, even crossing as far as to the European Union. But clearly the situation is becoming intolerable in Venezuela, which is such a rich country.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, those of us who have been on the venezuelan border have been impressed by the human river that crosses it every day. It's a river of suffering. From people who have to leave their country to find food and medicines they no longer find in shops and pharmacies. We've seen it before and it's always terrible, but in Venezuela there's one thing that makes it more outrageous: Venezuelans don't flee their country because of a natural catastrophe or war, as in Syria. Hunger and misery are a political operation of the regime of Nicolas Maduro, who wants a weak, hungry people to control and blackmail. A town without the strength to stand up to him. Ideology, corruption, and incompetence only explain part of the disaster. The main thing is a political decision: not to open a humanitarian channel that could save hundreds of thousands of lives. It is a criminal decision, as the OAS report states, that accuses the Chavista regime of crimes against humanity. Europe must make it easier for Maduro and the rest of the narcorrégimen hierarchies to be held accountable to the Criminal Court in The Hague. The signatory countries of the Rome Statute must activate without dilation the system of international justice that we have endowed ourselves with precisely for this: so that the tyrants may be accountable for their crimes before the world, without subterfuge or escape.

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I must begin by recognising the plight of those leaving Venezuela to find sanctuary and a better life in neighbouring countries. However, although this is the purpose of the resolution, we are deeply disappointed that this resolution has been hijacked by an entirely political project and has become a generalised attack on the Venezuelan Government rather than being about refugees. I have to note that if the Members of this House genuinely cared about the situation for refugees, they would call upon the European Union to play a more active role in welcoming them with dignity, wherever in our territory they might seek sanctuary. Yet we know that 99% out of the more than 10 000 applications for refugee status in Spain have been refused and that boat people arriving in the Netherlands islands of Aruba, Bonaire and Curacao are turned away. In the past, when external forces have attempted to overthrow and undermine legitimate governments, rather than creating more stability as their proponents claim, it has always led to tension, violence and even civil war.  I am not here to defend Maduro’s government, and as Greens we deplore any human rights violations – on all sides – within a country. But the incessant interference from the right-wing alliance is not going to facilitate peace. I am convinced that only a peaceful, constructive dialogue with a genuine democratic process will resolve Venezuela’s current situation, and this must lie in the hands of the Venezuelan people.

name: Javier Couso Permuy
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, umpteenth chapter of the European telenovela Obsesión venezolana.  Let me doubt your supposed humanitarian concern, a concern that never focuses on our miseries or partner governments. It would have been a fantastic idea, a delegation to the Mediterranean, a real humanitarian catastrophe: a hundred dead this week. Or as they were in America, a delegation to the Mexican border to see how the United States confines children in cages. Or closer, in Colombia: a tour of Meta, Amazonas, Chocó..., where, in recent years, there have been dozens of deaths from child malnutrition.  You are not looking for sincere help in solving problems. You are only concerned about the instrumentalization of human rights in a government change agenda, the creation of a humanitarian alarm that serves as an excuse for military intervention, as the head of Southern Command wants.  It must be hard and frustrating to accompany coups, sabotage of the economy, sanctions and even street violence so that, election after election, Venezuela re-asserts its sovereignty in the face of its attempt to re-edit a new colony ministry.  (He refused to have José Inácio Faria ask him a question under the "blue card" procedure.)

name: Ignazio Corrao
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I too was part of the mission on the border between Colombia and Venezuela last week, where we went to see that if there is a lack of food, if basic medicines are lacking, we are talking not about ideological or political positions but about a humanitarian crisis and a humanitarian crisis goes beyond any ideological position. Now, we have had seven resolutions and the result has been a tightening up by the Venezuelan Government and a deterioration in the living conditions of the Venezuelan people. Now, with this resolution, the hope is that we will really be able to open a minimum of dialogue that will at least bring the humanitarian aid that the Venezuelan people need at the moment. That is the wish we have with this resolution.

name: Joëlle Mélin
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, nearly 10% of venezuela's population will have left the country in two years, or nearly 3 million people. The reasons, as has already been said, are a very significant economic crisis accompanied by job losses and unprecedented difficulties in food and medicine supply. The Colombian dual nationals, graduates, but also all types of workers who are exiled to already unsealed border countries, but also to the United States and Europe, thus overloading new already overburdened immigration channels, are the first steps. What a waste at the beginning of the twenty-first century, which will have to be blamed on a process of globalization in general and speculation on raw materials in particular. Especially since some political leaders are pushing to the point of radicalization of overly selective political principles, principles that have already proved their failure.  So this cartoonish situation, which could have been avoided, must make all heads of state, including those of the European Union, think before encouraging again a phenomenon of inept and blind globalisation.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, beyond the serious political, economic and social crisis that Venezuela is experiencing, the Venezuelan people are affected by a serious humanitarian crisis which is affecting their neighbouring countries. The European Parliament wished to show its solidarity with this situation by sending an ad hoc mission which has been driven by the President of the European Parliament himself after the visit, by the way, of the Commissioner, Mr Stylianides, to which I would like to thank him for his sensitivity and his work. But, Madam President, it is important not to confuse the effects with the causes. Clearly, the European Parliament cannot and should not be de-existent from the dramatic situation that is taking place in this crisis, but it must mobilizing all its efforts with regional actors, with the international community, with the United Nations or with the Lima Group to restore democracy in Venezuela, where human rights and fundamental freedoms are seriously broken. And there are not a thousand solutions, Madam President. The only solution is to give the floor back to the Venezuelan people so that, through democratic elections, free and fair, we can, without people who are sanctioned, disabled or imprisoned – as I say – to return the word to the Venezuelan people and try to leave behind this time of suffering that assaults us – as the Commissioner said and as the colleagues who have been in Brazil and Colombia said – and these years of lack of freedom.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: – Madam President, many will wonder how it is possible that one of the richest countries on Earth has produced two million migrants. It's an unresponsive question believing that this is a mystery, no.  Unfortunately, ladies and gentlemen, this is the consequence of a failed, failed revolution, and it is also the consequence of a political crisis that requires a political solution.  There are three issues of the motion for a resolution which we are going to put to the vote which I would like to highlight.  The first is the one that has to do with the Member States, because the motion for a resolution calls, as our group requested, for Member States to regularize Venezuelans migrated to our countries. There are thousands in Spain, and I have addressed the Spanish Government directly to ask it to regularize this situation. The same is being asked for the rest of the Member States.  Secondly, I would like to stress the importance of us also following Peru. Commissioner, Peru, as you said, has 400,000 Venezuelans probably - less than one million that Colombia has - but it also requires help that we should extend.  And thirdly, let me stress the importance of the call for dialogue and for Mrs Mogherini and the European Union to play an important role in favour of international mediation, because I share with you that the people must be given back by means of a political agreement between government and opposition.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Dear! In our resolution, we focus on the humanitarian and migration aspects. Rightly so, because the situation in Venezuela is terrible and hyperinflation prevents people from purchasing basic food and medicine. My country, Poland, I say this on behalf of the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists, has also been in a dramatic economic and political situation. In the 1980s, one and a half million people Polish to emigrate. The solution in this situation turned out to be a peaceful transfer of power by the current regime and international support for political and economic reforms. Perhaps it is worth it for Venezuela to think about this peaceful transfer of power to those people who are protesting on the streets of Venezuelan cities today.

name: Javier Nart (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, thank you, Mr Stylianides, for your sensitivity. There is a country in the world where 90% of the population lives, rather, evil, in poverty; where 30% of childhood motherhood means the growth of their mortality and 60% maternal mortality; where measles, tuberculosis and malaria are endemic diseases; where there are no medicines and veterinary medicines for animals have to be consumed because the desupply is absolute and there is hunger; where inflation is 130 000%, at the rate of one and a half per hour, and where corruption is rampant: it is the country 169 out of 180. This country is not called Somalia, nor Congo. It's a country that has massive oil wealth. It's Venezuela. And it is the consequence of corruption, of inefficiency, of repression, of chavomadurist liberticide. And these are the facts, not the ideology. And this has been created by incompetence and chavomadurist corruption, not international conspiracy. I, for that country, claim the same thing I ask for ourselves and what we all claim for ourselves: freedom and democracy, which for some is subversive. And I'm ashamed of them.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the difficult political, social and economic crisis that Venezuela is experiencing is now joining an unprecedented migration crisis, which has shaken the regional balance, separated families, brought the institutionalisation of many children whose parents immigrated and triggered asylum applications.  According to the recent UNHCR report, in 2017, Venezuela ranked fourth on the world's list of asylum applications, only surpassed by Iraq, Afghanistan and Syria, i.e. countries that have been the scene of wars, suffered military interventions and where violent extremist groups operate. Forced migration is, unfortunately, a situation that persists, which worries us about the harmful effects it will bring to Venezuela. All because of the ditity of a regime that insists on trampling on the most basic democratic rules and respect for human rights, and to which I call for dialogue with the opposition. In fact, the recent presidential elections, which took place in the circumstances in which we all know, were marked by the highest abstention rate in decades.  A word for the Commission, the Council and the UN, close monitoring, sanctions and the sending of humanitarian and financial support to Venezuela and neighbouring countries.  Governments and the administration of migrant-taking countries, notably Brazil and Colombia, also for their notorious efforts to help the large hundreds of people who arrive at their borders every day and justify cash support to these neighbouring countries.  I end by congratulating this Parliament on its role in denouncing these situations, in the search for facts and in the possible support for migrants, the latest example being the visit to the borders of Brazil and Colombia promoted by President Tajani.  I also send a word of solidarity to the strong expatriate migrant community of European citizens living and working in Venezuela, including the significant Portuguese community.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the humanitarian catastrophe shows Venezuela on its way to the failed state. A band of thieves linked to drug trafficking is saothing about natural wealth, with the unbelievable cost of thousands killed in 2018, already due to hunger and lack of medicines.  50,000 Venezuelans flee a day, dramatically affecting neighboring countries. It is not enough for the Union to condemn electoral farce and impose targeted sanctions. It must help dismantle the barking that brings together opposition and regime figures and to engage in the empowerment of social activists, student leaders, new forces in politics and the media that take on and promote the necessary changes. This implies strategy and resources. It is not with small humanitarian programmes administered from Brazil that the European Union will make a difference. The European Parliament cannot wait for good offices from others. It is time for us to send missions from political groups, foundations, NGOs and other entities and to support training programs to help give prominence and strength to Venezuelans who can lead the change and stop the catastrophe. In Portugal, we see our returnees from Venezuela arriving in despair. It's time to work with them for change. Let's not stop hot as to the Maduro regime, which falls from rotten.

name: Mirosław Piotrowski (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are seeing a dramatic situation in Venezuela, which the authorities describe as socialist. The country lacks food, water, medicine, children are starving. These are the results of the rule of President Maduro, who, on the basis of the military, introduces socialist experiments.  Venezuelan citizens are fleeing the country en masse, going to Colombia, Brazil, Ecuador. These are hundreds of thousands of people who just want to save their own lives and their families. Nearly two million people are expected to emigrate even further.  The question is: how could the European Union help? Humanitarian aid must be rushed. He spoke of this assistance, measurable, Commissioner. I would like to join the ppe representative's call for it to be increased. It is necessary to decide quickly what measures we can immediately activate directly or through, for example, Caritas, whose assistance is accepted by the Venezuelan authorities.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the situation in Venezuela is intolerable. It is a tragedy to see how what was once a refuge from those fleeing repression is now a country from which thousands of people flee. But even more tragic is to think that the crisis could have been completely avoided. Maduro hasn't done anything to fix or relieve her.  We can't wait for Maduro to do something while people keep suffering. The European Union must already take action to address the humanitarian crisis, but this in itself will not solve the crisis in the long term. There has to be an end to dictatorship and a return to democracy. I ask the Council again to expand the list of sanctions and to extend it to its families and I ask you to start exploring additional measures as an oil embargo.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: – (The speaker starts the intervention with the microphone off)... to North Korea, which is counting on millions of victims, Venezuela is only the latest example of what happens every time communism comes to power. It's always like this, it's always been like this.  As we debate, we learn that polio, a tragic disease eradicated decades ago in the country, for which there are vaccines, has arisen in Venezuela. More than two million Venezuelans have left the country. The press, once free, was extinguished or nationalized. Persons who contest the regime are murdered or arrested for an offence of opinion. There's no food and medicine's missing. Caracas is already the most dangerous city in the world. The country isolates itself and in the stertor, among electoral simulacrums, Nicolás Maduro threatens, saying he is willing to take up arms and make another revolution, if the power changes, by vote, hands.  To that extent, it is the Communists who here defend this regime in the European Parliament who are most responsible for this tragedy in relation to a people who only commit the sin of wanting to be free. We have no doubt: we are on the side of democracy, on the side of freedom, on the side of decency.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the very serious crisis in Venezuela, not only political but also economic, social and humanitarian, is causing a major exodus from the population, as food and even medicines are scarce. It's not a soap opera, as our colleague said, it's a horror and misery documentary. Nearly one million Venezuelans have had to move to neighboring Colombia, whose border areas are in a very difficult situation. Other nearby countries, and even Spain, are receiving fleeing Venezuelans. It seems to me that the aid of the thirty-five million euros is insufficient, Commissioner. It seems to me that, on the occasion of the very next EU-CELAC ministerial meeting, and also in the meeting with the Pacific Alliance countries, this humanitarian crisis should be addressed and the most effective aid for the fleeing to Colombia and other States and also, in general, for Venezuelan citizenship remaining in the country be analysed. It is necessary – as Agustín Díaz de Mera said – to open a humanitarian corridor that Caracas continues to hinder. On the other hand, the European Union, and it has to take advantage of the summit with CELAC to do so, must leverage its contacts with Latin American countries in order, together, to put firm pressure on the Venezuelan authorities. It is a question of ending an authoritarian political line and allowing for a free presidential election.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this long-running, multi-dimensional crisis continues to deteriorate and there is no solution in sight. People are now voting with their feet and prices are increasing at, it was mentioned, 1.5% an hour. All this boils down to absolutely abnormal political and social conditions and as the Commissioner pointed out, this is a man-made crisis, after all. Venezuela’s experience proves that normal economic and social conditions are unavoidably linked to the free exercise of civil rights and the rule of law.  There is absolute urgency now to allow humanitarian aid to the countryside unimpeded and it is a shame that the government that has provoked this crisis is now not allowing aid from outside to reach the victims. Swift adoption of additional targeted sanctions against those responsible for the violation of democratic rights is needed and, finally, new presidential elections which comply with basic democratic standards are needed. Only democratic decision-making by the people fully exercising their freedom can lead Venezuela out of this quagmire.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, two million people displaced in 2018, an increase of 2000% in the number of asylum seekers since 2014, the emergence of diseases such as malaria, diphtheria, measles, and even polio, mothers walking miles with their children to cross the border and to be able to vaccinate them and solidarity of the Colombian people. That is what we have found in Cúcuta, border with Venezuela, where Caritas feeds more than eight thousand people a day. Today I do not want to consider how one of the richest countries in Latin America has come to this situation without a war or objective causes that justify it. Today I would like to address colleagues who have not been able or have not wanted to join us, something I feel deeply, as I would have allowed them to know the reality. I address those who have the most ties to the Venezuelan government. Stop closing your eyes and please help enable a humanitarian corridor to send medicines and food. The people of Venezuela need it.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I had a written speech here, but I have changed it appreciably and I would also like to greet the Commissioner.  Commissioner, last week I was also part of the delegation of this House to Colombia, more precisely the city of Cúcuta, and, colleagues, what I saw there was literally heart-cutting. I saw an entire people hungry, with diseases, persecuted, crossing that border, bringing with them and as only belongings the clothes they carried on their bodies. I saw people with an empty look, without expression, without any hope for their future. Commissioner, I want to thank you, I know the work you have, what you and the high representative have done to help that martyred people, in which citizens of my country, of Portugal, are found, and, as has already been said here, this is not a crisis that originates in any natural calamity, as a result of war or ethnic conflict, but rather a socio-economic disaster of gigantic proportions , created by a dictatorial, repressive and criminal regime. I will end, Madam President, by appealing to the Commissioner and the entire international community to grant refugee status to the Venezuelan people, as requested by the UNHCR. I also ask that, at the appropriate time, Mr Maduro and his sequazes be tried at the International Criminal Court for what are in fact crimes of humanity.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the deep humanitarian, economic and political crisis in which Venezuela finds itself deeply saddens me. It is painful to see that a country that possesses so many resources is now faced with a massive exodus because of the lack of access to basic humanitarian needs. Border communities in Colombia and Brazil are putting all their efforts into hosting Venezuelan refugees fleeing the lack of access to food and medicine. It is of the utmost importance that the European Union, us, support these communities financially and otherwise.  We should also take a leading role in facilitating dialogue in Venezuela. I fully support the Council’s call to rerun the recent elections that took place in such a grim political climate and in violation of the conditions for fair and free elections. Venezuelans want to live in a democratic country in which every voice can be heard and the European Union should be their partner.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, everything goes to create the conditions justifying an intervention in Venezuela. The narrative to seek and invent a humanitarian crisis, now a migration crisis, knows no bounds. The first is belied by UN reports, the second is Eurostat's own data that belie it with negligible levels of approvals of asylum applications in the European Union.  No one denies the venezuelan authorities the serious economic crisis the country is experiencing, its social impacts and the increase in migration flows as a result of sanctions, economic boycott scares or support for internal destabilization and resulting violence.  Between 2011 and 2017, three quarters of a million immigrants, 309,000 permanent, as a result of your troika and austerity policies. In common, we find policies sanctioned by the European Union, of an interventionist nature, that promote poverty, inequalities, that pay attention to the sovereignty of states and that do not serve the interests of the peoples, in particular the interests of the Portuguese community in Venezuela, so little of the Portuguese people. (El orador se niega a que José Inácio Faria le formule una pregunta con arreglo al procedimiento de la "tarjeta azul").

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission, on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to thank our colleagues for their interventions. I think all of us saw that the vast majority of Members of this Parliament share the same concerns, the same assessment, about the political crisis and humanitarian crisis in Venezuela.  As I said in my first intervention, I saw the situation, I assessed the situation on the ground when I visited Cucuta and other areas in Colombia. I know well from the great deal of information from our partners on the ground that they are trying behind the scenes to provide the children in Venezuela with medicines and vaccines.  I can promise you, as Commissioner responsible for humanitarian aid, that we will continue to provide, regardless of any obstacles and barriers, humanitarian assistance, specifically medicines, in Venezuela to prevent any medical problems for the children of Venezuela. This is my personal promise. We will, of course, continue to use all our instruments and means to accompany the country towards a peaceful, negotiated solution. It is a difficult journey but it is the only way that can foster a peaceful, democratic and lasting solution for the country.  We will also continue to reinforce our support to the population in order to alleviate their most pressing needs and provide assistance to neighbouring countries which have to cope with increasing numbers of Venezuelans fleeing their country.  May I close by signalling once again our appreciation of this Parliament’s role in keeping this urgent issue on the European and international agenda.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Motions for resolutions to be tabled pursuant to Article 123(2) of the Rules of Procedure shall be published at a later date. The debate is over. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. The protracted political, social and economic crisis in Venezuela has led to the largest mass migration in Latin American history since the discovery of the continent. According to recent estimates, around two million Venezuelans have left the country to escape food and drug shortages, unemployment, rampant crime and the repression of an increasingly authoritarian government. The scale of the phenomenon is such as to produce destabilising effects and strong social tensions even in neighbouring countries; I am thinking in particular of Colombia, but also of Brazil, Guyana and Ecuador. In the face of this unprecedented humanitarian crisis, it is essential that the European Union intervenes through the allocation of additional aid to support neighbouring nations in dealing with the enormous humanitarian effort necessary to ensure the reception of all refugees. However, in order to tackle the roots of the phenomenon, it will be necessary for the European Union to step up its international mediation effort with the Venezuelan Government in order to put an end to the violation of human rights and to restore democracy, an essential prerequisite for halting the escalation of the crisis and for accessing new presidential elections respectful of the principles enshrined in the Venezuelan Constitutional Charter and internationally recognized.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The following item is the Statements of the Council and the Commission: Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo. (2018/2742(RSP)).

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, let me thank you for your invitation to participate in this debate on this important topic today. When a new outbreak of the Ebola virus disease was declared in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) on 8 May, the international community was immediately alarmed. The memories of the long struggle to contain the virus in West Africa between 2014 and 2016 are still vivid in our minds. Around 11 000 people fell victim to the disease in three African countries, and the virus also spread to the United States and to Europe. This time round, it seems the lessons have been learned. The international response was fast, determined and comprehensive. The World Health Organization (WTO) reacted quickly, ensured leadership and coordination, asked for sufficient amounts of funding and initiated a wide range of measures, from medical and psychological care, to awareness raising and prevention. Donors stepped in early, making sure that the USD 57 million Ebola strategic response plan for the DRC was fully funded. We commend the Commission for releasing EUR 3.43 million in emergency assistance for response to this crisis on behalf of the European Union. We also welcome the fact that the WHO requested the activation of the Union’s civil protection mechanism and we welcome the fact that in 2016 the European Medical Corps was established to strengthen the EU’s capacity to respond to disease outbreaks and health emergencies, both inside and outside the European Union.  Sadly, 29 people have died as a result of the Ebola virus disease in the DRC. We can be cautiously optimistic that the spread of the disease has now been halted. The last new case was confirmed almost a month ago at the beginning of June. I’m particularly relieved that the disease did not spread beyond the three DRC provinces initially affected. It was crucial that the virus could be contained in Mbandaka, a port city of around one million people. But we have to remain on our guard before declaring the end of the outbreak. No new cases must be confirmed during 42 days, twice the Ebola incubation period, counting from the day the last case was confirmed.  So let us hope that the end of July will see a positive outcome. Even so, there will be no time for complacency. Many things worked well this time, such as ring vaccination of more than 3 000 people, which was not available three years ago. But we may be able to do even better. We welcome the fact that the World Health Organization will launch a review shortly, after the end of the outbreak has, hopefully, been declared. One thing is already clear: we must invest more in strengthening resilience in the DRC to respond to future outbreaks of the virus. The country’s health system is ill prepared to cope with challenges of this scale. In that context, we highly appreciate the European Parliament’s October 2015 resolution on the long-term lessons from the previous Ebola crisis and how to strengthen health systems in developing countries to prevent future crises. We must not forget that the DRC is also facing one of the world’s most complex and long-standing humanitarian crises. Some 13.1 million people in the country are in need of humanitarian assistance; 4.5 million Congolese have been initially displaced and 7.7 million people, or 11% of the population, are food insecure. The European Union and its Member States are at the forefront of the response to these needs, but more must be done. The Presidency will monitor developments in the DRC closely. We will put the humanitarian situation, as well as the Ebola outbreak, back on the agenda again if necessary to enable the Member States and the Commission closely to coordinate their response. Neither Africa nor Europe, nor indeed the world, can afford another Ebola epidemic.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to welcome the Austrian Presidency and to thank the Minister for her comments about this demanding field of the Ebola outbreak, and for her kind words about our engagement in tackling it. From the very beginning, the European Union has mobilised its resources to assist the international response to the new Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo. We have taken urgent action to help manage and contain the spread of the virus. Personally, as EU Ebola Coordinator, I have been monitoring the situation closely from day one, in direct contact and coordination with the new Director of the World Health Organisation (WHO), Dr Tedros Gebreyesus (that’s a difficult Ethiopian surname!). Eight weeks later, the WHO has stated that the Ebola outbreak has been ‘largely contained’ and that it sees the situation with ‘cautious optimism’. We won this fight because this time we were ready. We had developed our ‘weapons’. EU-funded research against Ebola has continued. We co-funded vaccines and diagnostics that were quickly deployed in the field at times when Ebola was not making the headlines. Because the truth is that we learned our lessons from the Ebola outbreak in 2014 in West Africa. I saw with my own eyes in November 2014 the situation in Sierra Leone, in Guinea and in Liberia and I can compare the situation at that time with the new outbreak in Congo. We should always be prepared for the worst. We should never be complacent – I completely agree with you on that, Minister, and I assure you there is no complacency when Ebola breaks out. The recent outbreak has not turned into an enormous epidemic because of the immediate, coordinated and efficient international intervention. It was a rapid and robust response. Our team in the Emergency Response Coordination Centre (ERCC) is following developments 24/7. Since the start of the outbreak, we have been working closely with the WHO, the Congolese authorities and our international partners. Our efforts focused initially on helping to get medical teams, equipment and supplies to the affected zones. In addition, we have supported the coordination of the response and the distribution of necessary information for the local communities. That is a very important activity. At the same time, all available EU emergency response instruments have been mobilised. Firstly, as the Minister already said, the Commission has provided EUR 3.5 million in humanitarian aid, primarily to the WHO, the Red Cross, the International Organization for Migration and UNICEF, and we have focused on coordination and logistical support for the Ebola response. Secondly, our assistance supports primarily life-saving intervention, including with our own European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations department humanitarian air service, ECHO Flight; infection prevention and control; water, sanitation and hygiene measures; behaviour advocacy; and, of course, safe burials. We know from the previous outbreak that burials are one of the most influential factors in the spread of the virus. We also support the surveillance of exit and entry points of Ebola-affected areas. This is another key measure to avoid the spread of the virus. Thirdly, the European Union also provides, in kind, logistical support through ECHO Flight, which regularly transports personnel, supplies and equipment from Kinshasa to the affected areas. Fourthly, our European Union Civil Protection Mechanism (UCPM) has come into play. The World Health Organization made a request for assistance, requesting emergency medical teams. Norway, through our mechanism, offered isolation transport shuttles to bring patients safely to treatment centres, medical personnel were deployed, and the Commission covers 85% of the transport costs. Fifthly, in terms of field expertise and deployments, the Commission’s regional humanitarian office in Kinshasa is fully mobilised. Extra staff have been deployed, including medical specialists and logisticians. More staff remain on standby.  Sixth is monitoring and coordination. The Emergency Response Coordination Centre is coordinating with Member States and other Commission and EU services and agencies, such as the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control, the humanitarian field office in Kinshasa and international partners.  The seventh aspect is satellite mapping. Copernicus is a well known, excellent and sophisticated mapping system. Copernicus Emergency Management Service has provided satellite maps of affected areas in order to support field deployments. I will continue to follow the situation on the ground closely. We will also look into lessons learned from this experience. So far, fortunately, because of our coordinated action, we have avoided the worst-case scenario. At the same time, we stand ready to provide any further assistance if needed. Our actions are a clear demonstration of EU solidarity with the people of the Democratic Republic of Congo. We will continue to stand by the Congolese people until this Ebola outbreak is over. In conclusion, once again I have to say that there is no complacency when Ebola breaks out.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, let me start by applauding the swift reaction of international players, including the European Union, to this outbreak. This is the ninth epidemic in the Democratic Republic of the Congo in the past four decades. I am glad to see there has been significant progress since the last one, in May 2017, and that the recommendations from Parliament’s last resolution on Ebola were taken into consideration. The number of potentially infected persons requiring follow-up has gradually decreased and by the end of June all of them had ceased to need mandatory monitoring. Nevertheless, because of the disease’s serious nature and the complexity of the geographical area in which it occurs, and therefore the lack of complete data, the risk to public health, both at national and regional level, remains high. For this reason the EU should continue to provide assistance through infection prevention control and support for health centres, as well as entry/exit point monitoring for the affected areas. The EU has also funded the largest research effort on the vaccine against Ebola and this is an initiative worth scaling up. From the regional perspective, it is important that the countries exposed to the possibility of an outbreak should take action on Ebola readiness and have emergency response plans in place, and that cooperation in this very important area be enhanced.

name: Maria Arena
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Madam President, since 1976, the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has experienced various Ebola attacks, which have been more or less managed with peaks of contamination in the 1970s, but much less today. A total of 1,000 deaths have been reported during the various waves of contamination in 40 years. On 17 May, following the case in Mbandaka, a city of one million people, the alert was issued again, and the World Health Organization (WHO) responded directly by launching an experimental vaccination campaign on high-risk populations, as well as information and isolation campaigns. Today, WHO and the government in the DRC recognize that the epidemic is contained.  On this basis, I have asked to extend our debate this evening to the general situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo. While the Ebola virus, since 1976, has killed a thousand Congolese, the war in that country since 1994 has killed more than six million Congolese, displaced thousands of them who still live in camps, maimed and raped young girls.  While the DRC is capable of stopping Ebola, it clearly does not have the will or capacity to protect its populations. That is why I have called for a broader discussion on the situation in this country on the eve of an electoral process and where everything leads us to believe that the disorder is organized by the government.  I refer to the speech by Mr Mugwebe, the Sakharov Prize of this House, for whom the elections will not be credible. According to him, the Congolese people still live in modern slavery, a government of the belly and blood that has no plans or visions.  Living, working, eating and being free are rights in a country as rich as the DRC. Yet massacres, rapes, massive destruction of habitats is the daily lot of this population.  All the institutions in the DRC today are illegitimate, whether it is the provincial assembly, the national assembly, the Senate, the presidency, and that does not seem to move anyone - even here in this assembly - because they will have to hold the so-called independent elections.  So, yes, we are concerned about Ebola, but I would say that the general situation in Congo should be of greater concern to us.

name: Charles Tannock
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, last week, barely two months after it had begun, the WHO described, to our great relief, that the Congo’s latest Ebola epidemic is largely contained. The rapid eradication of this bout of Ebola is indeed remarkable. The Congolese authorities and the international health community deserve much praise for their impressive move to contain the outbreak, leaving it far from the international health disaster that was seen back in 2013 as the West Africa Ebola crisis. While I applaud the success of the response, I am also aware of concerns that Kinshasa—imposed emergency measures implemented to contain the viral epidemic might be misused to further restrict the rights and freedoms of the Congolese people, in what can already only be described as a generally very repressive political environment. Looking ahead, I therefore urge the Congolese authorities to remain responsible and transparent in their use of emergency public—health measures responding to the outbreak. It would indeed be a great shame if such a fast and remarkable crisis response were abused by the government’s use of emergency powers ahead of democratic elections.

name: Charles Goerens
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, I think we are all going to say pretty much the same thing about the Ebola crisis. Even if it is redundant, it must be said. I believe that we must put to the fore of this Assembly for having alerted in time, in 2014, the authorities of WHO, the Commission and our Member States on the need to intervene quickly. That has been done. We have learned from that. If at the time we were slow to do so, today we reacted in time. If an event is not mentioned in the 8 p.m. news, that does not mean that we were ineffective, on the contrary. The fact that this epidemic is not the scale of that experienced in Sierra Leone, Liberia and Guinea four years ago is the result of our effort. So let's be proud of what we've been able to accomplish and address the underlying causes. The direct causes have been addressed, the underlying causes are those of extreme poverty. I fully agree with what Mrs Arena said, I believe that the situation in Congo as she has just described it is very relevant, and we will have to have a specific discussion on this subject in another debate. Let us also thank the Commission for doing everything in its way to keeping this epidemic within bounds. Thank you to the Commissioner who is tackling these causes, and I will also ask his colleague Mr Mimica to do everything possible to address the underlying causes of this epidemic. Thus, health infrastructure needs to be improved, not only in Congo, but wherever it has not yet been the case because, we remember, at the time, in Sierra Leone, the entire health system collapsed in less than a week. This time— it was not, because we have learned from it. So let's be proud of what we've accomplished.

name: Kateřina Konečná
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, since the outbreak of the last major Ebola outbreak in West Africa in 2014, we have also had an epidemic of Zika virus and a few other less serious diseases. It seemed that the current situation in Congo could not be compared to what we experienced at the beginning of the mandate. And I am glad that both international organisations and the European Union have learned lessons from previous experiences.  So far, the numbers of both infected and dead are in the dozens, and the disease is kept within one state. Last time we were in the thousands, and Europe was also in danger. I very much welcome the WHO's decision to supply the country with new experimental vaccines. The European Commission has also adopted an urgent humanitarian aid package, the European Medical Corps is ready to assist on the ground, and ECDC monitors the situation and provides updates on the situation to all interested authorities.
