Of course, there is still a risk of transmission of the disease to other states, but let us trust our protection mechanisms. We have learned our lessons, we have set them up, and I firmly believe that, after all the previous crises, this will simply not develop into another crisis.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to point out that the Democratic Republic of Congo has declared this new epidemic, with 55 cases per moment and 29 deaths, which is far from negligible, as early as 8 May this year. Let us therefore leave aside the fact that I personally called for an urgent debate as early as the last plenary session – but, of course, if the request starts with a populist it is not even worth considering. The fact is, we lost a month. I would not underestimate this issue, as is probably being done here, because the problem is that there are more epicentres located in remote rural areas but close to the Congo River which, as you know, feeds both the Central African Republic and the Republic of Congo; therefore, the risk of rapid spread of the disease is very high. Yet, according to the World Health Organization, there is a vaccine, ZEBOV, which is 100% effective and which must be used before any other in an emergency. Commissioner, can you explain to us why you expect an epidemic to outbreak before proceeding with ring vaccination? Can you explain to us why a vaccine defined as safe and 100% effective is not being distributed now?

name: Joachim Zeller (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her work and for the work she has In May, the world was alarmed by the news that ebola cases had occurred in the northeastern Democratic Republic of Congo, in the area of the city of Mbandaka, and that people had already died from the Ebola virus. The fact that the disaster did not appear to have occurred, as in 2014 and 2015 in West Africa, seems to have been due to the rapid delivery of international aid and lessons learned from the epidemic of three years ago. Nevertheless, the fight against Ebola remains a challenge. The vaccine developed so far is very expensive, difficult to store and only has a preventive effect. Local conditions in the Democratic Republic of Congo make it very difficult to reach people outside major cities. In addition, the people there are suspicious of foreign organisations, some even suggest ingesling the fact that they only want to make a lot of money from the disease. Nevertheless, the threat of an Ebola epidemic highlights the disastrous political and social situation in the Democratic Republic of Congo, which urgently needs a solution. Otherwise, epidemics continue to threaten.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, the return of the Ebola virus to the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) has reinforced the feeling of fatality that hangs over the country like a veritable sword of Damocles. We are tired of ginning up the rosary of evils that are eating away at the DRC and foreshadowing an apocalyptic sequel. Had it not been for WHO relief, we would have counted several victims of the epidemic, due to the late intervention of the health authorities. The return of the Ebola virus is a sign of a poor prevention policy, an indication of the failure of the Congolese state. The evils that undermine the DRC are of political origin, as the republican and patriotic citizens we have received today have reminded us. They were the bearers of a memorandum whose content we share. We must accompany them in their struggle to restore the rule of law in the DRC through free and credible elections, without Kabila, and for the good of the Congolese.

name: Ελένη Θεοχάρους (ECR).
text: Madam President, certainly as a doctor you are, you know the term 'homeostasis'. The word in English is the same, "homeostasis" and introduces the concept of the balance of species in nature. I firmly believe that Ebola and AIDS are suffering precisely because homeostasis applies. And we need to know that if we want to deal with them. Four years ago, West Africa was hit by an Ebola epidemic and the European Union helped significantly, albeit belatedly, to tackle it. Last May, there was a new outbreak of hemorrhagic fever in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Hemorrhagic fever is an endemic disease in Congo and appears to have first manifested itself in that country's Ebola river.  Pandemics are dealt with drastically with quick and aggressive actions. Because in West Africa we were late, we have now reacted very well, so we have avoided spreading the virus. The European Union has provided immediate assistance of EUR 1.7 million to Congo for experts, emergency personnel and equipment. Of course, democratisation, health education, unhindered access to health services and education are fundamental measures to tackle deadly viruses.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The previous Ebola epidemic has mainly affected West African countries. It was deadly: several thousand people lost their lives. At this point, it is worth recalling that the European Union is at the fore front of supporting african countries, including in the fight against this severe disease. And it is worth thanking the European Commission for its great commitment in this debate. I am convinced that the negative effects of this epidemic would have been much greater had it not been for the excellent work and activities of our representatives in Africa. But more needs to be done, not only to combat the disease directly – such as the development of the vaccine – but also to develop education and raise the level of health care in these countries.

name: Enrique Guerrero Salom (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I hope that at the end of this month we can definitively declare the end of the current Ebola outbreak. If that is the case, the European Union, neighbouring countries and field authorities should be congratulated for learning from the past and for acting quickly, providing safety and vaccines.  But the humanitarian situation in the Democratic Republic of the Congo is alarming. In October last year, the United Nations declared the maximum humanitarian emergency ⸺ level 3⸺ for the country for the existence of two and a half million displaced persons and four and a half million people in food emergencies. The future is not promising: 18 of the 26 provinces of the Democratic Republic of the Congo are in this humanitarian alarm situation. Only 17% of the needs have been financed.  We need to do much more and we need to take the floor of the representative of the Council today, who recognises the need to do more, and who must do more to apply it to the countries of the Union.

name: Lukas Mandl (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner Stylianides, Secretary of State Karoline Edtstadler, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for her excellent work. We have a new Ebola epidemic in Africa, and the European Union has managed to help better than in the past. It has been stressed on several occasions, and we must stress this, that we need a Europe that is strong and can help to the outside world and can assert itself and is free internally and gives preference to freedom. I am therefore pleased that, under the leadership of Commissioner Stylianides, we have recently been able to negotiate the civil protection package here in Parliament in such a way that we are strong and able to help externally and are free internally and give preference to voluntary civil protection structures. However, we also need to talk to Congo and not just about Congo. We need to talk to Africa and not just about Africa. Today, at the start of the Austrian Presidency, Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker has positively highlighted the fact that Sebastian Kurz, like all strong reform forces in Europe, is looking for cooperation with Africa. Emmanuel Macron is doing the same, and we need it. Africa is growing. By 2050, there will be two billion people, now one billion people in Africa. It is important to help our future, and this is best done through economic cooperation.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: Please, let's stick to time. I only let him talk because it's really so important that we work with the Congolese, not the Congolese. Very important message, thank you!

name: Neena Gill (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I welcome the fact that the EU has stepped up again its support to fight Ebola in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). However, I believe strongly that the EU needs to broaden its remit and address also the political crisis in the country. We cannot overlook hundreds of people who have been killed in political protests and some 4.5 million people who have been internally displaced as a result of increasing militia activity.  President Kabila’s delaying tactics are holding the DRC’s political transition hostage. The government is asking for more control and management of all aid donations. I think this would be totally unacceptable. Aid groups in the DRC have already expressed their grave concerns about the vital work being prevented.  My questions to the Commissioner are: despite the scale and brutality of the crisis, the DRC has not been able to attract the needed funding from the last donor conference. How do we tackle the donor fatigue? Secondly, what assurances has the EU received that elections will take place by the end of 2018? And thirdly, what is the level of EU coordination with African leaders to move beyond the political stalemate that we have in the DRC?

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, truly present Ebola as a risk to our future. I think we have a duty not to underestimate this risk and to be truly responsible. Helping means seeking prevention, but also being humanitarian. I think there are probably two basic starting points that we should follow. However, this particular project of help can also have its other side effects, such as strengthening educational capacities, the space is constantly full of superstition, those people, for example, believe that if the body is burned, that the soul of the deceased can no longer run out of peace. There are a number of simply concerns that we need to support with education as well, and I think that is one of those other side effects that we have to carry out at the expense or in the effort to prevent it.  But we must not forget the political problems that the landscape is going through. And to obscure the specific human rights violations persuasively commit by the regime there. This – I think – should also be addressed.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Madam President, last week it was announced that the Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) was under control. However, it seems like the situation was never of major concern to the authorities as they have experience and competence in managing Ebola. So let us be clear: Ebola is not the only challenge currently facing the DRC. The deep political crisis in which the country finds itself is much more worrying. The criminalisation of human rights defenders continues, in particular, members of LUCHA and Filimbi. These attacks on rights activists come after decades of widespread human rights violations right across the country. So ahead of the elections finally due to take place in December, the country is now experiencing increased tension. Parliament should therefore not be distracted and should support all efforts for the elections to take place in a peaceful and democratic manner.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, we have dealt with the Democratic Republic of Congo many times here in this Chamber. We are all aware of the undemocratic actions taken by President Kabila, who refuses to end his term of office and constantly renews it. We essentially have a civil war, because the opposition does not tolerate Kabila's tertiaries and, of course, does not tolerate anti-democratic processes, it does not tolerate the imprisonment of activists. Therefore, this is a serious issue that remains and on which we must insist as the European Union. Of course, from the European Union's point of view, on the issue of the non-spread of the Ebola virus epidemic, I think that important action has been taken. Fortunately, it has been possible to prevent and limit the spread of the virus. I think that is what the International Health Organisation has contributed to and, of course, the money that has been given, the opportunity given for immediate vaccinations. Therefore, considerable efforts are being made to contain the Ebola virus, but Kabila must at some point leave power.

name: Christos Stylianides
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank colleagues for their contributions. We had a fruitful exchange of views. I once again realise that we all share the same concerns, not only on the Ebola outbreak, but also about the political crisis in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). This is why you remember our efforts in order to proceed with this pledging conference. The European Union and I were co-chairing in order to make this pledging conference for the DRC a reality, regardless of the participation of the Congolese government. The European Union remains very involved in all aspects of the situation on the ground in the DRC. At the same time, because the current discussions about Ebola, Ebola is a virus we cannot afford to underestimate, and we also agree that we cannot be complacent. Let me repeat once again that we will continue to stand by the people of the DRC until this outbreak is over. This is my personal commitment as Ebola coordinator. I would like to assure you that we are already looking at what we can learn from this experience, and how we can improve. Prevention, preparedness and response, including research, are all essential elements in tackling this, and any other, outbreak. We know that Ebola might strike again in Africa. As you said, the health-care systems are, unfortunately, so weak. And this is why, under the European and developing countries clinical trials partnership, the European Union has put in place two large networks of preparedness research. Among them there are 30 African partners covering the whole region of sub-Saharan Africa. These networks are building up the capacity of our African partners to better respond to outbreaks such as Ebola or other emerging diseases. I would like to take this opportunity to thank all who worked together to contain Ebola, all who cooperated and coordinated in order to respond more effectively and more efficiently to this latest outbreak on the ground. The first responders and the volunteers, the medical personnel and the experts. But also our hard workers in the Commission services and other EU institutions and our Member States. All of them determined to help the people of DRC in this time of need. I want also to underline the good and effective cooperation we had with the World Health Organisation on the ground, but also at the institutional level. Finally, I want to repeat that we are not letting our guard down. We will continue to monitor closely the situation 24/7. Let us always remember that health emergencies have no borders. No one can face such challenges alone. Only together can we better assist affected populations and protect our citizens, EU citizens. Cooperation and coordination are preconditions for any effective response. I would like to clarify something about our efforts regarding vaccines. The Commission is funding Ebola vaccine development to the tune of over EUR 160 million. The EU has provided funding for the vaccine which is now being deployed in the DRC. A second vaccine, which is currently being assessed by WHO, has also received EU funding. So the European Union and global partners are assessing where new research funding is needed for diagnostic treatments and vaccines, as well as ways to better communicate with affected communities and stakeholders to organise the response. I would like to say this as an answer, because I strongly believe that it is better to clarify some things about our efforts in this very demanding research field.

name: President. –
text: Commissioner Stylianides, thank you very much for your commitment. I now give the floor to our Minister of EU Affairs in the EU Presidency, Ms Karoline Edtstadler. Thank you very much for being here and for your serious commitment. We are listening to you. The floor is yours.

name: Karoline Edtstadler
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, Mr Goerens said ‘we all say the same thing’. Nevertheless, or on the contrary, because of this consensus, I would like to thank you for todays’ exchange of views and also for the applause and the congratulations, namely that we learned our lessons and sometimes this is necessary and also pleasant for all the participating institutions, especially for the Member States and the Commission. I am also with Ms Arena when she says it is clear that the topic remains of crucial importance to both Africa and the EU. Moreover, I fully second what was said during the debate, that many Congolese people have great needs in many regards and that we have to monitor the situation also with regard to the human rights situation, which is quite challenging. I would also like to stress once more that Member States have supported the World Health Organisation (WTO)-led response and we quick to contribute to the emergency response plan so that it was fully funded by 29 May. As a consequence, the virus didn’t spread to Europe because it was possible to prevent it from spreading, even within the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC). Not a single suspect case has been reported in the capital, Kinshasa. As we take over the baton, the Austrian Presidency will ensure continued monitoring of the development of the situation in the DRC. We will provide Member States with all the information they need to step up their response as necessary, in close coordination with the Commission, to make sure that the EU as a whole will remain at the forefront of combating this dangerous disease and prevent another Ebola epidemic.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The debate is over. Dear Colleagues, Allow me to make two announcements. I'll take them both in English.  Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The Ebola epidemic this year was the ninth epidemic in the Democratic Republic of Congo. I say she was because it looks like she was stopped at a fairly early stage. This time, a repeat of the 2014-2016 hekatomba, when more than 11,000 people died, was avoided. The number of victims this time is likely to close in about 30 people. Several factors influenced the rapid containation of the epidemic, such as the relatively low level of urbanisation in the region where it occurred, which limited the transmission of the virus. But it is important to stress the immediate response of the World Health Organisation in cooperation with local doctors, who, with the vaccine, have organised a very rapid action to vaccinate people exposed to the virus and to isolate people infected or suspected of being infected. As a result, we are talking today about dozens of contagions or suspected contagion. We will have to wait a few weeks for the end of the epidemic to be announced, but this action has shown how important coordinated action is to prevent the spread of the virus. Although it is necessary to emphasize that we can not celebrate the end of Ebola. This virus can surprise us again, either by appearing in new places, or by new mutations. But lessons from this year's epidemic need to be learned in order to implement more effective ebola defences.

name: Elnök asszony. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question addressed to the Commission by Claude Moraes on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the prevention of the classification of humanitarian aid as a criminal offence (O-000065/2018 - B8-0034/2018) [2018/2769(RSP)].

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Deputy author. Mr President, helping people in need is the moral duty of all of us. When a Danish motorist sees a Syrian family with small children trudging along the highway, it's just humane to give them a ride. When Spanish firefighters on Greek islands rescue people from drowning, they deserve our applause. Nevertheless, danish motorists and spanish firefighters were taken to court for allegedly smuggling people.  The 2002 directive, entitled 'defining assistance for illegal entry, illegal transit and illegal residence', stipulates that each Member State must have appropriate sanctions if a European citizen helps someone to enter or move into the country irregularly in that Member State, if this is against national law. The directive also says that if a European citizen is seeking personal financial gain, that Member State must prosecute that citizen. Because that's a crime. However, and I prefer to talk about irregular and not illegal, but if a European simply gives aid to a migrant without a right of residence, this should not be criminalised against smuggling under the United Nations protocol. The directive (in short) "description of aid" provides for a non-binding option for an exception for humanitarian aid in Article 1(2). But that exception is apparently not well understood in all cases, otherwise those Danish motorists and those Spanish firefighters would never have been prosecuted.  The European Parliament therefore calls on the European Commission to formulate clear guidelines for the Member States on the application of this Directive so that the exception is regulated and that the provision of humanitarian aid in the future is embedded in each Member State or in law or in practice, and we make clear once and for all which forms of assistance should not be criminalised in Member States. I think it is of the utmost importance to underline this.  In Malta, the ship the Seawatch is waiting for permission to sail. The ship the Aquarius is located in Marseille in the port, because she was no longer allowed to resupply in Italy. There are currently hardly any NGO rescue ships operating in the Mediterranean. This is despite the fact that the law in Italy is very clear: humanitarian aid is not a criminal offence. Also in Austria, in Belgium, in Germany, in the United Kingdom, in Finland, in Sweden, in the Netherlands, in Luxembourg, in Portugal, in Croatia, in Ireland and this list is not complete, in those countries too, there is some way between people smuggling for financial gain, a criminal case, and people who help out of humanitarian motivation. That distinction is very important. In France, the law has recently been tightened and it is becoming more difficult for aid workers to provide assistance. Whereas in Hungary, since the vote on the new NGO law, it has actually become virtually impossible to help migrants with simple things like food and drink and a place to sleep. So, while many countries at home distinguish between aid and exploitation, they seem to have lost sight of this in rescue operations in the Mediterranean.  Last week's Council conclusions state that all ships operating in the Mediterranean must respect the laws in force and should not stand in the way of the work of the Libyan Coastguard. Of course, all ships at sea must follow the law. Why should this be emphasised? Don't these NGOs follow the law? I think so. I think they respect the law and also the law of the sea in which one principle is very clear, namely that a drowning man must be saved. Why is such an emphasis placed on the operation of the coast guard of a third country? The UN Protocol against Smuggling, which clearly states that the provision of humanitarian assistance is not a criminal offence, does it also apply in the Mediterranean? And the European directive on the definition of aid, right?  So, Mr President, it is very much desirable for the European Commission to give the Member States clarity on the interpretation of the directive. Thank you very much.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me first thank Ms Sargentini and say that I have taken note of her advice. There are not many of us here tonight, but what we say and have to discuss tonight is very important and I would like to express my thanks to all colleagues who have brought this issue to the surface. I would like to tell you that the focus of all our actions at EU level with the Member States is, and has always been, to disrupt the criminal networks that make significant profits out of the smuggling of migrants to and within Europe. Our actions have been successful so far, although we shall not reduce our efforts until we destroy their business model entirely.  Thanks to our coordinated work and also to the EU-Turkey Statement, the business of the smugglers on the Turkish coast has already significantly decreased. With the support of Europol, many migrant smuggling networks have been dismantled.  These are the kinds of results that we aiming for. We do not want in any way to prosecute citizens and organisations that provide genuine assistance to those in it. Criminalisation of genuine humanitarian assistance should be avoided and, let us be clear, EU legislation on the facilitation of unauthorised entry, transit and residence does not require Member States to do so. On the contrary, it provides for the possibility to exempt genuine humanitarian assistance from criminalisation under national law and so far, eight Member States have provided some sort of explicit exemption.  The Commission understands Parliament’s concerns about how the EU legislative framework might impact citizens providing humanitarian assistance. So we take note of your request for guidelines to be issued on this delicate matter.  The Commission has done an evaluation of the Facilitators Package that was published last year. We consider that there is not sufficient evidence about the need to revise the legislation at this point in time. However, we acknowledge the perceived risk of criminalisation of humanitarian assistance as one of the main areas in need of improvement.  That is why we have started to engage with civil society representatives and the Fundamental Rights Agency. A first dedicated meeting took place in May, in Brussels, with the relevant stakeholders and agencies. Discussions on this issue also took place with Eurojust and national prosecutors at the end of May. We are expecting feedback from the participants, and we will continue this process.  Our objective is to create and maintain an ongoing dialogue and exchange with interested stakeholders. We want to gather evidence and foster a dialogue on the implementation of the Facilitators Package precisely to avoid criminalisation of humanitarian assistance. Such an exercise does not preclude other forms of reach—out or initiatives at a later stage should the need arise. I look forward to hearing your views.

name: Frank Engel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, let us be clear, it is not just a question of preventing humanitarian operations from being penalised or criminalised. It is also, and in my humble opinion, also a matter of ensuring that the passage of illegal migrants is not facilitated under the guise of humanitarian action, not because there would be too many, but above all because we are participating in this way in the sinister scheme of human traffickers. There are reasons to fear that a number of operators who are currently in the Mediterranean are there precisely for this reason, and I have a problem with that. Let these people do it even inadvertently, I will, but at the end of the day, we facilitate in this way a trade that I believe we have a moral duty, an obligation, to eradicate in the name of human dignity. And therefore, we really need to establish clear guidelines in all directions. What can be considered unacceptable, illegal aid, and what is clear from humanitarian action? In my view, action must be described as humanitarian, under supervision, under control and probably under the instructions of the official authorities responsible for such operations. We have recently witnessed in the Mediterranean an action almost sovereignly conceived by some captains who believe themselves not only empowered, but also allowed to act where no one has sent them, while others would also be there. This does not help Commissioner, and it does not help to give credibility to these operations. I believe that we need to ensure that everyone is and remains in their place.

name: Sylvie Guillaume
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D - Mr President, the criminalisation of humanitarian aid is becoming more and more common in the Member States. It is therefore urgent to recall that there is a directive on the issue, and the Commission's role is to explain how best to apply it.  We therefore call on you, through this resolution, to set out explicit guidelines. These should enable national authorities, in particular, to distinguish between smugglers and citizens who act in a selfless manner. Without this distinction, it will be difficult to be truly effective in the fight against the real criminals that are traffickers.  We must avoid the wrong target and the amalgamation of good-faith citizens with smugglers, especially in France, as my colleague Judith Sargentini pointed out. We therefore call for harmonization in this area. It is essential for the work of associations and actors on the ground to be known and framed throughout the Union.  The Commission's message must be clear in an increasingly suspicious European context towards migrants and those who help them.

name: Jussi Halla-aho
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, yes, people should be helped when in distress. But sometimes people get themselves in distress in order to be rescued. Everybody agrees that the migrants should not be drowning in the Mediterranean. At the same time, we must remember that the people who are crossing the sea are mostly economic migrants from sub-Saharan Africa. They are coming because both Libya and the Mediterranean are easier and cheaper to cross than they were 10 years ago.  These people take to the sea on rubber boats and other unseaworthy vessels because they know they have a good chance of being picked up by NGO ships that are waiting close to the Libyan coast, and of being ferried to Europe. Those NGOs thus contribute actively not only to the migration crisis here in Europe, but also to the humanitarian tragedy in the Mediterranean by luring people to the sea. Good intentions cannot be an excuse for anything. Stupidity should not be a European value. This maritime taxi service should not be able to operate with impunity.

name: Cecilia Wikström
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, usually in the field of migration we are asking the Commission for new or revised legislation, but in this case we have a directive, the Facilitation Directive, which is being applied differently in different Member States and therefore what we need from the Commission is guidelines. Of course, a regulation instead of a directive could help but, judging from recent experience with the asylum package, adopting a new regulation would take a very long time and we need to act much more rapidly on this. What is at stake? Well, this concerns the directive that affects citizens who are helping other human beings and providing humanitarian assistance at sea – and who can end up being charged with criminal activities. I chair the Committee on Petitions and we have received a number of petitions on this. I would argue that we need to do more so that we manage migration properly in the Union, but until this becomes the case we should not punish citizens for doing what every human being should do when they meet people in distress, at risk of losing their lives at sea. So we need the Commission, now, to provide guidelines to Member States to ensure once and for all that real humanitarian assistance is not, and will never be, a criminal act in the European Union.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, while we have this debate, a ship of the NGO Open Arms is heading to Barcelona with four fellow MEPs from this house after having rescued sixty people who, without the NGO Proactiva Open Arms, they would surely have died, just as four hundred people have died off the Libyan coasts earlier this weekend because we have basically expelled NGOs from the Mediterranean and have made a policy of training the Libyan navy so that it can have its own rescue and rescue zone, which it has shown that it is incapable of doing so, in violation of human rights. And the results are there. And, above all, we have moved towards the criminalization of the NGOs, which have been so essential. And not just in the Mediterranean. I would also like to remind the Sevillian firefighters of Proem-Aid, who were also accused of human trafficking for helping precisely refugees. And this criminalization of humanitarian aid must end. And it must end, inter alia, because, as has already been said, the United Nations Protocol against the Illicit Traffic in Migrants states in a very clear way that, in order to accuse someone of trafficking, there has to be a clear and proven profit and, secondly, because one can never accuse someone who is providing humanitarian aid of trafficking. And it is true, in our Directive, in the Border Pin Package Directive, we currently have simply an indication that Member States can introduce derogations from humanitarian aid in the event of accusing someone of trafficking, and that is not enough. We therefore ask the Commission to revise this Directive to oblige Member States to exempt humanitarian aid from penalties and to make those guidelines which have also been requested by other Members. (He refused to have Tomá-Zdechovsk-question him in accordance with the "blue card" procedure.

name: Barbara Spinelli
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, there has long been a more or less explicit criminalisation of anyone who assists people from third countries, by sea or by land. In practice, humanitarian aid is outlawed, despite clear indications that it is a crime to provide aid to those in danger. I am talking about the UN Protocol on trafficking in migrants and the Convention on the Law of the Sea. The facilitation directive contains ambiguities: one after another, the rules of European and international law are ignored or dismantled, even constitutionally in Hungary. We are preventing ships that search and rescue from disembarking in our ports, stopping those who stay with migrants fleeing in the Alps. In the Mediterranean there will be no more ships to rescue shipwrecked people, in the absence of any operations in this direction of the Union that did not Europeanise Mare Nostrum in time. We are going back to the 1930s, when international bodies gave in to the arbitrariness of rogue states. If the Eu ropean Union, the guardian of European law, does not offer clear lines that abolish the crime of solidarity, the colossal failure of the League of Nations will be repeated. I would like to end by thanking the interpreters and supporting their strike.

name: President. –
text: The next speaker is Mr Coburn and I can tell him that his team is in the lead.

name: David Coburn
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I am missing football for this so I regard it as a very serious issue. Prime Minister Orbán has quite rightly passed the ‘Stop Soros’ laws. The laws are aimed at stopping the influence of George Soros in Hungary. New laws make it a criminal offence to be associated with an NGO participating in criminal activity, with a 25% tax imposed on foreign money coming into them. And why not? NGOs should stop virtue-signalling and obey the law, whether on land or at sea. The Hungarians have every right to defend their sovereignty and their elected government’s ability to fulfil its manifesto promise of cutting down on immigration, which, of course, is damaging their economy and their capability in terms of social rights and everything else. NGOs seem determined to change the nature of Hungary’s culture, regardless of the views of the Hungarian electorate, by breaking Hungary’s laws. All nations have the right to protect their citizens’ jobs, healthcare and quality of life. It is not for NGOs to decide this [...] (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – In the last few days they have been in the news, the boats Lifeline and Aquarius, sailing under false flags with their obligatory radio beacons out. Sponsored by Doctors Without Moral Borders, they are part of the illegal migration chain, a chain that ranges from recruiting migrants in Africa to delivering those people to the country where they want to live. All links in this chain facilitate an illegal activity. The European Parliament is a big fan of these NGOs, which by picking up migrants just off the coast of Libya provoke the deadly smuggling of people across the Mediterranean. The European Parliament now believes that NGOs should never be prosecuted for people smuggling.  Mr President, criminal law is not within the competence of the European Union. The Member States deal with criminal law. This discussion shows that this is a good thing, because that means that also the adoption of the exemption rules on criminal law is a sovereign right of each Member State.   Mr President, NGOs are not above the law. Thank you very much.

name: Lívia Járóka (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European Allow me to state that I am a social anthropologist, a human rights activist, I have led a lot of humanitarian programmes myself – usually from my own resources – and that I fully understand the good intentions of my colleagues, but I must say that I agree with President Tusk, who said at last week's summit that all ships, including NGO vessels that are cruising the Mediterranean, must comply with the laws in force and should not interfere with the work of the Libyan border guard.  I'm glad we went in that direction yesterday. I do not want to speak out against the life-saving assistance of NGOs. However, as stated in Council Directive 2002/90 on assistance to illegal entry, transit and residence, measures must be taken to combat assistance to illegal immigration. Not only in the context of illegal border crossings in the strict sense, but also in the context of maintaining networks for the exploitation of people.  The current EU legislation does not preclude the criminality of those who help illegal immigrants, and even says that sanctions can be imposed in all Member States on those who illegally help people enter the territory of the state. Helpers, instigators must be punished.  Unfortunately, there are NGOs that are not on the right side. They are trying to hide this, and NGO organisations must respect the existing EU legislation without exception, and as we have heard, the hungarian government's aim was already to ensure that the judiciary can take action against those who transport it for money... (the President has withdrawn the floor from the Member)

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr President, at a time when migration flows are decreasing, however, the Mediterranean remains a mass grave exposed to the inaction of the Member States, which turn their backs on good humanitarian practices such as those of the new Government of Spain, which received the Aquarius and will receive the Open Arms ship tomorrow.  But the most outrageous thing is that this aberrant interpretation of the Aid Directive persists. Article 1(2) of that directive states that Member States 'may' exempt from criminalising those providing humanitarian aid in the rescue at sea. You must say "should".  It is therefore imperative that the Commission act to ensure that, under no circumstances, never again – nie wieder – humanitarian aid can be criminalized, allowing three Spanish heroes to sit on the bench: Manuel, Enrique and Julio of PROEM-AID. That no humanitarian organization has to pay with the penalty of the bench or criminal proceedings to have rescued lives at sea with sacrifice of one's own.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, you are asking that all Member States include in their legislation that NGOs operating in the Mediterranean should not be criminally prosecuted. Can we stay serious now! We have to face up to the fact that these NGOs are being used by people smugglers, so that the latter can be left out of harm's way. For example, the Aquarius passed all the safe havens in Tunisia to try to disembark in Europe. Médecins Sans Frontières went out of its way to bring African fortune seekers to Europe. Two days ago, the Spanish NGO Open Arms tried to sabotage a rescue operation by the Libyan coast guard. Two other NGOs did the same a week earlier under a false flag.  Then I ask you, what the hell are they doing? For us, the focus should be on saving people from drowning. The only way to achieve this is to stop the lucrative business of people smuggling. Therefore, illegal entry into the EU of fortune seekers should no longer automatically lead to a right of residence. Thank you.

name: Eva Joly (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, by declaring that NGOs are playing the smugglers' game, Emmanuel Macron is following in the footsteps of the Italian government. In addition to failing to fulfil its obligations to receive asylum seekers, to mistreat them from Calais to the Italian border, to lock up children and to condemn the humanity of solidarity citizens, France is now going so far as to attack head-on NGOs that address the shortcomings of the Member States. What a shame!  Taking these NGOs as scapegoats is playing into the game of the extreme right and other populists. Obstructing the work of NGOs only worsens the plight of those who cross the Mediterranean to escape the worst. The truth is that France, like many other states, prefers to attack citizens who show humanity rather than criminals who attack migrants. This has to stop.  Let NGOs and European citizens intervene unhindered. Better yet, assume for yourself what is a moral obligation.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF).
text: Mr President, unsurprisingly, the European Union is dissociating itself from the Member States which wish to penalise these associations which, under the guise of humanitarian aid, actually promote human trafficking. Claude Moraes' motion for a resolution is therefore a gigantic call for air in which the smuggling mafias will be engulfed tomorrow. On the contrary, we call on the European Union to toughen measures to combat illegal immigration and to close this Pandora's box now. We also call on Member States to increase financial sanctions against these NGOs, some of which receive opaque funding, as well as to confiscate their boats, such as the Aquarius. Like Matteo Salvini, let us send a clear message to the smuggling channels, as well as to all those who would be tempted tomorrow by illegal immigration to Europe. In short, the saving of lives in the Mediterranean should not be used tomorrow as a Trojan horse for a migratory submersion in Europe.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, always aiding or abetting the unauthorised entry or committing of any crime increases the possibility of not resolving the migration crisis, and I think that there have been a number of arguments that show that there is a need to appreciate those non-profit organisations that actually help, but, on the other hand, it is necessary to tell those who are only used to transporting economic migrants that they will not do their job in this way. This is not about criminalising humanitarian aid, on the contrary, we are happy for every volunteer, for every person who does his job in the non-profit sector for the benefit of a good cause.  On the other hand, we must say that a number of non-profit organisations or people who claim to be doing a non-profit activity are breaking the laws of the European Union and breaking the laws of the Member States, and we must start punishing them harshly. I cannot imagine that this activity would continue. What bothers the European Union and many of its citizens today, why they are sceptic of it, is precisely that non-compliance with the law. And the double standard within the entire European Union.  Finally, I would like to stress to my Green colleagues here that I do not understand how a politician can get on a boat and bring it to port, even though he knows that this ship is breaking the law. Personally, I'm not going to do it.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as European governments close in on their selfishness, there is another face of Europe: that of the many volunteers and organisations that save lives on land and at sea, trying to offer worthy welcome. Yet they are under severe attack, accused of favouring illegal immigration and even cooperating with traffickers, accusations that have proved completely unfounded in several judicial decisions. It is unacceptable to attack those who are only making up for the serious lack of a European humanitarian response. It is unacceptable that the ships of those who save lives at sea should have to fear legal consequences for complying with the obligation to provide assistance, which is laid down in international law: we are faced with a veritable criminalisation of solidarity. Do you really want to fight the traffickers? Open legal and safe access routes in all European countries. That is why we are also calling for a change to the aiding directive, making compulsory the clause expressly excluding punishment for those who offer humanitarian assistance. And we are asking all countries to introduce it.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, landings continue and deaths at sea have increased with them: one hundred deaths off Libya just a few days ago. But in this tragedy of our time it remains to be clarified the role of non-governmental organizations that provide assistance to migrants and that have, through their rescue actions, encouraged traffic.  In other words, the traffickers, aware of the presence of vessels flying the flag of countries in half of Europe and providing assistance at sea, have increased the use of sea carts for their dirty trafficking.  We are here today to call on the European Commission to reconsider the rules in force to define humanitarian assistance and to go through Directive 2002/90. The Italian Coast Guard has repeatedly complained that that directive, which applies in emergency situations, has instead become the norm.  The Member States of the European Union are required to water down legislation introducing criminal sanctions against the facilitation of irregular entry, transit and residence.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a crime of solidarity: that is the absurd concept we are discussing here today. With this concept, the anti-immigration Europe makes us take the form of an almost Kafkaesque absurdity. In Europe, the cradle of humanism, an ever-increasing proportion of the population has joined anti-humanism, so much so that the judicial leaders of some Member States are having to consider sanctions against citizens of solidarity, starting incredible trials against solidarity. The feeling of dislike of migrants is the political flag of xenophobic and populists, who confuse relief with crime and corrupt our certainties. At the beginning, in some European states, the crime of illegal immigration against migrants was invented; then someone commuted it into a crime of solidarity against their willing citizens. In this way, the traits of a process of barbarism of our society, which must be remedied, are travelling. We therefore also need clarity for our European directive. We must therefore repeat one thing: European citizens who help people in difficulty must be rewarded and awarded medals of civil merit, and it is completely misleading to compare them to human traffickers or to accuse them of aiding illegal immigration. Let us be strong, once and for all: the philanthropic action of our fellow citizens consolidates the primacy of the person! Legality is certainly important: but where people's lives are in danger, we must appeal to the legitimacy of solidarity actions.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, how can the European Council become embroiled in the lies of the extreme right, considering that disembarkation centres outside Europe are actually torture and detention centres as in Libya, where the coastguard is a fiction, it is in fact a militia trafficking human beings? How can European leaders embark in the narrative of the extreme right, seeking to criminalise NGOs for saving human beings from drowning in the sea? The Council has failed until today to give a ‘save and rescue’ mandate to EUNAVFOR MED Operation Sophia, which has nevertheless saved over 30 000 lives thanks to maritime law obligations. If our military, our coastguards and even our NGOs were to let people die in the Mediterranean, could European leaders look themselves in the mirror? Could they face their children and can they face their grandchildren? European Commission, do your job! Be the guardian of the Treaties and pass these guidelines preventing Member States from criminalising the saviours of what is left of our decency and humanity.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I am a little deaf from the speech by my previous colleague. I stand by the fact that helping people is really an expression of humanity. After all, history is an expression of helping people. Many nameless heroes have really helped, and they have an important place in history.  On the other hand, it is important that the rules are respected, and I am not sure that we can distinguish very easily between who is a smuggler and who is actually illegally breaking those rules and who is actually helping by saving people on the high seas. They, too, are responsible for plunging into the high seas and plunging into some danger.  I dare say the thesis that a taxi driver is not a savior. And this is where we should be leading the dividing line. If someone decides to board people even against the rules of Libya or possibly international law, they also put them in some danger.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the compassionate response of ordinary people to the humanitarian crisis facing desperate migrants and refugees, who are crossing Europe in search of safety and a sustainable life, is in stark contrast to the bureaucratic and political failure of the authorities. Many people have provided food, shelter and medical assistance to people on migratory routes across Europe, providing lifesaving acts of kindness where none existed. Shockingly, in France, Germany, Denmark, Sweden, Italy, Greece and the UK, some of these people have now been criminally prosecuted because the recipients of their compassionate acts are not nationals. This is pure unadulterated racism on the part of the authorities. This is saying that European lives are more valuable than others. It is absolutely unacceptable that the EU should remain silent when Member States use a European directive to criminalise assistance. Having worked in close partnership with several organisations providing humanitarian assistance on the ground, I fully support my colleague Claude Moraes’ call for the Commission to [...] (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the criminalisation of rescue NGOs in the Mediterranean begins here in the European institutions. A few hours ago, in this House, the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, warned NGOs: "Respect the law and do not hinder the work of the Libyan coastguards". It fills me with shame. I am ashamed that NGOs are attacked in this way, who are the only ones who do their duty to help. Since when did Mr. Tusk represent the paramilitaries of the Libyan coastguards? Proactiva Open Arms has recently denounced in this Parliament the criminalization suffered by all activists. First they were campaigns of discredit, then he moved on to military action, threats, shooting and kidnappings. Now he's going on to the prosecution. You can take note, Commissioner, as I said. Sea—watch and Lifeline are still held. This week four Members of this House witness the Open Arms rescue sixty people and the ports in Italy and Malta are closed to them. You, Commissioner, the problem is that you do not have a policy of rescue and welcome. What it has is a policy of faithful follow-up of xenophobic and racist policies of the far right.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, the desire and the attempt of illegal immigrants to enter the countries of entry in any case, especially in the countries of entry, has made these unfortunate people exploited by many different actors, first of all by illegal traffickers, and secondly by NGOs. You know that in all countries and especially in Greece, NGO employees have been profiting and continue to profit at the expense of illegal immigrants, violating their human rights that they are supposed to be fighting for. I give you an example in Greece where the police dismantled a brothel set up by NGO members and exploited young immigrant women and, unfortunately, children there. Finally, we also have so-called solidarity, who, in the name of ill-conceived humanism, knowingly help illegal immigrants either to enter the country illegally or to remain in it illegally. We must not confuse situations – it is a completely different thing to offer food to a hungry illegal immigrant and another to exploit and break the law. The state must prosecute these very illegal... (The President interrupts the speaker)

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: membre de la Commission. – Monsieur le Président, chers collègues, merci pour ce débat. Nous sommes d’accord pour dire qu’il s’agit d’un sujet délicat, mais important. Tout d’abord, il est clair que la non-assistance à des gens en danger de mort est non seulement inimaginable, mais aussi illégale en vertu du droit international. Nous sommes prêts à travailler avec vous pour empêcher la criminalisation et la mise en cause de citoyens et d’organisations qui aident ceux qui se trouvent en danger et dans le besoin. Cependant, nous poursuivrons notre lutte contre les passeurs et les trafiquants d’êtres humains, qui exploitent le désespoir des migrants. Je voudrais d’ailleurs souligner que les législations pénales nationales excluent déjà dans la plupart des cas la criminalisation de l’assistance humanitaire. Refuser l’aide à des personnes en situation d’urgence est même un crime. I would like to be very clear on that. The duty of assistance at sea to anybody in distress is already an obligation under international law. Now, as regards the situation in the Mediterranean Sea, it is essential that all those involved comply with international rules. This is our guiding principle. We should never forget that we are all working towards the same goal: saving lives at sea and putting an end to the business model used by smugglers to exploit human misery. Our objective is to replace this model by legal and secured pathways for those in need of protection. We have made good progress over the past few years in this direction, and we have to step up our efforts. As regards the situation in Hungary, the recently adopted legislative package raises concern as regards its compatibility with several aspects of the aquis. As we always do, we are examining it and, on the basis of the outcome of our assessment, we will take the necessary steps. It is very clear to us that we should not turn our backs on the values and the principles on which Europe is built. On a more general note, the Commission is aware of the challenges experienced by many civil society organisations in Europe, and is committed to supporting strong, independent and pluralistic civil society in the Member States. The Commission will continue to promote, within its competences, full respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. We will also continue actively to foster, support and preserve the role of civil society organisations in promoting and safeguarding the European Union’s fundamental rights and values.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The motion for a resolution to be submitted in accordance with Article 128(5) of the CRP will be announced at a later date. The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 5 July 2018. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – The first global study on migrant smuggling published on 13 June by the United Nations Office against Drugs and Organised Crime (UNODC), based in Vienna, revealed that at least 2.5 million migrants were illegally transferred across borders by people smugglers in 2016, making more than $7 billion ($1.9 trillion) in revenue. Migrant smuggling has become a global crime, which requires a serious response. They don't care about any lives, and unfortunately European NGOs are assisting in this when they are still ringing migrants from Libyan waters.  Most of the migrants are economic migrants. They are transported to sea without water, food or life jackets in crowded rubber dingboats, expecting to be quickly found and "rescued" by NGO rescue ships from Libya's coastal waters and then transferred to Europe. It must finally be said that the practice of NGO vessels 'vailing' migrants from Libya's coastal waters and then not returning them to Libya, which is a few kilometres away, must be put to an end, as this has become a very strong pull factor.  I therefore agree with the conclusions of friday's EU summit that, in order to permanently block the commercial activities of people smugglers and thus prevent a number of tragic deaths, the factors that lead people to embark on the dangerous journey must be eliminated.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on the definition of SMEs by Markus Pieper on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (O-000050/2018 - B8-0031/2018) (2018/2545 (RSP)).

name: Markus Pieper
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. First of all, thank you for the opportunity here today to answer this oral question. Ladies and gentlemen, private entrepreneurship in small companies is the real economy. These are business ideas with concrete services, with concrete products, these are the local jobs. These entrepreneurs and workers pay taxes. Taxes finance social benefits. From this point of view, small and medium-sized companies are the basis of society – by the way, Amazon and Google would be nothing, they would be nothing without the real business. That is another reason why we are in favour of a modern right to protection of benefits, and we are in favour of tax justice. Today it is a question of how we define small and medium-sized enterprises. The Commission has launched a consultation on this. The old definition of 250 employees and a maximum turnover of EUR 50 million has come of age. She is from 2003, she is almost 15 years old. As a Parliament, we have taken this as an opportunity to make two proposals. Firstly, we want to adjust the definition slightly upwards. Economic growth, inflation – we have to take this into account. Adjustment upwards also means a certain flexibility. For example, if companies receive funding over project periods of several years and exceed the thresholds during this period, then preferential access to funding must remain – there should be more flexibility here. The same applies to red tape relief. Here, too, there must be longer transitional periods if farms grow out of the classical definition. The second point is that, and this is a very important concern, we would like to invite the definition to take the issue of SMEs a little further. When companies grow very fast, management does not grow in all areas. To relieve bureaucracy would make sense, in a sense, as a thank you for the jobs, especially if these companies otherwise have very reliable characteristics – for example, they are owner-managed or have a high equity ratio. Commissioner, please also consider further reductions in bureaucracy. We often have companies with 1000 employees or more that should not be expected to be the full force of the legislation, for example because they produce very few hazardous substances due to the way they are produced, emit very little CO2, sell very little online, etc. – there are many examples. If we were to take small and medium-sized enterprises further here, for example, consider a mid-cap category, then we could deregulate more effectively. Exceptions could then be made for such companies in emissions trading, waste legislation and accessibility, which could be allowed – because it is only a matter of small things – without jeopardising European environmental or social policy in any way.  In this sense, therefore, we invite the Commission to make proposals , the adjustment of the thresholds and new discharge for a mid-cap category. You are in the consultation process, please take Parliament's suggestion with you. We also combine this – and this is also a very central concern – with the desire to make small and medium-sized enterprises in the Commission more of a cross-cutting task for all Commissioners and Directorates-General, because I believe that much more can be achieved here, particularly with binding tests for small and medium-sized enterprises, in the interests of compulsory seam tests, if we had this idea in all the Commissioners' IAtes, in all the Directorates-General, that we do not allow the full force of European legislation for all companies equally.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. –Mr President, let me update Members of the European Parliament on our work on the definition of SMEs, but I just want to start by reminding you of three figures that I am sure you all know. SMEs account for 99% of European Union enterprises. They provide 90 million jobs and they generate almost four trillion in value added.  We believe that SMEs should be able to operate in an environment that really enables them to start and grow their businesses, and we have been working across the Commission to address exactly this objective: from the start-up initiative, through our work on the single market initiatives, through a strict line on enforcing late payments, for example, to the New Skills Agenda. Administrative burdens, changing legislation, finding the funds: these are just some of the worries of small and medium-sized enterprises. The smaller the enterprise is, the heavier those worries weigh on them. An important element in this discussion is of course an SME definition. As you are aware, we are currently carrying out a thorough evaluation of the SME definition to examine if it is still fit for purpose in the current business and finance environment.  How are we doing this? By carrying out a wide-ranging, in-depth analysis and evaluations. We listened to SMEs via a targeted survey – almost 6 000 SMEs replied. We listened to all those who use the definition on a daily basis, to those who provide loans to SMEs or who relieve their administrative burdens or finance their ideas with a grant or State aid. So 150 individual interviews were carried out. We listened to all associations and other stakeholders that know SMEs and protect their interests. The public consultation received nearly 1 000 contributions and over 100 position papers. It was closed just recently in May. We are now considering all the submissions and carrying out a dedicated evaluation and an impact assessment. We also, of course, listened to the Members of the European Parliament.  What is more, this really vast consultation exercise was done on top of three earlier evaluations carried out in 2006, 2009 and 2012. No major issues were revealed back then but there have been developments in the meantime, especially in two rulings of the Court of Justice of the European Union in 2016, and these rulings pointed out certain issues that the wording of the definition might apply. It is particularly important and relevant in the context of groups of linked enterprises. I can confirm that this issue forms a part of the evaluation.  The second question refers to adaptation to inflation of the nominal thresholds used in the definition. On this aspect, again I can reassure you that this is also among the items covered by this evaluation. On the third point, the so-called mid-caps, we are of course aware of the challenges they are facing – and they are really facing a lot of challenges, for example scale-ups – and again, we are also looking into this issue and we are evaluating this. All the issues flagged in your questions are being specifically addressed, in addition to the whole spectrum of aspects that form part of our evaluation. The next steps will depend on the outcome of this global assessment. So due account will be taken to ensure that the burden on SMEs is limited to the minimum and that clarity and stability for those who use the definition are the underlying objectives. I am looking forward to listening to you.

name: Paul Rübig
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has done. We strive to ensure that from self-employment to the first employee in an SME, new employment can be created as quickly as possible and good wages can be paid. We do not want barriers to the top, we need to promote them and we need to reduce red tape where there is global success for our businesses. I have just looked at the pilot projects and the preparatory measures, and unfortunately there is not much support from the Commission. We have submitted e.B. the Female Business Angels. Of course, it is extremely important for young women and young companies to share ideas with each other on how to be successful, or we have submitted the capacity building for SME organisations. Yes, small and medium-sized enterprises, self-employed people do not have NGOs here in Brussels, and if they have any, they are not very well positioned. Then we also submitted the WTO dispute settlement – it is precisely here that small and medium-sized enterprises could receive support. Commissioner, I would ask you to support these projects. This is really a basis for new employment in Europe, and you are a guarantee that we will be able to achieve this together.

name: Patrizia Toia
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, mr Pieper's determination has led us to this important debate this evening. This is an opportunity to reaffirm the centrality of small and medium-sized enterprises in the European manufacturing system and the European economy. The Commissioner has reminded us very well with little data of the importance and value of this set of companies, including micro-enterprises and family businesses, which, however, have allowed the european continent's economy to be competitive and productive. I believe that we must continue along this path, and the current consultation, to which the Commissioner referred, is also intended to represent the will of the Commission and all the institutions, including Parliament, to work in this direction. I believe that small and medium-sized enterprises must be provided with the capacity to take advantage of the new opportunities offered by the resumption of exports to third countries, the recovery of competitive capacity after the economic crisis. We must understand that there will be no growth, not even for SMEs, without innovation and the ability to take advantage of the opportunities arising from the opening up of global markets. We know that innovation means not only targeting small and medium-sized enterprises that have a disruptive capacity and strong change, but also those that can allow incremental innovation, that gradually changes the ecosystem and makes it grow. In this sense, I think that, while it is true that 90% of the growth in the next few years worldwide will be generated outside the European Union, we really do have a task to accompany SMEs. We are familiar with the subject of credit, exports, internationalization, etc. Let me make one final comment: if it is true that we believe in SMEs, we must give them centrality and we must not confuse the plans. That is why it is important that any change in the definition criteria should take place on the assessment of the facts and with their contribution. Talk... (The President cut the speaker off)

name: Caroline Nagtegaal
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Small and medium-sized enterprises are invaluable to European countries and also to the Netherlands. More than half of all working Dutch people work for small and medium-sized enterprises. We actually buy all our stuff from SMEs. SMEs are the most important source of entrepreneurship in our society. If we like a centre of a town or village, it's usually because there are not only multinationals, but also because there are those smaller, local companies. That is why SMEs deserve our generous support.  In order to access funding and also to EU support programmes, the definition of SMEs is of incredible importance. That is why I want the Commission to first examine whether it is beneficial to adapt the definition rather than to decide directly that this should be done. Above all, let us not try to add more criteria to the definition. The wider the definition becomes, the more difficult it becomes for SMEs to claim the support it really deserves. I have told SMEs that the change in the definition is not necessary as far as it is concerned. So why would we change something that works well? Let's really make life easier and not harder for entrepreneurs. That is why I have also been working on simplifying VAT regulations. This is how we really help small and medium-sized enterprises and, with it, we all really move forward. Thank you very much.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, in this Parliament we are constantly talking about SMEs and their importance for the economy and employment, their number and the necessary legislative improvements that need to be made to support them, but when it comes time for truth and we discuss what an SME is, we find ourselves again with a lack of concreteness about its definition. Categories or indicators are established that leave the door open for larger enterprises and capitalization, such as medium-cap companies, to access SME support. This perverts the very meaning of what a small and medium-sized enterprise is.  Nor can we agree to allow a two-year adjustment period for companies that are no longer considered SMEs because they have increased their number of workers or turnover to adapt to the new regime to which they must be subjected. A company does not transform overnight: aid must occur in the transformation process, but not once the transformation has already been done.  In short, we are not moving forward with this definition proposal; more so, SMEs are not going to benefit from it. The result will be the opposite: indefinition and profits for larger companies.

name: Dario Tamburrano
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, on this screen too, I read the title of the description 'Definition of small and medium-sized enterprises' on this screen this evening. Yet this dossier has, from the outset, been marred by repeated attempts to include arguments and positions that do not concerning SMEs. They are the backbone of the European economy, and we know that. The policy to support them is based on a definition that today makes it possible to clearly classify the vast majority of European companies as SMEs. SMEs are counting on a clear definition that changes as little as possible over time. That is why it must continue to be based fundamentally on the criteria of the number of employees, turnover and balance sheet. However, in the discussions that preceded this day, we have always asked not to mix up the plans, including in this resolution definitions and hypotheses of funding for mid-caps, new criteria or indicators that value exports or other aspects, without there having been a real impact assessment of some proposals. We will therefore oppose dealing with issues of this magnitude unless the text is amended with the amendments.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE).
text: – European SMEs are in a paradoxical situation. On the one hand, it is they who form the basis of our economy, bring jobs and development to the regions, and today they are already making a significant contribution to innovation, on the other hand they are suffering from underfunding, the unavailability of credit and an increasingly complex bureaucratic environment. If we are to help them better, we must have a clear and functional definition of what a small and medium-sized enterprise actually is in our conditions. What was true in 2003 before the rapid development of the Internet and modern technologies, before the advent of new forms of business, can no longer reflect reality. It is no longer enough to say that this company has so many and so many employees, so it is in such a category. We have start-ups and various technological ecosystems. Financial instruments and the reality of the market have also changed over the last 15 years. In short, the definitions in force today, on which both European and national legislation are based, no longer stand. Let us therefore look for new ones that reflect reality and cover micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, start-ups and other existing forms of entrepreneurship. However, let us also look to the future, when the conditions have been changed in this way in 15 years' time, which is another 10 years to come. The European Commission needs to start working on a definition of small and medium-sized enterprises that not only suits the status quo, but is also open to the changes that will inevitably come.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D).
text: – Mr President, small and medium-sized enterprises account for 99 % of europe's business fabric, more than 90 million jobs, generate 3.9 billion of added value. The consolidation of an appropriate definition of SMEs is therefore a key step towards the health and competitiveness of the European economy, as well as for balancing its social fabric.  It is essential to ensure simple processes and legal certainty. Thresholds, in particular the number of employees and capital, must be sector-weighted but at the same time objective in their definition.  The key to the definition should be the ability to contribute to better access of these companies to markets and innovation and modernisation mechanisms.  The definition of a mid-caps company, in addition to the definition of SMEs, cannot reduce the access capacity of SMEs to the various EU programmes. It only makes sense as a process of adding opportunities and not competition for the same resources.  The definition of SMEs must strengthen these companies on the basis of the European economic and social fabric and that is the challenge to which the Commission must respond.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Small and medium-sized enterprises are a real powerhouse. More than 99% of companies are SMEs. They employ more than 90 million people in Europe. They generate more than 4 billion added value. But on the other hand, these are the companies that are the hardest on the market. They suffer from a lack of access to capital, excessive bureaucracy, rigid labour law or high living costs. It is these companies that need public support, but in order for this support to be effective, it is necessary to be able to define well which companies belong to this sector and which do not. The world, on the other hand, is changing. The economy is also changing. New forms of economic activity, new business spaces are being created, including on the Internet. Therefore, a definition that is based on traditional criteria, such as the number of employees employed or turnover, does not fit into the present day. It is therefore worth considering a new definition so that we, as the European Union and the Member States, can support this very important sector of the economy more effectively.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, 99% of companies, ninety million workers, as has just been said. This shows that the data show that not only are small and medium-sized enterprises a source of employment and wealth, but they are a very important element of vertebration and social cohesion in Europe. But it is necessary to create an environment – as was shown – more appropriate to bring about improvements and to boost its growth. Improvements in the definition, simplify administrative barriers that so hurt their competitiveness, promote export, promote programmes to support innovation and modernization, and establish support mechanisms. Some are expected in the next Multiannual Financial Framework. It is necessary to provide resources to gain in extension, to gain in competitiveness, to improve environments and to continue to generate employment and economic activity.

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr President, we do need to modernise the definition of small and medium-sized enterprises. We've moved on to the new era. And the number of workers must change and turnover must be widened. However, in addition to the update, we must also look at the trap. And the trap is nothing more than to create a new special category within small and medium-sized enterprises, which will have easier access to finance. These are medium-sized enterprises which obviously have much greater and easier access to the markets for money and capital as they grow their businesses. We must take account of the legal specificities, because the European Central Bank's latest report on the access of euro area businesses to finance typically states that in my country, Greece, small businesses were disproportionately affected. 21% said the most important problem they face is finding resources. So we do need new criteria. However, care is also needed for micro-enterprises, to facilitate their financing, to tackle their problem and to help them recruit from an employee.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I believe that we should actually help in this case, too, where I think it is not that difficult. This is about the definition of small and medium-sized enterprise. The real strength of the economy is recognized precisely by the strength of small and medium-sized enterprises.
